of Perama Working, but poorJust outside Morecambe, a tourist town that no longer draws so many tourists, George McCullough, a single parent to a six-year-old son, is&nbspin financial meltdown. His rent has&nbspfallen into arrears, and he can&nbspno longer pay the family’s utility bills. He’s started&nbspto dip into his overdraft, incurring further bank charges.He’s&nbspstopped socialising and sometimes skips&nbspmeals to ensure that his son eats&nbspthree times a day. But he can&nbspno longer afford to give the boy a balanced diet or a new school uniform, or take him to see friends.“He basically can’t go to any of his mates’ parties or houses,” McCullough says. “I literally can’t afford to pay for a gift, or even to take him there.”What&nbspthrew&nbsphis affairs into crisis was the transition to universal credit. Before the welfare changes, McCullough received around £685&nbspevery month to supplement the roughly £500&nbspa month he earns as a bus driver for disabled children.It’s&nbspnot just that he now receives&nbsproughly £40&nbspless a month, though for a family that was already struggling to stay above the poverty line, the cut – the cost of a week’s groceries – was painful. (Others have experienced worse: the average working family has lost more than £75&nbspa month, according to calculations by the Child Poverty Action Group.)What has really hurt McCullough&nbspis&nbsphow that loss is&nbspcompounded, severely, by the problematic rollout of universal credit in 2016.Under the new system, all claimants have to wait at least five weeks for their first payment –&nbspa dangerously long delay for families living hand-to-mouth. In McCullough’s case, the delay was long enough to throw him into a vicious cycle of debt.By this May, the family had almost climbed from the hole when they were hit by a second quirk of the universal credit system. After his employers paid him early, giving him two payments in one month, officials wrongly concluded that his salary had doubled and cut his benefits. For several weeks, they refused to admit their mistake, plunging him back into debt.In Morecambe, the problem is compounded by cuts to local children’s services. Before austerity, schools could quickly refer vulnerable families to a local state-funded children’s centre“If this is going to be a regular occurrence,” McCullough asked, “where is the incentive to work?”McCullough’s experiences are not unique. The government’s own research into the system found that nearly half of claimants needed help to fill out the application form, while four in 10 were still facing financial difficulties eight months into their time on universal credit.Duncan Smith, who was the secretary of state for work and pensions between 2010 and 2015, acknowledges&nbspproblems with the way the system has been put into effect.&nbspHe even resigned in 2015 because the finance minister at the time, George Osborne, cut an additional £4bn&nbspfrom the welfare budget. “I thought that was too much,” Duncan Smith says.But “the system itself is the right system,” he adds. “Though a large number of working families are still in poverty, they were in deeper poverty when they were out of work. As they move into work, they’re better off.”Back at McCullough’s, the father’s eyes well&nbspup as his phone buzzes&nbspwith debt notices from the local water board, and he describes&nbsphow he struggles&nbspto provide his son with some of the basic things in life – like fresh vegetables, new clothes and haircuts.McCullough voted Conservative in past elections and says he would do so again if an election were held tomorrow. Despite his travails, he supports the party’s cautious approach to state spending, and he thinks there are too many people expecting handouts for nothing.But he no longer believes that restructuring benefits will get more people into work, or more children out of poverty.“Until you walk a mile in someone’s shoes, you can’t know,” McCullough says. “Until you’ve seen how it works, you don’t understand.”In Morecambe, the area’s Conservative MP&nbspDavid Morris&nbspsays in an email that child poverty had fallen in his constituency, and blames&nbsp“left-wing political activists” for any suggestion to the contrary. In previous interviews, he has accused headteacher Collingwood of having political motivations for speaking out.But the demand for free breakfasts at Morecambe Bay Primary is not the only warning sign.The relative child poverty rate in Morris’s constituency rose to 25.9 per cent from 2013 to 2017, up from 24.2 per cent, according to research by the Centre&nbspfor Research in Social Policy at Loughborough University. That may not sound like much, but the rise has produced marked changes on the ground.How social supermarkets are filling a gap in austerity BritainAt the Morecambe Bay Foodbank, for instance, the number of children who received at least one parcel of free food has almost doubled to 1,229 in 2017-18, from 656 in 2013-14. At the local branch of Citizens Advice the number of food vouchers distributed to children in the same period increased sixfold, to 1,336 from 222.In Morecambe, the problem is compounded by cuts to local children’s services. Before austerity, schools could quickly refer vulnerable families to a local state-funded children’s centre, where social workers would work with children and parents to solve their problems.Since 2010, however, roughly 1,000 of these centres have been closed across Britain after about £990m&nbspin funding cuts. Those that remain – such as those in the Morecambe area – have substantially reduced their capacity.“The caseload is growing, and the system&nbspby which we would have supported them is diminishing,” Collingwood says. “We feel much more like an island.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Anyone can post in open comments. story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsAt the end of the 19th&nbspcentury, playwright JM Synge&nbspescaped to the&nbspstripped back and simple life on&nbspInishmore, Inishmaan&nbspand Inisheer. Today, little has changed on the islandsClick to followThe IndependentIn the 1950s, transportation on the islands was by a pony-drawn cart and even today there are few carsThe last time I saw Bridin Concannon, she was walking towards me along the narrow road on the westernmost edge of the island of Inishmaan, off the west coast of Ireland.“Were you out at Synge’s Chair?” I called out as she approached.The sun behind her hung, unmasked by clouds, low and long in the Irish early summer sky.“I was,” she said. Her voice was strong, clear – the way one’s voice can be when exhilarated. “I’ll start writing a play soon.”Trump cancels trip to Ireland after massive protests plannedWe both laughed loudly, and strode past one another. She was headed back towards the village and I towards the cliffs over the North Atlantic, to a perch of limestone that the author frequented during his time here, a spot known locally as Synge’s Chair.The Irish playwright JM&nbspSynge (1871-1909) first came to the Aran Islands in the summer of 1898 looking for inspiration and to learn the Irish language. Over the next several years he would return again and again, growing more connected to the people and the wind-and-sea-battered land they inhabited.Synge’s most famous work&nbspPlayboy of the Western World&nbspwas inspired by a story he heard while on the islands, and caused riots in Dublin when it was first staged in 1906. The foremost playwright of the Irish Renaissance – a movement inspired by strong political nationalism and a revival of Celtic traditions – Synge was co-founder of The Abbey Theatre, also known as the National Theatre of Ireland. All six of his plays are either set in or heavily influenced by his time in Aran.The three remote Aran Islands of Inishmore, Inishmaan and Inisheer hide in plain sight in the mouth of Galway Bay. They are still predominantly Irish-speaking, insular and, as even in Synge’s era, considered a place lost in time.It was the poet William Butler Yeats who suggested that Synge come to these islands. “Go to Aran,” Yeats told his friend. “Live there as if you were one of the people themselves express a life that has never found expression.”Synge grew more attached to the islands over time, and I had a notion that repeat trips might similarly enhance my appreciation of Aran’s more subtle charms. I decided to visit the islands over a period of several months, from early spring to high summer. I hoped that my repeated act of return and departure would elicit in me the sense of investment, as well as illuminate details and patterns of day-to-day local life that are the deep appeal of such places as Aran, places not needy of a traveller’s attention.Synge took a steamer from Galway that sailed at the mercy of the tides, on the rolling sea, and transferred into a currach, a small canvas-covered fishing boat, to make it to shore. These days things are slightly easier, with a daily ferry schedule as well as light aircraft service.My initial impression of the largest island of Inishmore from the ferry was not dissimilar to Synge’s:.&nbsp“A dreary rock appeared at first sloping up from the sea and into the fog,” the author wrote in The Aran Islands –&nbsphis classic account of his time here, first published in 1907. “The place looked hardly fit for habitation. There was no green to be seen, and no sign of the people.”Part of the considerable allure of Aran lies in what it lacks. There are no cinemas and few cars electricity only arrived in the 1970s. Seventeen-year-old Thomas Kennedy summed it up for me within minutes of my arrival when he said:&nbsp“There’s no facilities here – you rely on the people.” And while much has remained unchanged since Synge’s time, society has reached the islands. Synge wasn’t confronted with the dozen or so glamping structures visible on arrival, for one. And the pierside Atlantic Hotel, where Synge resided while on Inishmore, has been transformed into the Aran Sweater Market.But beside the shop, three pubs, one food shop, a restaurant and a handful of bed and breakfasts, there is little else in the way of commerce. The 12 square mile island is home to roughly 760 people, most clustered around the main settlement of Kilronan, with the vast majority of terrain given over to small parcels of grazing and farmland, delineated by Aran’s most dominant feature, its dry-stone walls.“You have to be OK within yourself to live here,” Melissa Gillian told me as I stood eavesdropping on a wedding reception outside the Aran Island Hotel. A Maine native, she married a local man and has lived on Inishmore for 10 years. Gillian was one of only a handful of outsiders I met over the months – all are married to locals her sentiment was one I heard often, on all three islands.Most visitors stay only a few hours, travel a well-worn circuit and hustle back onto the boats for the comparative metropolis of Galway or the pubs of Doolin. But it is during the early morning hours, and again later in the afternoon once the last ferry of the day has gone, that the island’s deeper appeal emerges.If you’ve seen one image of the Aran Islands, it is likely to be an aerial shot of Inishmore’s Dun Aengus, semicircular stone walls that abut a 300-foot sheer cliff above the Atlantic. The initial walls of this ring fort – one of seven to be found on the islands – date back to 1100BC, and it is next to impossible not to gravitate to the site while on Inishmore. A visit at daybreak was rewarded by absolute solitude, as the wind whistled over the stones. Birds caught thermals below the cliffs. Clouds raced across the sun. Time stretched.As I was leaving, the buses began to arrive. I sat on a wall eating a Nutella crêpe&nbspand watched coach after coach deposit people with fanny packs and (unneeded) sun hats. Though watching the human drama of group tourism from a slight remove has its own rewards, I had a date with a magic well.Early on during Synge’s first visit to Inishmore, he met a man who told him a story. A Sligo woman, it seems, had a dream that her blind son might be made to see if she travelled to a particular well out on the Aran Islands. She did so, and upon touching the well’s water to her sightless child’s eye, he exclaimed, “O mother, look at the pretty flowers!” Synge would use this story and his visit to the site as the inspiration for his play&nbspThe Well of the Saints.My local map indicated the well as a tiny dot not far off the road, yet I’d cycled past it twice without luck. Finally I caught sight of an old sign that directed me over one stone fence and then another, through several fields, until I came upon the ruin of a tiny building:&nbspThe Church of the Four Beautiful Persons&nbsp(no one I met on the island could explain the origins of the name). I stepped over cow pats and entered. The sun emerged and the grey stones brightened. by Pope Francis in the visitors book at Aras an Uachtarain in Phoenix ParkJust beside the small church, I found the shallow well, still encircled by limestone, still filled with lightly running water. A tin cup had been left beside it, and someone had tossed in a small crucifix. A small pile of stones, similar to the ones that covered the well’s floor, sat next to it, apparently meant to be thrown in the well. As a long-ago lapsed Catholic, this ritual seemed to me somehow more pagan than Christian. I tossed a few in, thinking of my children.Back in town, the crowds were converging for the afternoon ferry to the mainland. On impulse, I grabbed my bag, deciding again to follow Synge’s lead – this time to another of the islands.After only a brief stay on Inishmore, the playwright headed for Inishmaan, of which he noted:&nbsp“Gaelic is more generally used, and the life is perhaps the most primitive that is left in Europe.”I wondered how much things had changed, and as I headed to the ferry for the short crossing to the middle island, Loraine Conneely, an Inishmore native, read my mind. “You’ll see,” she said. “It’s still the same over there. It hasn’t moved.”If the traveller is greeted with a (relatively) bustling arrival on the big island, no such welcome – in fact, no welcome at all – awaits the visitor in Inishmaan, which is less than four square miles. The ferry dock is a half-hour walk to what passes for a village (there is one shop and one bar). Life, as it did in Synge’s time, revolves around the caprices of weather and the ties of community.Little energy is spent looking outward – exactly how the 160 inhabitants prefer things.Over my months of coming and going, I encountered many of the same people again and again on Inishmaan: Ciaran O’Ceallaigh, who was raising his son on the island because he wanted him “to grow up in a true Irish-speaking environment” Bartley Conneely, who owned 21 acres and six cows, and could easily be persuaded to give a visitor a lift to the ferry and the pair of ladies I often saw when out walking, who cautioned me against staying too late up at the ring fort of Dun Fearbhai, lest the fairies interfere with me.Synge noted many stories of strange happenings on the island. “These people make no distinction between the natural and the supernatural,” he wrote. But he also eloquently described a people living a hard-scrabble life very close to the elements: “Of beings who feel their isolation in the face of a universe that wars on them with winds and sea.” Synge encountered people who carried themselves with workaday dignity and offered a humble, sincere welcome – exactly what I found on Inishmaan 120 years later.“We’re ambivalent about tourists on this island,” the restaurateur Ruairi de Blacam told me. “You’re left to go about your business. Get a map – you’ve got shoes – and off you go.” De Blacam is a local boy who made (extremely) good. In 2007 he and his wife, Marie-Therese, opened Inis Meáin, the singular high-end restaurant and inn on the islands.“It’s unlikely, if not impossible, we could have done this if I wasn’t from the island,” he said as I sipped some of his delicious lobster bisque and watched a setting fireball sun slash light across the limestone just outside the restaurant’s picture window. “You need the people’s support.”He continued: “We’re on a precarious perch out here in the ocean. People lean on each other in all sorts of ways. When I was a kid, I went around with a candle and people still dressed in traditional clothes. Ireland was 20, 30 years behind the rest of the world, and Aran was 20, 30 years behind Ireland.”The sun dropped, as Synge wrote of a similar sunset a century earlier, “like a lozenge of gold flame into the sea” and the ocean was cast in a purple hue.“But things are moving fast we’re catching up a bit,” de Blacam smiled and placed a dish of scallop ceviche with toasted almonds in front of me.“What you have to understand is that the people here live a very simple life. And we’re here by choice. There’s an understated pride, and the legacy of Synge is certainly a part of that.”Very much so: The cottage to which the playwright returned each year – a small, whitewashed, thatch-roof affair – has been preserved as a museum of sorts. Though it’s technically open to the public, hours vary, and it took some doing, to track down Ciaran O’Faherty, whose great-grandparents had offered Synge a bedroom in what was then their home. Once I finally cornered him in the pub, O’Faherty was happy to oblige me with a look. On this island that insists on existing out of time, the cottage’s green front door was a portal through the century things inside remain as Synge had described: “My room is at one end of the cottage … There is a kitchen with earth floor and open rafters … It is full of beauty and distinction.”As much as Synge relished his island home, he spent most of his days out walking the land. Over on the far western side, atop high cliffs, he found a stand of rock looking out over Galway Bay and Inishmore that he would return to again and again. “As I lay here hour after hour, I seem to enter into the wild pastimes of the cliff,” he wrote.This was when I found myself headed out to Synge’s Chair. The semicircle cluster of limestone created a natural barrier against the elements, cradled the visitor and invited lingering. Each of my visits was similar time slipped the way time can when there is nowhere to go: at first excruciatingly slowly, then in a blink, the day would be gone.With just the one pub for action, nights on Inishmaan are quiet and even a loner can yearn for society. As Synge did, I made the short crossing to the smallest island of Inisheer (on two occasions I was the only ferry passenger from Inishmaan). Upon coming ashore, Synge was confronted with a man –&nbsp“a drunkard and shebeener” – who lived “with the restlessness of a man who has no sympathy with his companions.” Upon my arrival I was met with an only slightly less distressing social challenge.As on Inishmore, the day tourist trade had taken hold. There were horse and trap rides, coffee carts and stands selling local fudge. But just beyond the flurry of town, Inisheer, with its 250 residents, is perhaps the most physically picturesque of the three Aran Islands, and its three square miles make it easy to navigate on bicycle. (Bikes were readily available directly off the ferry on both Inishmore and Inisheer. Not surprisingly, there was no bike rental on Inishmaan.)Atop the island’s highest hill, beside the ruin of O’Brien’s Castle, Aine O’Graiofa had put a few tables out in front of her home and called it a restaurant. I took a seat in the driveway and settled in for one of Ireland’s staple country lunches – ham and cheese on toasted white bread – while looking down across Galway Bay to Connemara in the distance.Inisheer boasts three pubs, one shop and a church.“The priest died four years ago and they haven’t sent another,” O’Graiofa told me. “We’re left to our own devices.”We chatted of the decline in the church’s dominance over the people throughout Ireland.“Sure it’s their own fault,” she said. “We have the old schoolteacher who goes up and leads folks in the rosary that’s all we need.”Watching a ferry cross the bay down below, I asked if it was heading for Inishmaan.Businesses call for gay marriage to be legalised in Northern IrelandHIV rates rise in Northern Ireland – despite falling across rest of UKThe motley crew lining up to contest the Irish presidential election“I doubt it. You go over there and you don’t see a soul they’re all hiding behind the stones.”We laughed, but soon enough I made my way down to the dock.Back on Inishmaan I walked past the old graveyard from which Synge took inspiration for his play Riders to the Sea, and continued up the hill, across from Synge’s cottage and up over five stone fences and through five small fields to the ring fort of Dun Chonchuir. Synge would “often stroll up there after a dinner of eggs or salt pork, to smoke drowsily on the stones.”Like Synge, I had sat on these walls and viewed the sea in nearly every direction, but on this evening, a fog rolled in. The air became moist. Summer changed to autumn in a matter of minutes. I could barely make out the far end of the small fort enclosure. With no wind, a heavy silence hung in the mist. title: mercedes benz brexit production move nissan plant sunderland
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsDaimler-owned brand looked into using Nissan's Sunderland plant to manufacture carsClick to followThe IndependentMercedes-Benz boss revealed the now-dropped plans at the Paris Motor ShowMercedes-Benz had been considering moving production to the UK ahead of the EU referendum in 2016, but decided against the move after the vote for Brexit, the car maker’s chief executive has revealed. Dieter Zetsche, outgoing head of the brand, told Paris Motor Show attendees that he had begun negotiations with Nissan regarding potentially using its Sunderland plant to build Mercedes-Benz cars. “Before Brexit there was one project where we were looking at an option of producing cars in Sunderland together,” he said. Mercedes-Benz owner Daimler formed an alliance with Nissan and Renault in 2010. Earlier this year, Nissan announced that it was cutting hundreds of jobs at the Sunderland operation, due to falling demand for diesel vehicles. Mr Zetsche shared no further details about the now-abandoned plan, the Times reported. A number of other car makers issued warnings at the Paris event, with Toyota stating that a no-deal Brexit would lead to a temporary stoppage in UK production, primarily at its Burnaston plant. Toyota warns no-deal Brexit would stop UK productionAston Martin cuts target share price for stock market listingUK car manufacturing falls again as industry demands Brexit safeguardUK car sales plunged 20 per cent in SeptemberThe Japanese company’s Europe president, Johan van Zyl, said it was difficult to predict how long the stoppage period would last. Meanwhile, Maxime Picat, executive vice president for Europe at Vauxhall owner PSA, said leaving the EU with no deal would disrupt production. “We’ve been doing all we can to develop our UK business, restore Vauxhall and Opel profitability, reinvesting in Luton and improving our sites’ competitiveness in order to help them face up to an uncertain future,” he said. “But there are limits. Those limits are customs barriers, and the loss of freedom of movement, for people and goods. If we get to that point, we will be obliged to take measures.“If we suddenly have to start manufacturing for the UK in the UK, and for Europe in Europe, there will necessarily be an impact on UK production.”Several car makers have called for Brexit negotiators to avoid a no-deal scenario, warning that such a departure would hit production and investment in the UK market. BMW recently said it would bring a planned shutdown of its Oxford plant forward to begin on the same day the UK leaves the EU, in a bid to minimise the potential disruption a no-deal Brexit would create.Meanwhile, Honda has said that a no-deal Brexit would cost it tens of millions of pounds, while Jaguar Land Rover has moved workers at its Castle Bromwich plant to a three-day week because of “continuing headwinds impacting the car industry”.Ralf Speth, Jaguar’s boss, has previously warned that tens of thousands of jobs in the UK motor industry are at risk if a no-deal Brexit goes ahead.He also said the current lack of clarity around Brexit means he does not know if his plants will be able to function after 29 March 2019, and added that interruptions to production could cost up to £60m a day.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - It is comparable in size to its&nbspplanets, roughly the same size as Neptune – orbiting a planet as big as Jupiter.The two are floating around their own star 8,000 lightyears away.Nasa releases statement about bizarre International Space Station leakIt was found in the same way that scientists discovered those thousands of exoplanets: watching for the small dips that happens when they move in front of their star, and working out from those how big it is and what its orbit might be like.They looked at data from&nbsp284 planets found in that way by the Kepler Space Telescope and tried to find those that had anything strange about their orbits.One of those planets, known as Kepler 1625b, seemed to be behaving strangely.&nbspWe saw little deviations and wobbles in the light curve that caught our attention, Kipping said.They watched the planet for some time, and noticed that soon after it passed in front of its star, there was another dip of light, which appeared to be a moon trailing the planet like a dog following its owner on a leash.It also seemed to be passing in front of its star slightly sooner that might be expected, which would be consistent with the kind of wobble that would happen because of a moon's gravity.&nbspAn extraterrestrial civilization watching the Earth and Moon transit the Sun would note similar anomalies in the timing of Earth's transit, Kipping said.It is possible that the strange behaviour could also be caused by another planet in the system, and hope for further data from space telescopes to confirm their findings. They are demanding £5 per drop &amp £1 per mile as a minimum rate.Matt Rouse, a striking kitchen worker at Wetherspoon’s Bright Helm pub in Brighton said he had been inspired by his co-workers to “call out injustice in our workplaces”.He added: “We are determined to stand together and make our demands for £10 an hour for all, and union recognition heard.&nbsp“This is only the beginning, we will keep fighting for everyone, for better wages and rights for hospitality workers across the country”A bad Brexit could cripple workers’ rights Uber responds to calls for greater protection of workers’ rightsCBI says UK in slow lane. Boosting workers rights could change thatMcDonald’s, Wetherspoon and TGI Friday workers to strike next monthWetherspoons bans dogs from all their UK pubs as of todayThe hospitality sector employs around 4.5 million people – ten per cent of the UK’s working population. But its workers have not traditionally organised to demand better pay and conditions, making the current strike&nbspsignificant, despite its small scale.Shadow chancellor John McDonnell backed the action and reiterated Labour's plan to give all workers a living wage of £10 an hour.&nbspI am giving my support to the striking workers in Wetherspoons, TGI Fridays and McDonald's today, he said.These are workers that have been ignored by their employers and are simply asking for a wage they can live on and the same basic rights at work we should all be entitled to.Boni Adeliyi, a TGI Fridays waitress in Milton Keynes said: “We’re striking on 4 October to show the strength we have when workers come together. The movement is growing and change is coming. All young workers should join a union – it’s important to know your rights and how to fight for them when they’re being ignored. Together we are stronger.”&nbspStriking McDonald’s worker Lauren McCourt said the industrial action could transform the sector for the better.“The days of poverty pay, insecure contracts and lack of respect for workers are numbered. title: uk new car sales plunge september smmt emissions standards brexit
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsNew UK car sales in the year so far are 7.5 per cent behind where they were this time in 2017Click to followThe IndependentAn economist warned that market uncertainty will put consumers off buying cars in the short termUK car sales plunged 20.5 per cent in September, which is usually a strong month for the market, largely because of new emissions standards, while Brexit uncertainty also caused decline. &nbspNew figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) showed the total number of new vehicles registered in September was 338,834, down from 426,170 in the same month last year, with diesel vehicles recording a 42.5 per cent decline. In the year to date, car sales are 7.5 per cent behind where they were this time last year.The SMMT said the decline in September followed an “unusually high August and a turbulent first eight months of the year as the market responded to a raft of upheavals”&nbspmainly changes to diesel policy after new emissions standards were introduced. UK car sales drop as manufacturers warn Brexit is hurting industryUK car sales drop as diesel demand plummets for 14th month in a rowUK car sales expected to drop for two years, warns motor industry bodyMike Hawes, SMMT chief executive, said: “With the industry given barely a year to reapprove the entire European model lineup, it’s no surprise that we’ve seen bottlenecks and a squeeze on supply. These are exceptional circumstances with similar declines seen in other major European markets. “The good news is that, as backlogs ease, consumers and businesses can look forward to a raft of exciting high-tech cars and a market keen to recover lost momentum.”Ian Plummer, Auto Trader director, said 2018 has been “very challenging for both retailers and manufacturers, with the fuel debate and Brexit anxieties denting consumer confidence, and inflationary pressure on exchange rates hitting profits”. However, he added: “Despite the many economic uncertainties, there is some positive news on the horizon for 2019 too. The plethora of new electric and hybrid vehicles that are on display at this week’s Paris Motor Show are not far from hitting forecourts, giving consumers some great new choices in this emerging fuel type which grew again last month.“What’s more, as more consumers move away from traditional ownership to usership models, the appetite for finance remains exceptionally strong.”However, Samuel Tombs, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said consumers were unlikely to begin buying cars in great numbers in the near future. “Finance costs likely will continue to rise gradually, while the recent rise in motor fuel prices might dissuade some first-time buyers. High levels of saving intentions also suggest that buyers will be cautious when considering major purchases. Accordingly, the chance of a substantial revival in car sales over the next six months remains slim,” he said.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Anyone can post in open comments. That compares to the legal minimum rate of £7.83 for people aged over 24, which is set to rise to at least £9 by 2020.Wetherspoon boss Tim Martin said the company’s employees were its most valuable asset.“It is understandable that there is pressure on pay with low unemployment and a housing shortage,” he said.Labour 'would give gig economy workers full employment rights'PwC throws spotlight on two tier gig economy with flexible work offerUnion defeats Deliveroo in latest round of gig economy rights caseMcDonald’s, Wetherspoon and TGI Friday workers to strike next monthLiving Wage Foundation unveils pay rise for thousands of workers“However, bonuses, free shares and other benefits should be taken into account in&nbspassessing pay.”About&nbspa quarter of Wetherspoon employees own shares in the company and all staff are entitled to discounts on food and drink at its pubs.Staff in a number of UK cities are set to strike and a rally is scheduled to take place in London’s Leicester Square.Some Uber Eats couriers have said they will not log-on to the food delivery app between 5pm and 6pm in protest over a cut in rates. The concept is that when a butterfly flaps its wings, it can cause a catastrophe'Click to followThe IndependentA volcano on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi has started to spew lava causing an ash plume to rise two-and-a-half miles into the air.&nbspMount&nbspSoputan&nbsperupted days after a powerful earthquake and devastating tsunami rocked the island, killing more than 1,400 people and injuring hundreds more.&nbspOfficials believe the death toll will rise over the coming days and weeks.&nbspAlthough the volcano is situated hundreds of miles from the where the tsunami hit,&nbspthere are fears that the ash that has been spewed into the sky could hamper aid efforts.Appeal launched for Indonesia earthquake as aid begins to arriveVolcano erupts on same island as earthquake-stricken city of PaluWhat is liquefaction and what role did it play in Indonesia?Over 1,200 confirmed dead after Indonesian earthquake and tsunamiA government volcanologist said it was possible the eruption was accelerated by the magnitude 7.5 earthquake that struck late last week.&nbspIt could be that this earthquake triggered the eruption, but we have seen an increase in volcanic activity since July and this began surging on Monday. Yet we can't say there a direct link, as the mountain is quite far away, said&nbspthe head of Indonesia's Volcanology and Geology Disaster Mitigation Agency, said on local television.&nbspKasbani, who only uses one name, said planes were warned to avoid the area as volcanic ash is hazardous to plane engines.National disaster agency spokesman Sutopo Purwo Nugroho&nbsptold a separate&nbspnews conference in Indonesia's capital&nbspJakarta, that no residential areas are within the 4-kilometre danger radius.&nbspThe volcano agency said the public should avoid the area nearest the volcano and masks would be made available in the event of ash fall.&nbspNazli Ismail, a geophysicist at the University of Syiah Kuala in Banda Aceh on Sumatra island, stressed there was no concrete evidence to show the two incidents are linked.&nbspPeople talk about the butterfly effect. The concept is that when a butterfly flaps its wings, it can cause a catastrophe, he said.&nbspSo it is possible for the earthquake to trigger the volcano eruption, but it's not conclusive. title: emmanuel macron news france approval rating G rard Collomb
story: The French President was dubbed France&rsquos first &ldquomanager-president by French media after intimate details of his bizarre behaviour towards his government were published.His approval ratings are now as low as beleaguered former leader Francois Hollande when he began to decend out of the Presidency, according to a poll that showed 33 percent of voters approave of his actions compared with 67 that do not.In a flurry of embarrassing articles it was revealed the 40-year-old colour-codes his diary, sends 2am text messages to members of his parliament, handles all communication personally and interferes in minor matters to seize any breadcrumbs of power left in the wake of his interior minister&rsquos resignation.He also bans staff talking to French media without first his consent in signs the president&rsquos power machine is spinning out of control less than 18 months since he won the election.Interior Minister G&eacuterard Collomb announced he was stepping down to run for his old job as mayor of Lyon earlier this week despite the president, who he had loyally supported, refusing to accept his notice.                 French interior minister resigns TWICE in less than 24 hours                France would prefer 'NO DEAL BREXIT' to a 'bad deal'Mr Collomb&rsquos desire to leave government &ldquoas soon as possible would undermine Mr Macron&rsquos legitimacy, it was claimed. His departure added to mounting disharmony towards a president whose approval ratings are now as low as his predecessor Fran&ccedilois Hollande at 30 percent.This, insiders say, could also be in part down to Mr Macron running such a tight ship while in office.Mr Collomb breached Mr Macron&rsquos media consent rule before jumping ship to make the astonishing declaration Mr Macron &ldquolacked humanity.Mr Collomb told BFMTV: &ldquoWhen you become too sure of yourself at some point you think you can in everything.The French President was dubbed France&rsquos first &ldquomanager-president by French media (Image: EPA)                Belgian minister BLAMES UK for EU's migration woes                Brexit Secretary launches BLISTERING attack on French President MacronThis earned Mr Collomb, who would be the seventh high-level official to leave their post since Mr Macron&rsquos presidency, a plea from French voters to stick around for another year, but he refused.Other officials in Mr Macron&rsquos team who have stepped down include defence minister Sylvie Goulard and former party chief Richard Ferrand to name a few.French Environment Minister Nicolas Hulot was another who quit, having citing huge differences with Mr Macron as his reason, adding &ldquoI can&rsquot lie to myself anymore.Despite displaying a lack of control over his own matters, Mr Macron has waded into foreign affairs on several occasions, most recently declaring Britain should be entitled to a second EU referendum &ldquofor sure.Mr Collomb breached Mr Macron&rsquos media consent rule before jumping ship (Image: )Yesterday, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab accused Mr Macron of &ldquounsavoury political posturing and tactics and says the EU negotiating strategy &ldquoseems designed for political purposes of drawing a wedge across the UK in a retaliation of the president&rsquos meddling in Brexit negotiations.

title: Brexit news UK Theresa May EU Conservative Party European Union Chequers
story: Brexit supporter and Conservative MP for Chingford and Woodford Green pointed out Theresa May did not mention Chequers once during her speech.Speaking on Channel 4 News, Mr Duncan Smith suggested this was a &ldquocrucial shift in the Government&rsquos targets for Brexit negotiations.He said: &ldquoWhen she spoke about Brexit, what was quite interesting is that there has, I believe, been a shift in the position for the Government.&ldquoNot one single mention of the word Chequers. And mostly mentioning free trade and also wanting to do that deal on free trade with the European Union.                Brexiteer MP lashes second referendum bid with CRUCIAL point&ldquoAnd asking the European Union essentially to open to the further discussions.&ldquoI think that suggests to me quite strongly that the Prime Minister and the Government recognise that existing Chequers proposal is not acceptable to the EU, is really not acceptable to most MP&rsquos and therefore a shift in what we are asking them for, which is free trade, which is what Barnier said he wanted to give us is pretty much the right track to take.&ldquoSo, I am intrigued. I am very supportive of her as she listens now to what is I think, the inevitable, and goes down that road.The Channel 4 News host Krishnan Guru-Murthy stepped in pointing out that Theresa May&rsquos &ldquovision of Brexit was a Common Rulebook.Mr Duncan Smith replied: &ldquoIf she was saying that she would have talked about Chequers.&ldquoWhat was quite clear today was that she did not talk about Chequers she talked about a free trade deal with the European Union.&ldquoI wholly support that, that is absolutely the right thing to do. A very special deal with them.The Prime&nbspMinister's&nbspChequers plan has received huge criticism from EU leaders and from leading Brexit supporters in her own party.During her speech at the Conservative Party conference on Wednesday, Mrs May she wanted a good Brexit agreement but warned the EU Britain isn't afraid to leave with no deal if we had to.She said: Don&rsquot let anyone tell you we don&rsquot have what it takes. We have everything we need to succeed.She added: &ldquoWe will not betray the result of the referendum. And we will never break up our country. I have treated the EU with nothing but respect. The UK expects the same.Brexit news: Iain Duncan Smith hinted at a shift in Mrs May's Brexit approach (Image: &bullC4NEWS)&ldquoIn a negotiation, if you can&rsquot accept what the other side proposes, you present an alternative. That is what we have done.&ldquoOur proposal is for a free trade deal that provides for frictionless trade in goods.Although,&nbspbacking her plan, Mrs May said: &ldquoSo this is our proposal. Taking back control of our borders, laws and money.&ldquoGood for jobs, good for the Union. It delivers on the referendum.&ldquoIt keeps faith with the British people. It is in the national interest.

title: Brexit news Gerard Batten Theresa May speech deal latest UK EU withdrawal
story: The incensed British MEP insisted the Prime Minister had undermined the progress of the Brexit negotiations with her unwillingness to share the details of her demands.Mr Batten appeared unimpressed with Theresa May's speech at the Tory Party Conference on Wednesday, putting into question her ability to deliver a withdrawal deal with the European Union after backing Remain at the 2016 referendum.Speaking to RT UK, the leader of Ukip said: How can we trust her? She was a Remainer up until the day of the referendum.Why would you believe anything she says? You can only judge her on results and so far there haven&rsquot been any results.                Lord Sugar launches SCATHING DIG at Brexit in Apprentice opener                Farage warns THIS aspect of May's speech signals Brexit to get worseMr Batten suggested the&nbspfailure to propose a deal based on a pre-existing EU trade deal with other non-EU countries had put in jeopardy the successful conclusion of talks with Brussels.He also claimed Mrs May had done little to have the bloc respect her during the negotiations, further decreasing the chances of a new arrangement.He continued: There are two things I&rsquod like to pick up on, one was talking about offering the EU a free trade deal. Well, yeah, why doesn&rsquot she do that?She could say to them &lsquolet&rsquos have continued free trade.&rsquo You have 58 free trade agreements with countries around the world, none of them include the free movement of people, and she could have said &lsquowell, you&rsquove got plenty of these on the shelf, we can customise one pretty quickly, you can make your mind up about it. We can have one of those or you can have WTO terms.&rsquoBrexit news: Mr Batten put into question Mrs May's ability to deliver Brexit (Image: BBC&bullRT UK)Why doesn&rsquot she do that? She talks about seeking respect from the EU, that&rsquos the other thing. Why would they respect you if you are not actually telling them what it is that you intend to do and you keep on asking &lsquohow do we leave, can we have this?&rsquoThey&rsquore not going to respect somebody like that.Prime Minister used her speech to issue a rallying cry for ministers to unite and back her plan following weeks of party feuding.According to Bloomberg, Mrs May wants to rush her final Brexit deal through Parliament in weeks in an attempt to fight off opposition to it from her Conservative Party.Brexit news: A confident-looking Mrs May kickstarted her speech dancing to ABBA (Image: )People familiar with the matter have reportedly said her team wants the final withdrawal agreement signed off by lawmakers within two weeks of the terms being agreed with the European Union.This would see Parliament vote on whether to accept or decline her proposals by the beginning of December following a summit of EU leaders on the weekend of November 17-18.Ministers believe reaching a deal quickly will provide enough time to pass important legislation through Parliament before the UK exits the bloc on March 29.The pound rose on Thursday following a report Ireland is backing Theresa May's plan for an all-customs union with the EU.Sterling had fallen to $1.2922 overnight - its weakest since September 10 - but recovered to increase 0.2 percent to $1.2967 and 88.61 versus the euro.

title: Brexit news update Tim Martin Wetherspoons Femi UK EU trade deal
story: The Wetherspoons boss was questioned by Mr Oluwole on the UK's post-Brexit trade opportunities and to give an example of any nation in the world trading with countries that are not on the same continent.&nbspWhen Mr Martin gave the valid example of Australia, the young Remainer argued that the top countries Australia trades food with are the ones that are geographically closed to it.&nbspBut the prominent Brexiteer hit back replying: &ldquoI think the point is we can still trade with the EU under World Trade Organisation rules.And when Mr Olwole claimed trading&nbspunder WTO rules would increase&nbsptariffs and make food more expensive, Mr Martin said: No, the opposite.                Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling advances despite no-deal threat                Farage warns THIS aspect of May's speech signals Brexit to get worseHe added: &ldquoWe can have zero tariffs on imports from the entire world once we leave the EU.It comes as the Prime Minister&nbsptold Tory delegates at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham that striking a frictionless trade deal with Brussels would secure the certainty British business will need to operate in the future.In her speech, Mrs May said:&nbspOur proposal is for a free trade deal that provides for frictionless trade in goods.It would protect hundreds of thousands of jobs in the just-in-time supply chains our manufacturing firms rely on.Businesses wouldn&rsquot face costly checks when they export to the EU, so they can invest with confidence.Brexit news: Tim Martin shuts down Femi Oluwole on post-Brexit trade (Image: FEMI OLUWOLE&bullTWITTER)And it would protect our precious Union &ndash the seamless border in Northern Ireland, a bedrock of peace and stability, would see no change whatsoever.No simple free trade agreement could achieve that, not even one that makes use of the very latest technology.She added: Our proposal would mean we could renew our role in the world, strike new trade deals with other countries.With control of our money, we can spend more on our NHS.With control of our laws, we can bring decision-making closer to the people and returning powers to Westminster, Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast.And with control of our borders, we can do something that no British government has been able to do in decades &ndash restore full and complete control of who comes into this country to the democratically elected representatives of the British people.A strong critic of the Prime Minister's Brexit strategy, Nigel Farage has claimed Mrs May's focus on frictionless trade in her conference speech was a sign a much worse deal than her Chequers plan would be reached at the end of the negotiations with Brussels.&nbspHe warned: There was a phrase in her speech that I think commentators really properly noticed. Frictionless trade, what does that mean? That means, basically, the deal has been done.This isn&rsquot just going to be Chequers, which she couldn&rsquot even mention because she knew she might get a little bit of abuse from the floor.This, by the time she comes back in the afternoon of 19 October, will be much worse than any of the Eurosceptics feared Chequers was going to be.

title: Brexit news SNP Nicola Sturgeon fisheries CFP Scotland latest UK EU withdrawal
story: The Scottish MP launched a scathing attack on the Scottish National Party for attempting to betray Scottish fishermen with their demands for a second Brexit vote.Last week Aberdeenshire South council became the first local authority to officially back a new vote on leaving the European Union when SNP councillors joined forces with Labour and Green colleagues.But Mr Thomson did not take well to the news, telling the audience at a Fishing for Leave event the decision was an attempt to keep Scotland under EU rule: I am astonished that SNP members representing fishing communities would seek to betray fishermen, to drag them back into the Common Fisheries Policy and disregard their views altogether.It is vital we keep speaking up for Brexit and for what it will do to revitalise our fishing industry and our coastal communities.                Fishermen face 'REAL CHALLENGES' as EU quota makes the RICH RICHER                May says Sturgeon is BETRAYING SCOTLAND with fishing industry plansThe CFP, which allows European Union vessels access to UK fishing grounds and imposes strict quotas, is despised by many British fishermen who blame it for decimating what was once a national industry.Despite voicing opposition to the CFP and it granting permission to EU vessels to catch fish in British waters, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has remained an outspoken critic of Brexit &ndash going as far as suggesting Scotland be allowed to stay in the single market in 2017.Mr Thompson continued: Freed from the Common Fisheries Policy, we as a nation will be able to conduct our own fisheries policy on our terms.&nbsp That means stopping free access to our waters for European boats.It means sustainable fisheries and having plenty of our fishermen to catch plenty of our fish.Brexit news: Mr Thompson tore into the SNP's attempts to keep Britain in the EU (Image: SKY NEWS&bullYOUTUBEFishing for Leave)He added: We&rsquoll also be free from EU regulation decided by the unelected and the unaccountable that only serve to put additional burdens on our fishermen.Delivering her speech at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham, Theresa May also blasted the Scottish First Minister for her efforts to keep the country tied to the EU customs union.In a direct message to Ms Sturgeon, the Prime Minister warned keeping Scottish trawlermen in the CFP would be a betrayal of Scotland.Mrs May said: &ldquoOur proposal would be good for our rural communities, getting us out of the Common Agricultural Policy. It would be good for our coastal communities.&ldquoWe would be out of the CFP, an independent coastal state once again. And with the UK&rsquos biggest fishing fleets based in Scotland, let me say this to Nicola Sturgeon.&ldquoYou claim to stand up for Scotland, but you want to lock Scottish fishermen into the CFP forever. That&rsquos not &lsquoStronger for Scotland&rsquo, it&rsquos a betrayal of Scotland.

title: Brexit news Galileo satellite system UK EU withdrawal airbus latest Barnier
story: The British CEO appeared positive about the global prospects of the British space sector after Brexit.The European Union has threatened to stop Britain from using the shared Galileo satellite system after its withdrawal from the bloc due to security risks but Mr Martin insisted there are opportunities for the country all around the world.Mr Martin told Sky News his company has already begun to seek new commercial partnership with non-EU countries: I am bullish. The great thing about space is that it&rsquos a global industry.When you think about the way satellites work, floating around the whole world, you can do business anywhere. We want to maintain a strong relationship with Europe but we are already looking at opportunities in North America, South America, Australasia, Asia.                WE&rsquoLL DO IT OURSELVES! UK space team issue WARNING to BrusselsThe chief executive also suggested British companies will explore new opportunities even faster after the UK ultimately breaks off ties with Brussels in March 2019.Mr Martin added: That will continue and that will accelerate even faster.Figures published on August 9 suggested the UK could compete for contracts to launch an estimated 2,000 small satellites by 2030 thanks to the burgeoning British space sector.The data also suggests Britain is well placed to thrive even if the European Union does deny the country access to the Galileo satellite system after Brexit.Brexit news: The satellite company boss said he felt bullish about the prospect for the sector (Image: &bullSKY NEWS)EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier threatened to cut the UK&rsquos access to the Galileo system after its withdrawal from the bloc despite the &pound1billion contributions to the overall &pound8.5billion costs.Airbus Defence and Space, the aerospace company at the forefront of much of the technology which is powering the Galileo satellite system, said they are ready to deliver a rival system if Brussels follows through on threats to exclude Britain after Brexit.Business development director Andrew Stroomer told Express he has no doubt his team has the know-how to build a stand-alone satellite navigation system out of a facility which currently builds an impressive 25 percent of the world&rsquos telecommunications satellites.Mr Stroomer said: &ldquoWe would like Galileo to continue with the participation of the UK but if you look at Galileo, the UK has contributed some of the most complicated parts of that.&ldquoWe don&rsquot do everything &ndash but we do enough to show we are capable of building such a system for the UK. From an industry point of view, we have the capability.&ldquoThere would not be a conflict of interest. It would mean working with the UK government as a customer.

title: Brexit news Theresa May Dominic Raab EU deal latest
story: With Conservative Party Conference finishing yesterday, the Prime Minister and Brexit Secretary turn their attention back to Brexit negotiations, with the October 18 summit edging closer.The European Commission announced last night the political declaration, which will shape the UK&rsquos future relationship with Brussels, will have to be be published on October 10.The Prime Minister was locked in phone conversations with EU leaders this morning to try and smooth things over after her Chequers Brexit plan was rejected by member states last month.One Cabinet minister involved in the process told the Sun: &ldquoWe need some very fancy footwork to get the Withdrawal Agreement wrapped up by the October council.                Theresa May really gave the speech of a lifetime, says LEO McKINSTRY&ldquoBut deadlines always concentrate minds.&ldquoThe PM will be hitting the phone hard and we think it&rsquos just about doable.The 27 EU leaders will meet to discuss Brexit on October 17, during another lavish dinner before the start of the EU summit.The document is seen as a turning point for the negotiations and Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is expected to make a the trip to Brussels to meet his negotiating counterpart Michel Barnier next week as he desperately attempts to piece the declaration together.Theresa May and Dominic Raab have been given six days by Brussels to nail down a Brexit deal (Image: Getty)The Prime Minister was chained to her phone with EU leaders this morning (Image: Getty)Mr Raab and Mr Barnier will have to break the delicate Irish border impasse before full talks on a future trading relationship can begin.The EU&rsquos solution to the Irish issue is a border in the Irish Sea, but it has been rejected by Theresa May, as she claims it would effectively slice Northern Ireland away from mainland Britain.The Prime Minister has now formulated a plan which involves &ldquospreading the pain on where the future of the Irish borders lie between the UK, the EU and Ireland.She hopes her proposal will move negotiations on by accepting a number of regulatory checks between Northern Ireland and Great Britain.                BREXIT: May to RUSH deal through in WEEKS to fight off Tory rebellion                Brexit news: Varadkar holds EU meetings as Irish border solution nears Dominic Raab is expected to make a the trip to Brussels to meet his negotiating counterpart  (Image: Getty)EU diplomats believe there is a distinct possibility the Irish backstop could be resolved ahead of the next October European Council summit.However, one diplomat revealed to Express people &ldquoshouldn&rsquot get their hopes up for a deal to be concluded at the gathering.A further intensive four-week negotiation is scheduled to take place before another Brexit summit in November.

title: farmer Jim stops 250m film studio
story: Jim Telfer&rsquos family has worked Pentland Mains in Midlothian for more than 100 years (Image: Press Team Scotland)His landlord Nick Gibsone, an advertising executive, went to the Scottish Land Court in an attempt to have Jim and his family removed.But the tribunal, which rules on landlord-tenant disputes, found that the Telfers should not be forced out against their will.Chairman Lord Minginish QC and farming member Tom Campbell said in their judgment that the effect of Mr Gibsone&rsquos plans on the family would be &ldquoto dispossess them of all&nbspof their land, including their home and means of livelihood.They added: &ldquoWe recognise that deciding the case in such a way&nbspthat a project said to be of national importance does not go ahead is a serious matter.                RBS slammed after just two branches are saved                Solar panel scam gang jailed after conning victims of life savings&ldquoHowever, this is not the only place in Scotland on which such a development can take place. The applicants&rsquo pleadings tell us that 28 sites were considered, then the list shortened to two, of which the Pentland site was preferred.The farmhouse was first occupied by Mr Telfer&rsquos grandfather in 1915. The family own the house and&nbspbuildings but the land belongs to the Gibsone family.Mr Gibsone said after the ruling: &ldquoOur family is devastated by&nbspthe land court&rsquos decision and its consequences for us. We are not by any means a wealthy family and the current estate is little more than&nbsp100 acres. We have spent five years trying to make the best of what&nbspwe own and leave a lasting legacy that would be of benefit to the many, not the few.&ldquoWe had hoped to reach an amicable agreement with Mr Telfer which would have resulted in&nbspsubstantial compensation, and this remains the case.Jim was forced from his home to make way for Scotland&rsquos &pound250million national film studio (Image: Press Team Scotland)&ldquoWe are disappointed not only for ourselves and the developers, but for Midlothian and Scotland, with the loss of hundreds of potential jobs and the boost to the economy the film studio could deliver.&ldquoWe must now consider all options, including appealing to the Court of Session.The Scottish Government and other supporters of the project hope it will attract Hollywood stars and millions of pounds of investment to the country.But Andy Wightman, the Green Party MSP who has campaigned&nbspon behalf of Mr Telfer, condemned the way the farmer and his family have been treated.He said: &ldquoQuite why the landlord, the developers and some voices within the Scottish film industry&nbspignored the fact that a sitting tenant has legal rights that have now been upheld is for them&nbspto explain.                Prince Charles all smiles in kilt on Scottish visit - where&rsquos Camilla?                Police operating 'postcode lottery' on drunken loutsThe tribunal found that the Telfers should not be forced out against their will (Image: Press Team Scotland)&ldquoWe have been consistent in our support for our constituent throughout this process, and&nbspwe hope that the stress and anxiety facing Jim and his familyis now over.&nbsp&ldquoIt is now incumbent on industry and the Scottish Government&nbspto deliver the much-needed national film studio on a site where development would be lawful.Jim shares his 60-acre smallholding outside Edinburgh with his wife, daughter and granddaughter.Daughter Mary Begbie, 53,&nbsp said last year: &ldquoAt the end of the&nbspday money doesn&rsquot mean anything&nbspto dad. He&rsquod rather keep onfarming and keep the farm for the community.&ldquoTo lose it would be devastating, hugely to ourselves but also to the&nbspcommunity &ndash and for something that could be built elsewhere.

title: UK weather forecast Met Office update England Scotland Wales BBC Weather
story: A new weather front will sweep into the UK causing temperatures to plummet to 3C for some on Thursday as rain and gale force winds will batter north England and north Wales.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern warned the extremely cold front will sink in on Thursday and will slow down by the end of today hitting parts of the country with up to an inch of rain throughout the day and Friday.And temperatures could fall to 3C in Scotland overnight in stark contrast to the 19C still warming up southern areas of the country.Mr McGivern said: &ldquoMild ahead of the rain but fresher conditions behind it because it&rsquos tidying with that cold front.                UK weather forecast: Heavy rain and strong winds to BATTER north                BBC weather forecast UK: INCH of rain to fall this week before STORM&ldquoThat cold front sinks south through Thursday evening and slows down upon reaching northern England and north Wales.&ldquoSo we keep this clear distinction in the weather as we go through Thursday night.&ldquoClearer but fresher air into Scotland and Northern Ireland.&ldquoWinds picking up a touch of gale force there across the far north-west.&ldquoFrequent showers as well for north-western coasts.UK weather forecast: Met Office warns Britain to be hit by cold front on Thursday  (Image: MET OFFICE)UK weather: Temperatures in Britain could reach levels as low as 3C on Thursday (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquoFurther south much milder and generally cloudier with some misty low cloud in places.&ldquoSome dampness as well, especially for northern England and north Wales as we begin Friday.&ldquoAnd this is where the cold front slows down so we can expect the cloud and the rain to continue to come and go across north Wales and northern England for our Friday.&ldquoSome sunshine to the south of that across central and southern England as well as South Wales and warm, between 19C and 20C.&ldquoBut we keep those cool blustery winds for the far north and north-west along with frequent showers.On Friday, the outbreaks of rain will continue across northern England and Wales, with some heavy at times.Then, over the weekend persistent rain will batter central, southern and eastern areas of the UK, where a few places could see more than an inch of rain.But northern and western areas are going to be largely dry and bright, whereas it could feel quite cold in eastern areas where the rain resides.With Storm Leslie expected to strike the UK in a fortnight bookmaker Coral have slashed odds on October being the wettest on record.The firm now makes it a 4-1 chance from 8-1 Britain braces itself for a tropical storm this month.

story: The map using the latest weather charts shows Hurricane Leslie swirling across the Atlantic Ocean where it remains a yellow-coloured storm before morphing into a vengeful blackish-red blotch as it sweeps in on Ireland and the rest of the UK.The map was posted by a Twitter account called Severe-Weather.EU with the caption: &ldquo850mb temp anomaly across the Atlantic where hurricane #Leslie is on the way towards Azores and western Europe next week.&ldquoNotice how significant Arctic outbreak pushes behind Leslie while it remains a warm-core cyclone far north passing west of Ireland late next week.The illustration triggered a flurry of replies by followers of the page.Leslie&rsquos monster path of destruction has been detailed on a terrifying colour-coded temperature map (Image: WX Charts )Hurricane Leslie: Peak wind gusts head towards Europe and the UK (Image: WX Charts)One said: &ldquoI sense that my flight on Saturday may be somewhat turbulent.Another added: &ldquoWow!, that's some anomaly! Weather churning chaos... Jet streams haywire.Despite the storm not being scheduled to hit the UK until early next week, the approach of Leslie will bring torrential rain the UK this weekend, with more than an inch expected to fall over Saturday and Sunday.Strong winds and murky conditions dominate the forecast, with patches of mist and fog to cloud parts of the UK like a blanket.                BBC weather forecast UK: INCH of rain to fall this week before STORM                UK weather latest: Hurricane Leslie heads toward UK - When will it hitAs Leslie creeps closer toward Britain it will also cause a temperature ide between the north and south.Fog and mist along the south coast are expected to bring in milder temperatures compared to the north, where residents will feel a chill in the low teens.With Storm Leslie expected to strike the UK in fortnight bookmaker Coral have slashed odds on October being the wettest on record.The National Hurricane Centre (NHC) have been monitoring storm Leslie as it meanders in the Atlantic Ocean.                UK weather forecast: Could October be wettest on RECORD?                Hurricane Leslie watch: Will Storm Leslie batter UK with high winds?Today, the storm has grown in strength - and is now classified as a hurricane.The hurricane is approximately 510 miles east-southeast of Bermuda and has maximum sustained wind speeds of 80mph.Should it reach the UK, Leslie will have weakened significantly - but could still bring strong winds and downpours.Met Office chief meteorologist Andy Page said earlier today: &ldquoLeslie will likely strengthen to a hurricane as it moves over warmer waters with large swells affecting Bermuda and east coast of the United States and the Caribbean.The map using the latest weather charts shows Hurricane Leslie swirling across the Atlantic (Image: WX Charts)&ldquoIt is likely to gradually weaken after this and move eastwards across the North Atlantic&ldquoSome models suggest Leslie will track south of the UK while others suggest it may move close to the UK by the end of next week.

title: UK weather forecast Hurricane Leslie map path latest NOAA Met Office BBC Weather
story: The tropical storm was upgraded to an Atlantic hurricane on Wednesday&nbsppacking 80mph winds at its centre.According to the National&nbspHurricane&nbspCenter (NHC)&nbspLeslie &ldquois beginning to turn northward while holding steady in strength.Forecasters have said it is too early to predict what impact the category one hurricane will have on the UK, but the country should be braced for rain and wind.Leslie could bring wind speeds of up to 75mph to parts of the UK and current forecast models show the storm heading towards the north-west of the UK.                Hurricane Leslie MAP: UK 'at risk' as Leslie turns into a HURRICANE                Hurricane Leslie, Sergio and Walaka put US UK and Hawaii on ALERTThe storm is meandering in the central North Atlantic and large swells are affecting Bermuda, but it is likely to gradually weaken and move eastwards across the Atlantic.However, it is likely to bring a spell of strong wind and rain to parts of the country.Met Office chief forecaster Andy Page said: &ldquoIt is too early to tell the exact impact on the UK but it will most likely bring a spell of strong winds and rain - the type of weather associated with low-pressure systems at this time of year.Tracking information shows Hurricane Leslie moving eastwards across the Atlantic towards Britain and then to the northwest of the UK, so the storm could bring a north-south split in the weather.UK weather: Hurricane Leslie could reach the UK with gale force winds next week (Image: EARTH NULL SCHOOL)Wet and windy conditions could hit in the north-west and dry and warm weather in the south and east.The hurricane-force winds are already extending 45 miles from the centre of the huge storm and weaker tropical-storm-force winds extend as far as 205 miles from the centre, but it will not be felt in the UK until next week after Leslie has moved up towards America.Mr Page added: &ldquoTropical Storm Leslie is currently in the central North Atlantic and is expected to remain there over the next few days.&ldquoLeslie will likely strengthen to a hurricane as it moves over warmer waters on Tuesday and Wednesday, with large swells affecting Bermuda and east coast of US and Caribbean.&ldquoIt is likely to gradually weaken after this and to move eastwards across the&nbspNorth&nbspAtlantic.&ldquoSome models suggest Leslie will track south of the UK while others suggest it may move&nbspcloser&nbspto the UK by the end of next week.Due to the changing weather system in the Atlantic, the Met Office said it cannot predict how much rain and wind will hit the UK just yet.The Met Office website&rsquos latest forecast reads: &ldquoSaturday: wet and breezy in England and Wales, showery in northwest.Sunday: dry initially, rain in the north later.

title: EU news Emmanuel Macron France latest update Brussels European election 2019
story: Speaking to Euronews, Mr Poulin argued Emmanuel Macron's promising vision for the future of the European Union as announced one year ago at a speech at the University of La Sorbonne has been dismantled throughout the year by crashing position of Angela Merkel in Germany and the French President's unsuccessful relationship with members of his cabinet.Mr Poulin claimed that despite Mr Macron's position continues to be stronger than the German Chancellor's, it would be very difficult for him to be seen as a strong figure ahead of the European Parliament elections in May 2019.The EU analyst said: &ldquoI think it&rsquos very difficult for him to be seen now as a strong figure for this campaign of the European elections.&ldquoRemember when he did a speech one year ago at La Sorbonne, there was this plan about France and Germany hands in hands having a new plan for Europe.                 French interior minister resigns TWICE in less than 24 hours                Macron&rsquos approval ratings plummet to 30 percent as revelations emerge&ldquoWhat happened during the last year is that Angela Merkel has got a lot of issues struggling for power with the CDU Party.&ldquoAnd while Emmanuel Macron seems to be on a more positive strike, now it&rsquos clear that he&rsquos got a lot of internal problems with trying to find people to support his policy and prominent figures to support his policy.&ldquoWe&rsquoll see how he can just bounce and return to be the strong man for Europe again, but a lot of questions are still in the air.Mr Poulin's comments come as the French President was hit by the resignation of his Interior Minister&nbspG&eacuterard Collomb on Tuesday.EU news: Analyst Alexis Poulin claims Emmanuel Macron no longer holds a 'strong' position in Europe (Image: &bullEURONEWS)The former interior minister said he wanted to resign so he could run as mayor of the city of Lyon in spring 2020.When asked whether he would stay on as interior minister after Mr Macron turned down his resignation on Monday, Mr Collomb said: &ldquoThe French people and the people of Lyon need clarity, so I maintain my offer to resign.&ldquoConsidering the rumours and the pressure, I don&rsquot want the fact I will be a candidate somewhere tomorrow to affect the way forward for the interior ministry.Later on Tuesday, the Elys&eacutee Palace said Mr Macron had agreed to let Mr Collomb go and that Prime Minister Edouard Philippe would fill the key cabinet post until a new replacement is found.Mr Collomb is the third minister to step down in two months in a major blow to Emmanuel Macron, whose administration has been marred with setbacks.Mr Macron said it was &ldquoregrettable that Mr Collomb had been pressured into resigning, according to his entourage.The former interior minister's refusal to abide by Mr Macron&rsquos orders were seen by critics as a bold challenge to the President&rsquos authority, coming just weeks after the 40-year-old leader was forced to replace his popular ecology minister and the sports minister.Mr Collomb announced plans to quit the government two weeks ago, saying he would resign after the European elections in May 2019 in order to cause as little disruption as possible.However, opposition rivals said his looming departure undermined his legitimacy as the head of one of the most sensitive jobs in France.

title: poachers lions mufasa Akwaaba south africa black magic
story: The lions were killed in Akwaaba Predator Park in South Africa  (Image: Akwaaba Predator Park)The lion was killed along with four others on Monday, October 1 at Akwaaba Predator Park, which is 80 miles west of Johannesburg.The poachers broke into the park and poisoned the lions before hacking off the front paws of one and part of the face of another.Upsetting images show Mufasa&rsquos mutilated body with other dead animals close by.Park manager, Bronwyn Moss, said: &ldquoIt&rsquos heartbreaking.                Poachers use deadly glue traps to trap Britain&rsquos best loved birds                Soldiers&rsquo pride in saving wildlife from poachers&ldquoAll the lions were land reared from when they were cubs so it&rsquos like losing five children.&ldquoThey were close to our hearts. My only hope is that the lions were already dead by the time the poachers started chopping off parts.A security guard made the discovery when he found a lot of blood in one enclosure and a lion&rsquos two feet and face had been chopped off.The Akwaaba Predator Park is offering a reward of 100,000 rand, which is &pound5,550, to anyone with information leading to the arrest of the poachers.The poachers fled when staff arrived to the shocking scene  (Image: Akwaaba Predator Park)The poachers fled the scene after staff disturbed them.Ms Moss said: &ldquoWe suspect that the lions were all poisoned at the same time and that the poachers were disturbed by the security guards before they could hack parts off the other lions.&ldquoWe are devastated that this could happen on our doorstep and that our babies were killed for nothing. The poachers murdered five and only got parts from one. What an absolute waste of life.&ldquoThe poachers could have been after the parts to make traditional medicine or they could have been harvesting them for a trophy collector. We hope to get to the bottom of it soon.Staff at the park have been left devastated by the killings  (Image: Akwaaba Predator Park)The Lion King film follows Simba, a lion cub who is the son and heir of Mufasa.In a post on Facebook, staff at the park said: &ldquoTragedy struck last night at our park. We lost five lions to murderers.That is what they are, they killed our babies. Our hearts are broken.Five lions were killed by the poachers  (Image: Akwaaba Predator Park )We are down but not out.As you may have seen, we are offering a cash reward for any information that leads to the successful capture and conviction of these murderers.&ldquoPlease help us, let's stand together and find these monsters.

story: 'I only talk to SOBER people!'
