title: kim jong un north korea odds nobel peace prize 2018 latest
story: Kim Jong-un and Moon Jae-in are odds-on favourites to share the 2018 Nobel Peace Prize (Image: )The North Korean leader and Moon are the odds-on favourites at 4-6 to share the prize, after Coral was flooded with bets on the Korean leaders.US President Donald Trump is the second favourite at 5-2 to become the first American president since Barack Obama in 2009 to win the award, while Raif Badawi is the lowest priced non-politician in the betting at 16-1.Coral&rsquos Jim Hill said: The betting suggests Kim Jong-un and Moon Jae-in are on course to share the 2018 Noble Peace Prize as they are odds-on on the back of their efforts in trying to secure peace between the two Korean countries.Despite some negative publicity this week, Donald Trump is second best in the betting and is still attracting strong support.                North Korea has 'SECRET stash' of nuclear weapons - Seoul warningAt the start of the year, the US president was a huge price to win this award but his odds have shortened with every month.The Nobel Peace Prize 2018 will be awarded on Friday October 5.The odds come as US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he was optimistic his planned visit to Pyongyang this weekend would bring progress toward a second summit between Mr Trump and North Korean leader Kimand in building a path to North Korea's denuclearisation.Mr Pompeo said: I'm very happy to be going back to get another chance to continue to advance the commitment that Chairman Kim and President Trump made back in Singapore in the second week of June.Donald Trump is the second favourite at 5-2 to win the Nobel Peace Prize (Image: AFP )I'm optimistic that we'll come away from that with better understandings, deeper progress and a plan forward, not only for the summit between the two leaders but for us to continue the efforts to build out a pathway for denuclearisation.The North Korean dictator pledged to work towards scrapping his regime&rsquos nuclear arsenal in June but his actions have fallen short of the US President&rsquos demands for a complete inventory of Pyongyang&rsquos nuclear weapons.Mr Trump appears keen to hold a second summit with Kim despite the lack of action.North Korea Foreign Minister Ri Yong Ho told the United Nations last week that continued sanctions were deepening the North's mistrust of the US and there was no way Pyongyang would give up its nuclear weapons unilaterally under such circumstances.

title: theresa may brave brexit vote
story: In the largest vote ever recorded in Britain, we chose to leave the Brussels racket.And as she reveals in our exclusive interview, Theresa May is determined to tell the world that we are getting out, no s, no buts.Tory Conference this week will be testy. There remain serious splits in the party over Brexit but on one thing they must be united: nothing can imperil our exit.But while the PM is right that a second referendum is for the birds, the country is constantly holding a referendum on her leadership.On domestic issues it is Labour that seems to have an answer to everything — eventhose easy solutions rely on made-up money and would be disastrous in practice.Governments cannot just promise the world in airy-fairy speeches but, faced with an Opposition full of empty promises, the Tories must be radical.They cannot just deliver watered-down versions of whatever Jeremy Corbyn has cooked up.There are plenty of brains in the Tory party. Let’s hear their ideas and a real vision of what Britain can be.IT is disgraceful that major food stores are exploiting a legal loophole to avoid showing ingredients on packaging.Teenager Natasha Ednan-Laperouse’s death should serve as a warning of how dangerous this practice is.The law states that when food is prepared onsite, ingredients labelling is not necessary. It is designed to protect small, independent stores.But our investigation today reveals large chains have not learnt from this avoidable tragedy.Pret a Manger was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame seed in its artisan baguettes and yet it continues to sell items without allergy warnings.Now Natasha’s mother Tanya has challenged the chain to lobby for a change in our labelling laws.And, hopefully, stop other parents having to suffer such a terrible loss.BON appétit, M’luds. You’re scoffing and quaffing grub and booze to the tune of £, A DAY and WE’RE footing the bill.The House of Lords, which is filled with political cronies and gloried lobbyists,represents the very worst of Whitehall’s snouts-in-the-trough culture.The sooner we have an elected House with a few handpicked specialists, the better.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond brexit speech trevor kavanagh opinion
story: He is also writing his ­Halloween Budget on October . Nobody is hoping for voter-friendly treats.For a man in charge of our economic destiny at such a momentous time, this “stubby-pencilled accountant” has precious little to say. It seems he even remained mute at a recent Cabinet session to war-game a No-Deal Brexit — surely the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s special subject.Well-informed Spectator editor Fraser Nelson says other ministers piled in with upbeat projects but Hammond “seemed to have no ideas and kept quiet”. Spreadsheet Phil possesses either supreme self-confidence or total contempt for the .million who voted for Brexit, or both.The man who a year ago faced political death has become the most powerful figure in Theresa May’s Cabinet — perhaps including herself.She remains the figurehead. But the minister she planned to axe until her botched General Election is running the Brexit show from his Treasury eyrie.Hammond’s sympathetic image as Eeyore, a woebegone soft toy, is misleading. This man combines thin-skinned arrogance with a rare combination of political disabilities — cloth-eared, ham-fisted and leaden-footed.The grey image of bungled Budgets and barren creativity stands in vivid contrast to his outrageous Project Fear scaremongering. Mrs May certainly deserves blame for her hapless EU negotiations and the mutant Chequers plan for a Hi-HoBrexit.THE Tories have made a decent start to their conference – but they need to set their ambitions higher.Last week the Labour Party promised easy answers on everything from housing to the economy. It was a radical,utterly disastrous, vision for Britain.The Government changing tipping rules and increasing taxes on foreign property buyers is pretty small beer.Not least since the former was first announced three years ago and the latter is pretty much copied from last year’s Labour manesto.Philip Hammond — rarely mistaken for a ray of sunshine — needs to provide light at the end of the austerity tunnel.He must lay the groundwork for entrepreneurs to thrive in a newly liberated, unapologetically free market economy.And he should challenge business to work with him, too. The self-appointed “voices of British business”, iniably dominated by large corporate interests, push every day for more and more Brexit concessions.Yet as last week showed, Labour’s unreconstructed Marxism is a far more serious threat to future prosperity than any kind of Brexit.It’s time for big businesses to play their part in building a better Britain, rather than refighting a referendum which was as much a vote against them as the political establishment.Eeyore Hammond must encourage them to invest in Britain’s future.She survived last year’s election catastrophe only because Remainers feared a true Brexiteer such as Boris Johnson might replace her.Hammond has since deployed his Treasury reach to capitalise on her weakness and box us into BRINO — Brexit In Name Only. Mrs May is the willing captive of passionate Remainers in Downing Street, Whitehall, the Cabinet Office and, crucially, the all-powerful Treasury.Since the departure of close aide Nick Timothy, there is nobody within earshot who voted Brexit — including Mrs May. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, like his predecessor David Davis, has virtually no say in negotiations.Hammond now calls the shots, backed by panic-stirring Business Secretary Greg Clark and Europhile Cabinet Office minister David Lidington.Brexiteers fear this Unholy Trinity is ready for more concessions over issues including migration, EU benefits and Britain’s vital financial services industry.Never forget, it was Hammond who blocked all spending and therefore all serious preparation for No Deal, a prospect now apparently facing this nation. In fact there was never a chance of No Deal.We will end up with a form of Chequers, but one even more pro-Brussels than the proposal which saw David Davis and BoJo storm out. Remainers are back in full Project Fear mode.European car firms are happily pouring billions into Britain — despite Brexit. Yet Greg Clark triggered last week’s chorus of fake alarm from Toyota, claiming its “just-in-time” supply chain would grind to a halt.This ignores the whole point of “just-in-time”. It is designed specically to cope with delivery glitches and operates worldwide in all circumstances under global trade rules.It was also Clark who handed Brussels its biggest anti-Brexit card by promising those shroud-waving car giants the UK would remain under EU rules. That led directly to Mrs May’s surrender over the Northern Ireland border, which has plagued negotiations ever since.It is a tragic fact — but no surprise — that we are now heading remorselessly for a deal on EU terms at our expense.EU leaders were never going to see us thrive outside. They insisted we will not be better off after Brexit.Anyone who hoped we might be set free to compete on equal terms should read ex-Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis’ story of his own country’s punishment beating.It was Varoufakis who compared Brexit with the Eagles’ hit: “It’s like Hotel Calornia — you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.” And we can blame Phil Hammond for blocking the fire Brexits.But Ms Jourova, a Czech raised under Soviet rule, wants Corbyn-style “regulation” of the free Press.The apple never falls far from the tree.PS. I wonder how M Macron feels after Europe’s Ryder Cup triumph in Paris... without a single French golfer And SIX from the UK!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: budget must put money in pockets
story: For all the wise words in his conference speech — on the opportunities of new technology, the horric dangers of Corbyn’s socialism and the importance of job-creating businesses — he needs answers to more immediate questions.The signs are ominous. The Chancellor, while admitting “st Century capitalism must deliver” for ordinary people, apparently intends to take MORE of our money for the NHS in his upcoming Budget.Polls apparently show voters are OK with that. But wait till it comes out of wage packets. Skint workers won’t thank the Tories for bailing out the health ­service. They’ll desert them for grabbing yet more of their take-home pay.Mr Hammond’s speech wasn’t all bad. His case against socialism was well put. Likewise his view that no sane party should try to outbid Corbyn’s ruinous spending pledges. We welcome his proposed digital services tax on Google and Facebookit can be made to work. ut Tory fortunes hinge on Brexit — and pay rises easily outstripping inflation.The Budget MUST put more money in pockets . . . not remove it with a tax raid or a suicidal rise in fuel duty.THE EU’s cry-bullies are OUTRAGED that Jeremy Hunt compared their aggression to the old Soviet Union. Well, diddums.He noted, quite reasonably, that Brussels’ forcible attempts to lock Britain in and deter others from leaving was ­reminiscent of the Soviet empire’s treatment of its member states.It is a figure of speech. The Foreign Secretary’s not literally comparing Juncker to Stalin’s regime of mass murder. And the EU has no defence. Which is why its lackeys, such as curtain-haired clown Guy Verhofstadt, instead wilfully misinterpreted him for dramatic effect.One even whined it could “damage relations” with other member states. Are they for real  The French president brands Brexit campaigners “liars” — implying .million Brits are dupes. Donald Tusk humiliates our PM. But WE’RE in danger of souring relations.Give it a rest, EU fools.HOW appalling that the sisters of terror victim cop Keith Palmer have no Legal Aid to pursue the truth at his inquest.Michelle Palmer and Angela Clark want to hire an independent expert to assess whether a permanent armed presence at Parliament’s Carriage Gates entrance might have saved their brother.But the Legal Aid Agency hasn’t processed their application. Meanwhile the women claim the Met is actively hostile.Why are the Government and police making enemies of Keith’s family Justice Secretary David Gauke should grant them legal aid today.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: toddler tied cage bed ellie may minshull coyle snapchat
story: Ellie-May Minshull-Coyle was just -months-old when she died bound to her bed with tight ligatures across her chest and legs, a jury at Liverpool Crown Court was told.Mother Lauren Coyle, , her boyfriend, Reece Hitchcott, , and their lodger, Connor Kirby, , all deny manslaughter after the tot died on March  last year.The court heard the night before Ellie-May was pronounced dead, Coyle sent a Snapchat message to a friend saying: This child is p*****g me oftonight.It was alleged the little girls ankles had been tied together and her sleeping position stopped her breathing properly, which ultimately caused her death.Coyle previously told police that Hitchcott began to bind her daughter to the bed to help her settle in a sleep routine - though she did not approve.Then at am the next morning Coyle allegedly messaged her father, Sean Coyle, to say her daughter had been crying in the  night but she had left her to cry for two hours.She added: Shes taking the Mick now.When Mr Coyle arrived at the flat at am, he went to the toddlers bedroom and realised there was a terrible problem.The court also heard the tots bed had been pushed against a wall and enclosed on the sides with slats from a cot lashed together with electric flex from a lamp.Sheets and bedding were also placed over the sides of the monstrous cage to prevent her seeing out into her room, which had no light in.Marks were found on the victims wrists and ankles, suggesting she had been tied down at the house on Ward Street in Preston.Ellie-May was not breathing and an ambulance was called but she was pronounced dead soon after at Royal Preston Hospital.Prosecutor Christopher Tehrani QC told the court: The prosecutions case is that Ellie-Mays death was unnecessary, pointless and wholly avoidable.A post-mortem examination concluded the childs death was caused by forcible restraint by ligatures in a face-down position complicated by hyperthermia.The pathologist also concluded that she had been tied to the bed on more than one occasion.All of the defendants deny manslaughter and allowing the death of the child, one count of child cruelty by caging the child in her bed, and another count of child cruelty by restraining her in the bed.The trial continues.

title: theresa may push lock brexit deal
story: The PM will start phoning leaders across Europe’s capitals this morning in a bid to close gaping gaps.Now that the high risk moment of the Tories’ annual conference in Birmingham is over, senior government figures say she is freer to make more potentially controversial compromises.Despite Mrs May’s demand for Brussels to end the new impasse after the Salzburg summit disaster, The Sun can also reveal that secret talks have already reopened.The PM’s chief negotiator Olly Robbins has been in Brussels this week to try to hammer out a backstop plan to ensure no Irish border.One Cabinet minister involved in the process told The Sun: “We need some very fancy footwork to get the Withdrawal Agreement wrapped up by the October council.“But deadlines always concentrate minds.The PM will be hitting the phone hard and we think it’s just about doable.”The EU announced last night that its  leaders will meet to discuss Brexit over dinner on October , the night before the next summit starts.But Britain has been told that the pieces for a orce deal must be in place by the start of that week for national capitals to then consider them.The UK’s new proposal involves “spreading the pain” over where Ireland’s future customs and regulatory borders lie three ways, between the EU, the UK and Ireland.The EU’s plan for a border down the Irish Sea has been firmly rejected by Mrs May.And her bid to collect the EU’s tarfs and keep Britain within a close customs arrangement has been ruled out by Brussels, along with any infrastructure on the Irish border.No wants to agree the full orce deal at the summit on October -, but hold back from writing it into legal text.A further intensive four week negotiation will then take place before another Brexit summit in November to agree the future framework for a UK-EU trade deal, before both are then signed at the same time.Of all the  EU leaders, French president Emmanuel is still seen as the hardest and most important nut to crack, as German boss Angela Merkel is still too distracted by her unstable coalition government in Berlin.Irish PM Leo Varadkar will touch down in Brussels today for talks with chief negotiator Michel Barnier and EU Council president Donald Tusk.EU diplomats are also increasingly hopeful of achieving a major breakthrough on the thorny border issue within two weeks.One EU diplomat told The Sun: Perhaps its one of the elements where we can move.Im more optimistic than I have been for months that a deal is possible. But they cautioned against overinflated expectations, adding: Dont be too hopeful of having white smoke.October is important but its about trying to get some feel good back into the talks and seeing whether there is indeed land in sight.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is then expected to go to the Belgian capital next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: conservative party brexit unity rod liddle opinion
story: I don’t think Theresa May is going to be on Strictly any time soon. Whoever convinced her it would be dead cool to walk on stage at the party conference and jig about to an Abba song needs a bit of invasive brain surgery, right now.It was like a remake of Re-Animator, or Night Of The Living Dead.There’s no point in Theresa trying to tell us she’s the le and soul of the party and actually a bloody good laugh.We know she isn’t. She’s about as charismatic as an underdone crumpet on a wet Sunday. But she doesn’t need to be Ginger Rogers. She’s the Prime Minister.And you have to give her credit for doggedly sticking to that role. EvenI’m not convinced she’s been doing it terribly well.But on Brexit — God, how mind-numbingly boring the whole thing is — she has a good point.I’m not a fan of her Chequers deal for us to leave the European Union. I think we’re giving too much away. I’d rather have a no-deal exit.But time is pressing. And I’m aware that while we Leavers won the referendum, the margin was comparatively small. So we ought to be gracious and accept a little bit of a compromise. Try to strike a respectable deal with those gangsters from insignicant countries.And a little further down the line, tweak the arrangements a little to suit us better. In the meantime, just strike the deal.And that means getting behind May and presenting a united front to Europe. Most of the Conservative MPs understand that, even the arch-Brexiteers like the excellent Michael Gove.But Bfo the Blundering Bear does not. I’m talking about Boris Johnson. Now he IS fun and good company. But he’s about as likely to become Prime Minister as I am to cop off with Emily Ratajkowski after a few pints and a quick meal at the Chicken Cottage.He has very little support among his political colleagues. He has a lot more among Conservative activists. But very little among voters north of Watford.And yet Bfo was at it again this week. Taking the p**s out of the Prime Minister. And making a rousing speech to his hardcore supporters. Demanding we tell the EU to stuff it.Well, there was a time when we should have told the EU to stuff it — two years ago when we first started negotiations.That time has passed. A lack of confidence from the Government and a ided party let us down.Now is the time to show a bit of unity and wring a deal out of the deathly bureaucrats. Maybe not the Chequers deal — May didn’t mention the word at all during her speech — but a version of it.Otherwise we’ll have a General Election on our hands. One the Tories will lose. And you’ll wake up to find John McDonnell is in charge of your finances and Diane Abbott is Home Secretary.Come on — surely that should concentrate the mind a little Hero of the week is Jane Lunnon, head of a girls’ school in South London.She has stuck the boot into “image-obsessed” reality TV – especially that coven of gurning and pouting imbeciles in Love Island, such as Megan Barton Hanson.Such programmes are “incredibly damaging” to young people, she reckons, calling them “trivial nonsense”.I think Jane is right. And the same goes for all those hyped-up talent shows where people with no talent – just a lust for fame – get judged on their appalling performances by people with no talent.Kids need to know the dference between fame for fame’s sake – and real achievement.Its horrible that Corine Remande has lost the sight in one eye after she was hit by a golf ball during the Ryder Cup.The poor woman was standing among spectators when Brooks Koepka’s tee shot hit her in the face.She’s now threatening legal action against the organisers. She says they didn’t give spectators enough protection.This is ludicrous. What were they supposed to do And what will happen is that in future crowds will be kept even further back from the action. Just because of one horrible accident.Wait until the same thing happens in cricket...The uni magazine said: “It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression.”With anxiety or sensory issues  What is wrong with these people They are “triggered” by almost everything. Especially by people who have views which dfer from their own.That REALLY triggers them. They shouldn’t be at university. They should be safe at home with mummy and daddy.That old windbag Mahathir Mohamad has been visiting the UK.Lovely to have him, of course. He’s the boss of Muslim-dominated Malaysia and he hates Jews.He was at it again over here. Said they all had “hook noses”.And that they were the cause of all the trouble in the Middle East.He’s allowed his view, of course, evenit is one based on hatred and the ideology of his own interpretation of his religion.But how would it beI said Muslims are the cause of most of the trouble in the world I’d be up before the Old Bill for a hate crime before you could say Islamic State.This is because Asian countries are getting more and more wealthy.I suppose this is a good thing. Problem is, I can’t stand them, the middle class.And the thought of nearly four billion people eating avocado on toast while doing Pilates then listening to Coldplay in their Volvo XCs makes me feel terribly queasy.The human race is being taken over by the legions of the smug. Get me outta here.Visitors to the Telford Exotic Zoo were disappointed by the penguins. They just stood, stock still.This is because they are plastic model penguins. The zoo had been unable to get the real thing.And here’s a tip for the zoo owners. Don’t buy any real penguins, stick to the models.I think plastic penguins would be far better suited to an enclosure of a dozen square yards of shingle with a tiny drainage ditch to bathe in.Why are we allowing zoos like this to open  If I were a real penguin in Telford Exotic Zoo I’d sue them. Or beat them about the head with a flipper.Have you seen Vladimir Putin’s new calendar There he is, standing naked in water, muscles rippling, looking stern.Another one has him cuddling a baby leopard.I hate to say this but isn’t it all a bit... um... camp And now for saying this I’ll probably end up resembling one of the glow sticks the kids buy at funfairs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm austerity over build houses
story: The PM used her annual conference speech as a giant job interview for her to remain as the nation’s leader after Brexit.Theresa May dances on stage and then claims austerity is overWith plots to oust her after March  mounting following a major revolt over her soft Brexit plan, Mrs May charmed the hall with a flurry of gags — and even danced her way on stage to her favourite Abba song, Dancing Queen.Her speech was seen as a clear plea for more time as she told the audience: “Our future is in our hands.“We stand at a pivotal moment in our history. It falls to our party to lead our country through it.”Top of Mrs May’s list of fresh ­policy offers was a major move to get thousands more frustrated families on the housing ladder.She announced the Government is to scrap a long-standing cap on how much councils can borrow against their current housing stock to build more homes.There are .million households on the waiting list, but only , homes were made available in .Explaining the change in thinking, Mrs May said: “We cannot make the case for capitalismordinary working people have no chance of owning capital.Solving the housing crisis is the biggest domestic policy challenge of our generation.“It doesn’t make sense to stop councils from playing their part in solving it.”The state will also spend more from next year while still keeping the nation’s finances under control, the PM pledged.In answer to pleas for more cash to ease the pressure on Britain’s crowded schools, stretched hospitals and creaking defences, she promised that “support for public services will go up”.Mrs May added: “Because you made sacrices, there are better days ahead.“A decade after the financial crash, people need to know that the austerity it led to is over and that their hard work has paid off.”Issuing her final plea for unity, the PM ended her address with the declaration: “When we come together, there is no limit to what we can achieve.”Her speech brought a long standing ovation from the audience in Birmingham — appearing to have won over sceptical Tory activists for now.Only minutes before Mrs May began her address yesterday lunchtime, one angry Brexiteer MP issued a withering demand that she resign.Ex-minister James Duddridge wrote to the backbench Tory  Committee to call for a no confidence vote in the PM.Branding her incapable of leadership, he said: “Blind loyalty is not the right way forward.”And hours later, Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom refused to back Mrs May to lead the Tories into the next general election.She told ITV’s Peston show: “I just think politics is a short-term game. A week changes a lot.”But loyalist Cabinet ministers were delighted with her performance.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab hailed it a “speech laden with leadership”.Torbjörn Sohlström — ambassador for Abba’s homeland of Sweden — was among those to see Mrs May’s attention-grabbing entry to the hall. He tweeted: “I can only say ‘bravo’.”The PM’s robotic dancing became a worldwide phenomenon in August when TV images of her trying to join in with children in Africa went viral.However, councils and campaigners were more impressed with the scrapping of the borrowing cap and the fresh trust ministers were placing on local authorities.Homeless charity Shelter’s boss Polly Neate called it “a major reform that shows real intent to back social house-building”.. Theresa May has a good sense of humour. She stunned Tories by entering the stage dancing to Abba’s Dancing Queen and making gags at her own expense, including a risque nod to steamy BBC drama Bodyguard.. She really cant stand Boris. The PM couldn’t even bring herself to use his name when she swiped out at him over reports he said “f*** business” in response to their Brexit concerns.. Her Chequers Brexit proposal is so toxic she couldnt say the word once in her -minute speech. She also name-checked the NHS more than Brexit -  times to .. She made it clear who wears trousers between her and Downing Street neighbour Philip Hammond, pinching his two big Budget announcements on fuel duty and a house building splurge, plus beating the Chancellor to it to declare an end to austerity.. Mrs May has no intention of standing down soon despite the Cabinet jockeying for her job by trying to renew her domestic vision so it lasts long after Brexit. But Lib Dem Sir Vince Cable, who appeared on a Strictly special in , said: “As somebody who takes dancing seriously, I was delighted to see Theresa May show that she is developing her new hobby.“But she was dancing on the head of a pin, confronted by an audience full of people plotting to oust her.”Labour’s Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell dubbed her claim that austerity is over as “a con”.ligtGOT a story  Ring The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or email exclusive@the-sun.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rooting against cashless britain
story: But in just ten years’ time, kids will find the idea of a porcelain container for metal coins ridiculous — and will be doing their saving on a phone app with cute graphics.Face it, cash is dying out. It is dirty and unhygienic — a report out this week said it is a breeding ground for bugs.There is even a version of Monopoly with debit cards instead of notes. And last month we told you of the  century The Boot pub in Freston, Suffolk, the first boozer in the country to go cashless.This looming death has been around for a while. In August, the Bank of England said it was considering phasing out p and p coins. And ATMs are closing at a rate of  a month.Just  per cent of payments are cash, down from  per cent in . And those payments only account for three per cent in terms of the value of how much is spent.Paying on card has been on the rise ever since Barclaycard launched in , but cards too face being eclipsed by payments on mobile phones. Either way, both mean we need cash less. And that is not a bad thing, right Getting rid of cash would hit criminals and tax evaders hard as they do business in cash to make it harder for authorities to track the movement of money.Businesses would rejoice because they would not have to pay security guards to transport money and would not have to spend ages counting and bagging it.Some also reckon it is easier to keep a tab on finances when spending on cards or apps. You might forget buying that extra round at closing time in the pub, but your phone will always remember. And of course, you get consumer protection when using a credit card, along with reward points or cashback offers.Credit card firms make their money not just from interest payments but from taking a small fee for each transaction — so they offer us incentives to choose their cards. Use an Air Miles card and before long you could have a free flight to Paris or New York.More than a quarter of clothes in the UK are bought online — and you can’t use cash over the internet. As we move even more to buying online and via smartphone apps, cash will be needed less and less. Whether cash dies out in five years or  or  just depends on technology.But many are in no rush to see the back of it — and not just because of nostalgia for their old piggy banks. One consideration is: Can we entirely trust the banks to look after our money  Fraud is soaring as criminals take advantage of security issues around online banking. Banks blame customers but critics say banks need to take responsibility.We have featured victim after victim on The Sun Money columns, and they all say bank staff have turned their backs on them. There are millions of others who need cash simply because they rely on it to pay for things day to day. And it is the less well off or elderly who rely on it the most.Consumer magazine Which  — which has been campaigning against the loss of banks and ATMs — has produced research showing poorer families and older folk are hardest hit.Gareth Shaw of Which  said: “ATM and branch closures are threatening to leave behind the millions who still rely on cash. Our research highlights lower-income families and older generations will be among the worst hit.”In June, services from Visa, one of the three main card providers along with Mastercard and American Express, went down with technical issues — highlighting the risk of being solely reliable on cards and phones. “When the trolley came around on the train and the card payment wasn’t working, the only people who could eat were those with cash,” one banker explained.And what about hospitality workers  The Government has said all tips, evenon cards, must go to staff — but we all know some unscrupulous bosses will not do that. Like many, I prefer to give my tips in cash so I know the waiter or waitress gets it all.Charity collectors often have card machines now but collections for most churches, schools and small local good causes still rely on tins and the rattle of coins.Cash may well be dying out, but I still make sure I always keep some coins in my pocket just in case. And I have older relatives who still feel most comfortable with coins and notes.So until we have a population where everyone feels happy when using a card or phone, I will be rooting against a completely cashless Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools shut london false widow spiders
story: Two primary schools and two secondary schools have closed after Britains most venomous spider was found on site.The discovery of the spiders were made by Newhams Environmental Team in east London.Pest control teams are now working to bring the outbreak under control before any more eggs hatch.One of the schools affected, Rokeby secondary in Canning Town, will remain shut until October .Star Primary in Beckton, Ellen Wilkinson Primary in Canning Town and Lister Community School in Plaistow have also had to close until further notice.Rokeby head teacher, Charlotte Robinson, said a pest control company estimated it would take three weeks to clear the spiders.In a letter to parents of the school’s  pupils, she wrote: “I have had to take the dficult decision to close Rokeby School to students and staff until Monday, October .“We have engaged a company to deal with and eradicate this pest, they have estimated that this will take up to three weeks.“The safety and wellbeing of students and staff must be our priority so whilst I understand that this may be very inconvenient for you it is in your child’s best interest to remain at home and not at school.”Lister Community School head teacher Anthony Wilson said he hoped his school would re-open by Friday.He added: “Investigations suggest that there may be some of these spiders on our site, and we are therefore following advice from the local authority and will be closing the school as a precaution to allow full investigation.”Lisle Von Buchenroder, headteacher at Star Primary and Sue Ferguson, headteacher of Ellen Wilkinson said they were looking at alternative venues so lessons could continue.False widow spiders are about the size of a p coin and are the most dangerous spider species in the UK.Their bites can be very painful and leave small puncture marks on the skin.A Newham Council spokeswoman said: “The spiders only bitemishandled or provoked. The venom is not particularly potent.“The schools are being treated and fumigated and we are working with the schools to ensure that children can continue to receive an education whilst their school is closed.Pupils are being set work via the schools and will remain in contact with schools.“We are asking all our schools and nurseries to proactively check their premises carefully for these spiders andthey see any signs, then contact environmental health or pest control.”False widow spiders are distinctive for their shiny, black flesh, bulbous bodies, thick legs and skull-like patterns.Millions of  widows, Britains most venomous spider, have been found across the UK and the population is believed to be growing.The species has a brown bulbous abdomen with cream markings that look like a skull. They have long legs and can reach about mm in size.Also known as steatoda nobilis, the spider is frequently confused for the black widow, which has deadly venom.

title: moment 30000 litres of prosecco bursts from tank after an explosion at italian winery
story: Prosecco lovers around the world wished they could have raised a glass – or even a bucket – to help scoop up the bubbly waterfall.The pressurised tank exploded in Conegliano, Veneto, in the province of Treviso, with video footage of the wasted wine posted on Facebook by the Lenoteca Zanardo Giussano winery.But instead of being popping mad, the Prosecco producers simply confessed there was “too much must in the silos”.Must is freshly crushed wine juice that contains the skins, sees and stems of grapes, which is used for fermentation.Seeing the popular Italian sparkling wine cascading onto the floor was too much for some Prosecco fans, with one posting that people should “observe a minute of silence” while others described it as a “tragedy” and a “waste”.More than million people have watched video footage of the , litres of booze overflowing after Zanardo Guissano posted the dramatic event on its Facebook page.Among them was Shane McLeod Brennan, who said: “I would grab as many containers, bottles, bags, cups and the report would be ‘Shane died doing what he loved the most’ attempting to drink a , litre bottle of wine.”Upset Prosecco fan Marco Cerizzi said: “Noooooo. If they had called us we would have dried up the excess!”Giovanni Pianegonda pointed out: “Once it was said: rather than lose a drop, it is better to drink a puddle.”“We cry together for the serious loss!” wrote one grieving wine drinker, while another admitted: “I would have showered under that gorgeous waterfall.”There was also the more dramatic: “Dont want to live in this world anymore.”

title: theresa may dancing abba trolled guy verhofstadt
story: Brussels’ chief spokesman Margaritis Schinas was asked about the Prime Minister’s on-stage antics yesterday, when she walked out to “Dancing Queen”.He responded with the names of several other of the Swedish band’s songs – adding that “breaking up is never easy, I know”.It came after Mrs May was last night trolled by EU Parliament boss Guy Verhofstadt, who evidently missed the funny side of her light-hearted move at the Tory conference in Birmingham.On Twitter last night he sneered: While dancing to ABBA today, PM May overlooked the fact that Bjorn from ABBA called Brexit a disaster.He shared a link to the singer discussing why he wanted Britain to stay in the bloc, which was filmed before the referendum in  where most Brits opted to leave.But Winston Churchills grandson Nicholas Soames was quick to hit back with a tweet saying: #ohbuggeroff!Today Mr Schinas was asked by a reporter an Abba-themed question, whether he would: “Take a chance on May or is Britain facing its Waterloo ”And he replied in kind, saying: My my, how can I resist you. We appreciate a bit of dancing - it always takes two to tango.“We prefer that the tune was Dancing Queen rather than the Winner Takes It All. What can I say  Breaking up is never easy, I know.The PM’s moves did win some plaudits among the EU though, with Swedens ambassador saying last night: I can only say Bravo to Theresa May for starting her conference speech with ABBAs Dancing Queen.Mrs Mays dancing yesterday sent the internet wild with hilarious memes.Social media went into meltdown after she once again showed off her moves at the start of her speech this afternoon.The Tory leader went viral earlier this year after she danced with schoolchildren in South Africa - and didnt hesitate to show off her moves again as she took to the stage in Birmingham.Sharing a meme of Strictly judge Craig Revel Horwood, one joked: I can only assume that the reason Theresa May is dancing so much recently is so that she has a shot at getting on Strictly in  once she gets forced out.Mrs May also used her speech to announce a freeze to fuel duty for another year, a council house revolution by lting the cap on how much authorities can borrow - and revealed the pain of losing her goddaughter to cancer as she unveiled a new strategy to detect diseases earlier.

title: andrea leadsom refuses back theresa may brexit
story: Andrea Leadsom refused to back the PM staying in No after Brexit, and would only say politics is a short term game.Speaking after Mrs May impressed crowds at the Tory party conference in Birmingham yesterday, the leader of the Commons wouldnt say she should stay for the long term.She told ITVs Peston: Thats all for the future.I just think politics is a short term game. A week changes a lot.Although the PMs former leadership rival praised her make-or-break conference day as fantastic she wouldnt offer her full support.I think shes had a fantastic day today. Shes shown some enormous priorities around future cancer prevention through housing supply and absolutely her commitment to getting a good Brexit, she went on.And I think we should all be backing her.Stepping down was a matter for her, she added.Many Tories have privately said they want her to step down after Brexit happens next March.But the PM has not yet said she has any intention to quit her job, and has repeatedly said shes in it for the long term.Even Tories who are unhappy with her leadership admit theres not time to get rid of her and hold a leadership contest now - especially as the talks with the EU reach a crunch point in the coming weeks.Mrs May is back at work today, launching a -day push to lock down a orce deal ahead of the EU summit headline.She will be phoning leaders across Europe this morning to try and secure agreement.The PM’s chief negotiator Olly Robbins has been in Brussels this week to try to hammer out a backstop plan to ensure no Irish border.One Cabinet minister involved in the process told The Sun: “We need some very fancy footwork to get the Withdrawal Agreement wrapped up by the October council.The PM will be hitting the phone hard and we think it’s just about doable.”The EU announced last night that its  leaders will meet to discuss Brexit over dinner on October , the night before the next summit starts.A further intensive four week negotiation will then take place before another Brexit summit in November to agree the future framework for a UK-EU trade deal, before both are then signed at the same time.The Irish PM is in Brussels today for talks with EU bosses, as the Northern Irish border continues to be a sticking point in Brexit talks.Mrs Mays DUP allies wont accept anything that virtually breaks up Northern Ireland with the rest of the UK, but stubborn Brussels chiefs are still refusing to compromise over their hard-line demands.Just minutes before Mrs May gave her speech yesterday one of her critics said hed sent a letter of no confidence in her to the partys chairman.James Duddridge said he no longer wanted her to lead the Tories and failing to remove her as leader could lead to Jeremy Corbyn winning the next election.I write this with heavy heart, however we now need a proper leadership election and to move on, he said.It needs  letters for Mrs May to face a leadership challenge, but she will need at least  of her own MPs to vote to actually boot her out.   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: homeowner stunned to find 6ft snake lurking in her sewing room so can you spot it
story: The snake hid itself in amongst the clutter of the room, but can YOU spot the scaly visitor Snake Catchers Brisbane, Logan, Ipswich and Gold Coast were called out to the Sherwood property in Brisbane, Australia, yesterday.The Queensland base snake snaring service said on Facebook: “We got called out to a snake that had made itself quite comfortable here in a sewing room.”Snake catcher Jasmine Zeleny identied the scaly stowaway as a coastal carpet python measuring more than six foot in .She said: “They can reach as long as three metres .“Theyre a non-venomous species, and they do very well in an urban environment.”Jasmine added that it was one of the most commonly caught snakes in Brisbane and generally ate rats and possums.She suspects the python crept in the easy way adding: “Sometimes its as simple as leaving the door to the room open.”The snake catching group posted the photo of the snake to their Facebook page, and teased users to seethey could spot the reptile.Bemused users have piled in with their thoughts and comments on the stealthy serpent.One said: “That gives me the heebie jeebies.”Another took aim at the tidiness off the room joking: “This is not a sewing room. It is a storage area in need of help.”Tania Heather added: OMG how did he get up there Janice Thompson chimed in with: I thought under the basket The business describes itself as south east Queenslands oldest and most experienced professional snake catching business.

title: teen girl 18 didnt realise she was pregnant until she was giving birth in kitchen
story: Milaois ­Murphy, , was assured by her mum Victoria that her stomach pains were appendicitis, but then her waters broke in the middle of the night.While they waited for an ambulance to bring the teenager to hospital with the stomach pains, her little bundle of joy arrived — at just  weeks.Milaois, of Dublin, who now has five-month-old daughter Harper at home, told Irish broadcaster RTE how she was ­getting sick all that night, but had no idea she was pregnant.She said: “I had back pain and I couldn’t sleep at night, but that was my only symptom. I thought that I was getting a bit chubby.“The baby could have been kicking but I didn’t know because I never had a baby and I thought it could be wind or something. Then that night, I was vomiting and vomiting and I said, ‘Ma, I need to go to the hospital.’“We thought it was my appendix and we rang the Mater at about am.“Within seconds I felt pressure and my waters broke everywhere. My mum knew straight away and told me to relax and called my sister and the baby literally slid out into my trousers.“She was born on my kitchen floor.“I was brought to the Rotunda. I was so numb with the shock that it didn’t click with me until the next morning that I had a baby.“Then I went up and I saw her and the mother instinct immediately kicked in. I rang her fatherand we went up and picked her name.”Milaois reckons Victoria’s actions in resuscitating her girl were heroic.She explained: “Harper was born on the kitchen floor. When she came out, she let out a little cry and then she stopped breathing, so me ma had to resuscitate her.“The baby was only the same size as her hand. She was just a pound. If it wasn’t for her, she is a super mammy.“I think the ambulance men were telling her how to do it. The ambulance and fire brigade were amazing.”RTE’s series catalogues the long and dficult road for baby Harper who was in intensive care for months and is seen having laser eye surgery.Consultant neonatologist Adrienne Foran recalled how the infant’s arrival, at one pound and  ounces, was a huge shock to Milaois and James.She said: “Harper was smaller than a bag of sugar. She was about  ­minutes old when I met her, she’d come in with no heart rate but responded very well to initial resuscitation.”James told how he couldn’t wait to go in and hold Harper every day.He gushed: “It’s crazy how happy she can make you be. She is such a strong baby.”

title: clear simple pregnancy tests recalled wrong results
story: Some , faulty Clear and Simple digital pregnancy tests are being recalled after a number of the at-home testing kits provided  positive results.The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agencyhas issued a recall of the affected batches.Dr Duncan McPherson, clinical director of medical devices at the MHRA, said: It is important people check the lot number of any Clear  Simple Digital Pregnancy Tests they have purchased to seethey have a product from an affected lot.If you have any questions about using digital pregnancy tests, please speak to your healthcare professional.Patient safety is our highest priority. We strongly encourage anyone to report any issues with this product, or more generally with any medical device, to our yellow card scheme.”If you have recently used, or are planning to use, Clear and Simple digital pregnancy tests then you need to check the batch number before you do.Catalogue number: DM-Lot number: DMEExpiration date: Jan If you pregnancy test is from this batch you shouldit to your pharmacy.Tests on a number of kits from this batch have produced  positive results.A  positive pregnancy test result means youre not pregnant but the test says you are, a heartbreaking scenario for many women.Home tests work by detecting levels of the pregnancy hormone human chorionic gonadotropinin your wee.HAVE YOU BEEN AFFECTED  Email us at andrea.downey@the-sun or call   . You can WhatsApp us on   .Some ask you to hold the stick in a cup of your pee for a few seconds, others ask you to pee with what seems like impossible accuracy, directly on to the stick.There are many things that can cause a  positive result, from using the test wrong to hormone imbalances and medication.In this case, a fault in the design of the Clear and Simple test meant more urine could pass through the testing strip, leading to a  positive result.Home tests work by detecting levels of the pregnancy hormone human chorionic gonadotropinin your wee.Most tests are about  per cent accurate when used correctly, but they are NOT fail-proof.Clear and Simple tests are being recalled for a manufacturing fault, but there are other reasons a test can tell you youre pregnant when youre not.Heres some of the reasons you may experience a  positive result.

title: theresa may dance tory party conference memes

story: Phones across the the United States today received the first-ever mock national wireless emergency alert.The subject of the alert read: Presidential Alert. title: ap photographer max nash conflicts royal family 40 years
story: Nash, who covered conflicts in Southeast Asia and the Middle East, was found dead after collapsing at home.The famed photographer shot everything from war zones, celebrity events and politics before retiring from The Associated Press in .He didnt want to hang up his cameras, though, and continued working as a freelancer for more than a decade.On his LinkedIn Page Nash wrote: Because I never found the job boring and still dont, I continue at .His iconic pictures captured Royal weddings, famous faces and war zones.Nash took images of Britains new Prime Minister Tony Blair entering Downing Street,  Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis in Israel and Prince William and Kate shortly after their wedding.Even sport got the Nash treatment with Manchester Uniteds Denis Irwin pictured being tackled by Chas Eddie Newton during the FA Cup final in .London born Nash first studied photography under his father, former Paris AP photo editor Michael OReilly Nash.He worked first for The New York Times before joining the AP bureau in Brussels in .That posting gave him his first experience in a war zone as conflict gripped Belgiums former colony in the Republic of Congo.Nash arrived at Saigons AP Bureau in late , joining Horst Faas and Carl Robinson as the bureaus photo editors.He told colleagues he often wore a helmet in Saigon not out of fear of bombardment, but because Faas would hit him over the head for mistyped captions.He also worked in Cambodia in the uncertain days after U.S.-backed Gen. Lon Nol overthrew Prince Norodom Sihanouk in .Some  foreign journalists were captured and killed by Khmer Rouge guerrillas after the coup, and former AP correspondent Jeff Williams recalled an incident in which he is certain that Nash saved his le due to his fluency in French.The photographer then covered the Israeli occupation of Lebanon, the Palestinian uprising and riots in the West Bank and Gaza in the late s.Those heavy combat assignments were followed by the First Gulf War and a rash of bombings in Israel in the mid-s.He later transferred to London, covering the British royals, the violence in Northern Ireland, Red Carpet events and car racing.Former bureau chief Myron Belkind: He never slowed down.Even when he finished an assignment, he wouldto the bureau and stay late to see what he could do to help his colleagues.Nash is survived by his children, Eleanor and Michael his brother, Tim and his grandchildren, Benjamin, Livi and Shelley.

title: 5 tory conference speech announcements
story: News announcements in Theresa Mays conference speech that will directly affect YOUR leCancer screening, petrol bills and affordable homes - here are the actual concrete policies revealed at the Conservative Party Conference ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video pivotal-moments-theresa-mays-speech-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May today launched a last-ditch bid to keep her premiership alive with poundbillion in spending with an all-singing, all-dancing Tory conference speech - literally. The desperate PM jigged on stage to Abbas Dancing Queen as she admitted for the first time that the Tory civil war over Brexit is harming her ability to get a good deal. Introduced by booming-voiced Tory Geoffrey Cox, she poked fun at Brexiteer Boris Johnson, heaped praise on business and free markets and fearfully attacked Jeremy Corbyn as he inches microscopically closer to power. But with all the over-the-top theatrics in Birmingham, you may have missed some big new policies - that will directly affect your le.  Promising to finally bring an end to eight years of savage Tory cuts, the Prime Minister pledged a poundbillion housing boost and a poundmillion fuel duty freeze. There was also a poignant tale of her goddaughter behind introducing a new cancer screening regime. Here are the things you actually NEED to know from todays big event.  Theresa May announced the first details of a new cancer strategy after poignantly revealing her goddaughter died of the disease. She pledged that by , , more people will be alive five years after diagnosis than today. The age for full bowel cancer screening will drop from  to  in a bid to raise the early detection rate, currently around %, to around % by . Currently a one-off screening is available from age  but screening every two years is only available from age . The NHS will invest in new scanners and build more Rapid Diagnostic Centres – one stop-shops that help people get treatment quicker.  Theresa May’s spokesman said more details of her cancer strategy - including how much it will cost - will only be revealed by the end of the year, when the NHS’s future plan is published. My goddaughter was diagnosed with cancer, she revealed. It came back and last summer sent me a text saying she was hoping to see another Christmas. “But she didn’t make it.” No further details of Mrs Mays goddaughter, including her age or name, have been released, on request of her family. . Fuel duty is frozen for the th time - while other groups suffer  The Tory government will freeze fuel duty for the ninth year in a row, in a move that will cost taxpayerspoundmillion. Scrapping the planned p-a-litre rise will be in the Budget in four weeks time. This is the very first policy from that Budget that weve had confirmed. It will benefit hard-pressed motorists. But it comes as other groups continue to struggle - with working-age benefits still frozen for four years to . Tory officials suggest the average motorist has gained about pound, in total from all the freezes since . Now compare that to the utterly astronomical cost.  The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates the cumulative effect of all those freezes is now costing the Treasury poundbillion a year. Thats more than the affordable housing budget and more than DOUBLE the amount gained by the government by freezing millions of peoples benefits. Greenpeace campaigner Morten Thaysen said: Instead of subsidising diesel and petrol May should be incentivising the take up of cleaner electric vehicles, and ensuring cheap and reliable public transport for all.  The borrowing cap imposed on local councils will be scrapped completely in a move that is expected to raise an extra poundbillion a year for housebuilding. It is a victory for councils after they spent years calling for the move, only to be rebuffed by the Tory government. But it wasnt immediately clear today whether the changes will have to be approved in Parliament.  Housing groups gave a cautious welcome. Chartered Institute of Housing director Gavin Smart said: “This is excellent news and we look forward to seeing the detail. The Federation of Master Builders branded the decision a victory for common sense. Ruth Davison of the National Housing Federation said: For years, everyone who builds affordable homes – both councils and housing associations – have argued this cap on council borrowing puts the brakes on building more homes. . Foreign home buyers will face a new tax  Mrs May revealed plans to slap an extra tax on foreign buyers of UK homes - and pour the proceeds into the governments rough sleeping strategy. A consultation will be launched on putting an extra rate of stamp duty on those who buy a home in the UK, but do not pay tax here. Tory chiefs said a higher % charge was already added to second and buy-to-let homes worth between pound, and pound.million. The new rate has not yet been set. But it would supposedly help youyoure trying to buy a home by wiping out unfair, foreign competition. . Austerity is over - but with a huge catch  The Prime Minister declared austerity is over after eight gruelling years. This isnt a concrete policy but,she keeps her word, itd have a huge impact on your family. The Prime Minister vowed to invest in public services and renew the NHS in her address to the faithful in Birmingham - despite benefits remaining frozen and cuts hitting Universal Credit. But there was a catch. She phrased her speech to say austerity will end AFTER she gets a good Brexit deal. That leaves open the suggestion thatshe DOESNT get a Brexit deal, austerity could simply power on. She said: When we’ve secured a good Brexit deal for Britain, at the Spending Review next year we will set out our approach for the future.

story: NewsGravestone of young mum-of-two who died suddenly is smashed by vandals in targeted attackBelfast mum Louise McIlwaine was only  years old when she passed away following a stroke in January ShareCommentsByMaurice FitzmauriceNeil Murphy:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsLouise McIlwaines grave has been smashed up "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father has revealed his heartbreak at having to tell his grandchildren their mother’s grave has been vandalised. Chris said: “I’ve always wanted to be covered in tattoos.” “I never considered how other people would perceive me. I’m fascinated with the pain of tattoos and the dferent levels of pain.  “For example I got my eyelids tattooed - and I was blind for three days. People are so blatant about [criticising me]. “I walk down the street now and they don’t even wait for me to walk past, they’ll just openly say ‘look at the state of his face’. “The impression was,you had tattoos it was gang-related. Especially in Northern Ireland where gangs are associated with terrible violence. “Just because I’m covered head to toe in tattoos it doesn’t mean I’m in any way a violent person. “Sometimes people will come up and speak to me - by the time we’ve finished they’ll say ‘I was completely wrong about you.”  Chris says he has had  hours of tattooing on his face alone,  hours on each arm and an excruciating  hours on his left leg. His first tattoo was tribal skull design but the ‘turning point’ was when he had a skull inked across his face. “Once you go to the face it does completely change the way you look,” he said. “But I still feel the same as I did before I had it done. I forget I have the tattoos on my face. I’m the same person inside.” Chris said he never expected his tattoos would make him such a target for judgement. “It never even crossed my mind,” he said.  “I didn’t think about how people would react. If I’d sat down and thought about it I might have done it dferently. “It was what I wanted to do, I just didn’t think about what other people thought.” However Chris doesn’t regret any of his artwork - in fact he’s booked in for another six hour session next week. He says the most painful of all his tattoos was his eyelids, in after which he was blind for three days. “I drove to get them done,” Chris explained. “I got out of the tattoo shop and I was completely blind. I walked into a lamp post on the way home. I couldn’t find my way to the car. I was stranded in Belfast for four hours until my partner came to get me. “It was scary being blind, putting frozen cucumbers and ice packs on my eyes.”  Despite the ordeal Chris says he wants to get his eyelids tattooed again. “I enjoy the pain,” he explained. He said that he finds peace when he’s under the needle. “My daughter has had health problems. At the time getting tattoos was almost a coping mechanism,” he said. “She was going through such pain in hospital. I’d go into the tattoo shop and say, ‘what’s the most painful place to get tattooed ’ and they’d say the face so I’d say, ‘give me that then’. “It sounds silly but I felt like I was taking a bit of pain away from her because I was inflicting it on myself.” “Its not self harm. I love it - it’s art and when she gets better I’ll go on getting tattoos.”  The only thing that could ever stop Chris’ tattoo habit is love for the kids. “As the kids grow up,my tattoos ever affect their le I’ll get them all laser removed. It’s something I wanted to do for myself butthey didn’t like me doing it I would go to the extreme of getting every single tattoo removed.” But that doesn’t seem likely, Chris says his two-year-old daughter likes to colour-in his few remaining bare patches of skin with felt-tip pens. “Jamie, he’s seven - he was four when I started getting tattoos - he’d love seeing my new tattoos. I even got one of the Hulk because he loves it.” So what’s next  Chris says he won’t be happy until every inch of his body is covered: eyeballs, soles of feet, hands and even his privates. “If I want to get my privates done I’ll have to go to England. Here in Northern Ireland they won’t touch it, he said.

title: mums horror toddler left minutes
story: NewsToddler was left just minutes from death after wasp attack in front of horried mumThree-year-old Paulie Pittman needed le-saving treatment after suffering an allergic reaction to the stings outside the family home in Brierfield, West LancashireShareCommentsByJamie LopezToby Meyjes:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPaulie Pittmans mum said he was left minutes from death "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA toddler was just minutes from death after being stung by wasps outside his home. Paulie Pittman needed le-saving treatment from paramedics after suffering an allergic reaction to the stings. The first time the three-year-old was stung he was playing outside his house in Brierfield, West Lancashire. His mum, Asher, had tried to fight the allergic reaction with an Epinephrine Injector but couldnt make it work, reports Liverpool Echo. Instead, an ambulance was called, by which time, Asher said, the shock was so severe that Paulie had to be lted upside down as the medics searched for a vein to inject. He was then taken to hospital for further monitoring.  Afterwards, she feared the problem was so bad she made him sleep in her bed as she couldn’t risk him being stung while asleep. She said: “It was terrying. It only takes four minutes for the sting to kill him. The source of the wasps was traced to a nest in ivy on the side of the young family’s council-owned house. But when Asher called the council she was told that no-one would be able to visit the property for three weeks – and West Lancs Borough Council would charge pound for the call-out alone. Asher, who has lived in Skelmersdale her whole le, said that, as a single mother, she could not afford to pay. She criticised the local authority’s response as “disgusting” and said she had to borrow money from her ex-partner to pay a private contractor to safely remove the nest on Monday.  When the nest was removed, she and Paulie were trapped in her bedroom as several wasps had once again entered the house. She said: “I’m livid. They put my son’s le at risk. If I hadn’t found a contractor to come that day, he could have died. “My dad had to come round with a spray to kill insects just so we could escape the house. He’s my baby and the council wouldn’t help him, it’s disgusting.” Paulie was also unable to start nursery at Bishop Martin for three weeks as all staff had to be trained on how to give an Epipen injection in the event of an allergic reaction.
