title: new mum severe post natal
story: NewsNew mum with post-natal depression hanged herself after wrongly fearing her baby would be taken off herPolish-born Magdalena Honour, , began self-harming just days after her daughter was born in January ShareCommentsByHayley SewellNeil Murphy:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMagdelena with her husband TomLtd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new mum hanged herself after a severe bout of postal natal depression which left her wrongly fearing the authorities would take away her newborn baby, an inquest heard. Former beauty therapist Magdalena Honour, , had been blooming in the days before her daughter was born but after the birth she mistakenly believed she could not cope when breastfeeding her, it was told. The inquest also heard from her mother who revealed she was concerned she would be taken from hershe accepted treatment.Magdalena was prescribed antidepressant medication for so-called baby blues but it was claimed healthcare professionals were either dismissive or regarded her a nuisance and she began to self harm .Last February , just seven weeks after the child was born, Magdalena was found hanged in the bathroom of her home in Bredbury, near Stockport, Greater Manchester by her mother-in-law who assumed she had been taking a shower.  At the time Magdalenas husband Tom, also , who runs a powder coating company was officiating as best man at a friends wedding. At an inquest which Mr Honour was too upset to attend, his mother Louise criticised the care her daughter-in-law received. Polish born Magdalena had met her husband through friends in  and married six years later. Her mother-in-law told the Stockport hearing: She was an extremely positive, warm and generous person who loved to travel and was very family orientated, and loved her family. She was my daughter-in-law and my best friend. She and Tom were so much in love and very close, and both worked very hard to get their first house together. She just really loved le and really wanted to have a baby and was over the moon when she became pregnant.  She had a wonderful time during her pregnancy and really looked forward to having the baby. She had lots of family and friends around her and was a very active person with lots of energy. On the Friday before the baby was born we had been out for a meal and she said she could stay pregnant forever because she felt so well - she was blooming. On th January her daughter was born and there were no physical problems with the pregnancy and they were allowed back home the next day. For the first couple of days Magdalena was just tired due to having a new baby - but she got more anxious and hyper vigilant. She wanted reassurance and she wasn’t sleeping very well. We tried to get her to have a rest but she felt she had to be watching the baby all the time. Initially she was breastfeeding and thought she was feeding for too long or not enough. She felt that she wasn’t doing it right. She would be sitting up right and couldn’t relax. She had a look of worry on her face at all times. She did take advice about breastfeeding but when she felt she couldn’t go out for Toms birthday, that rang alarm bells and she became more dependent on me to be there at the house. She stopped communicating with friends and family in Poland and it was out of character for her.  A health visitor did a depression screening with her which lead to a GP visit and she was given a prescription. She wasn’t keen on taking it but I encouraged her to and made no change in her condition. She thought she wasn’t able to care for her baby and wanted to go back to Poland so her sister and friends could help her. She became persistent about getting a passport for the baby and she needed encouragement to eat and drink. One time when I got to the house she was stood at the top of the stairs and the baby was asleep. She said I have been stood here for ages because I dont know what to do and I knew her decision making had become impaired. I phoned the GP on th February and tried to get an appointment but they said there wasn’t any.  They said they had a prescription ready for her so I picked it up for her, but they were antibiotics. I voiced my concerns about her deteriorating mental state and seemed like a psychosis. They give her some tablets to sleep as she was absolutely exhausted. The GP said get her to see me sooner but he was dismissive of my concerns. I wasn’t listened to. The inquest heard on February  Magdalena cut her wrist and was referred to a RAID mental health team who referred her to a psychiatrist over fears for her wellbeing but embarked on a course of home treatment. Mrs Honour added:  I think she had lost insight into how she was. Her beliefs became very fixed, about being able to look after her daughter. She was concerned she would be taken from her and me and Tom would be in trouble. A health visitor did come after she cut her wrist but came only once that week - it was grossly inadequate. She telephoned them in a very distressed state, she said she was underfeeding and over feeding the baby. She was very frustrated and that she wasn’t being listened too. The heath visitor was trying to get her off the phone like she was a nuisance. She was unable to relax at all - she looked tormented.  Her beliefs were getting very fixed over a delusional matter and she wasn’t making sense. We talked about bottle feeding and she had to stop breastfeeding due to medication. She was very worried about things being contaminated. She started to talk about that she wasn’t sleeping but she was. Magdalena was given diazepam and tablets to help her sleep but the tragedy occurred the morning after she declined to attend a family friends wedding where Mr Honour was officiating as best man. Mrs Honour agreed to stay over with her daughter-in-law and added: I told her that there’s no way we could have managed without her and we have got a beautul little girl. Her sister in law was coming from Poland on the Tuesday and we would get her through this. I had sent a text on the previous Thursday and it was like the old her was back. The text said she was sorry for being a pain and she loved me. I told her everything would be okay. To me it was more than low mood and depression and anxiety.  On Friday everything I purposely tried not to take over the care of the baby, I let her do it. I wanted to show her that he ability to take care of her was good. But she couldn’t recognise that she was caring for her so well. She didn’t want to be admitted for hospital. It fit into her belief that she thought their daughter would be taken away. She didn’t want them to come every day. She found it very dficult and didn’t engage with them. The hearing was told Magdalena was found dead after her mother in law became concerned about theof time she was in the bathroom and used a p piece to open the lock from the outside. GP Robert Beardsell told the hearing: Magdalena was very anxious about the baby and kept checking she was breathing. I would agree she was in a hyper vigilant state. Her sleeping was very poor but at the time I had no concerns over her harming herself. She was suffering with post partum depression with anxiety known as baby blues but I was concerned enough that she needed treatment. I gave her medication to help but she didn’t want to take it because of the breastfeeding. On February th I was requested to ring Mrs Honour back which I did but there is an issue of confidentiality when talking to family members of patients. That’s when I called back to see what she wanted to share.  She told of her anxiety and the lack of sleep but there was no information about suicidal thoughts. I believe I did listen. The bond is important from breast feeding so I felt it was important for her to continue. I didn’t get a strong sense that she was suffering with psychosis or illusions. Health visitor Hazel Wilson said: Magdalena was caring towards the baby and happy and the baby was responding to her well and gazing at her. She said the baby was unsettled at night and not wanting to be put down in the Moses basket but there were concerns she wasn’t coping. Post natal depression affects about -% of new mothers. By February  she was struggling with the baby as she was unsettled. She was quite anxious about putting her down and reluctant to ask for help. I was telling her that she was doing really well and was showing her how she was doing well. There were no concerns from me about weight gain or feeding but she needed more support to settle the baby and needed reassurance about her ability with the baby, and suffering with depression and anxiety. I invited her to a baby clinic and breast feeding group. It was to reassure her that she was caring for the baby effectively. I was concerned that she was suffering with post natal depression but the training I have in mental health is not what the home service can offer.

title: noisy neighbour mum wont evicted
story: NewsNoisy neighbour mum wont be evicted despite  complaints - because its not her fault walls are so thinNatalie Walker of Keynsham, near Bristol, wont be evicted after a High Court judge in London ruled in her favourShareCommentsByTristan CorkPaul KeoghToby Meyjes:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsNatalie Walker will not be evicted from her home in Keynsham "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum has been told she wont be evicted for being a noisy neighbour because the walls of her flat are so THIN.Some  complaints had been made against Natalie Walker for the noise coming from her flat near Bristol . But her housing association has seen its attempts to evict her fall on deaf ears after both a county court and high court judge ruled in her favour.Curo first tried to evict the mum last year but were told by a county court judge that the problems were mainly because the building they both lived in had a serious problem with sound insulation. The housing association appealed and took the matter to the High Court in London insisting the mum of two small children should be evited.But High Court judge Mr Justice Birss agreed with the county court judge in Bristol and said while Ms Walker admitted most of the noise was coming from her flat in Keynsham, she shouldn’t be evicted, reports Bristol Live The High Court heard that Ms Walker’s downstairs neighbour Jamal Azami was driven mad from the noise from Ms Walker’s flat upstairs, but the judge decided he was mistaken in thinking the noise was directed at him and his family. Many of the complaints against Ms Walker related to banging on floors, which the young mum put down to the noise of her ‘very active’ two small children. At the county court in March last year, Judge Paul Matthews said Ms Walker had breached the terms of her tenancy, but refused to order her out of the property in Durham Grove. Having heard recordings of the noise, he said there was a serious problem in relation to the buildings sound insulation.  It meant ordinary everyday activities - including talking and using the toilet - could disturb neighbouring residents. Appealing against the ruling to the High Court, the landlord argued that Judge Matthews was wrong not to evict Ms Walker. But dismissing the appeal, Mr Justice Birss said that, although Judge Matthews thought disturbances were likely to continue, further breaches of the tenancy were by no means inevitable. The judge had held that much of the disturbance he had identied was not caused by any breach of the tenancy agreement or nuisance by Ms Walker, he said.

title: primary school teacher who leaked
story: NewsPrimary school teacher who leaked SATs answers killed herself after being warned she could lose jobKatherine Margaret Walsh, , who taught at at St Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic School in Norwich - and who once appeared TV show Deal Or No Deal - told a friend the answersShareCommentsByYasmin HarishaNeil Murphy:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsKatherine Margaret Walsh was  when she died in May of this year"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA tragic young primary school teacher took her own le after sharing SATs questions with a friend and fearing she would lose her job, an inquest heard. Katherine Margaret Walsh, was found hanged at her home by her father Denis Walsh, , in May of this year. The teacher gained notoriety locally when she appeared on the TV game show Deal Or No Deal back in , when she walked away with just p. Katherine, also known as Katie, was aged  at the time of her death and a primary school teacher at St Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic School, in Norwich. An inquest into her death at Norfolk Coroners Court heard that Katherine had managed to find out what the questions to the exams were and she had told a friend who worked at a dferent school. In a statement, Mr Walsh said: Her friend had been caught and lost her job, but she told them Katie gave her the questions and it was likely she would lose her job too.  Devastated Mr Walsh explained in the inquest, on the day of Katherines death his daughter had told people she was off work sick. Mr Walsh told the inquest how he knew to go and visit Katherines home in the morning on  May after a friend had got in touch with the family. He explained the friend had received a concerning message from Katherine during the night. Mr Walsh said: My we called me that morning asking me to check on Katie because a friend said she had messaged her to say that she loved them very much. My we had been trying to contact Katie but she was not answering, so she asked me to go. He said when he walked into Katherines home, in Costessey, Norfolk he said he screamed out her name and held her and was hysterical and in shock. He added: She left a handwritten note on the bed and told me not to blame myself. In a second note, left on her iPad, Katherine apologised to her family and friends by writing: I know what I have done is going to hurt many people but I feel like this is all I can do.  Bear in mind, I was massively depressed and feeling like this before this. Mr Walsh explained Katherine had been battling with depression for a number of years prior to her death. Mr Walsh also explained in the inquest that Katherine had been suffering from depression and had been seeing her doctor for a number of years and mentioned Katherine had tried to commit suicide in the past. He added: The issue she had at work tipped her over the edge. She was also about to lose her driving licence because she had been caught speeding, and she was worried about paying her mortgageshe lost her job. Senior coroner Jacqueline Lake found Katherine, of Brian McCarter Gardens, took her own le.

title: princess charlotte prince george already
story: NewsPrincess Charlotte and Prince George already having royal training to ensure they dont make any mistakesAn etiquette expert believes Prince George and Princess Charlotte will already be learning some of the key skills they will need as a royalShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  OCT NewsIts time for Royal lessons! "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince George and his little sister Princess Charlotte steal the show every time they attend an event with their parents, thanks to their cheeky faces and cute waves. But as they get older they will be expected to follow all the rules and protocol that comes with being a royal . Kate and William are doing their best to give their kids as normal an upbringing as possible, but they are well aware of the unique future they have ahead of them. So a royal etiquette expert believes the Cambridges will be training George, Charlotte, and Louis when hes old enough from a very early age. Myka Meier, from Beaumont Etiquette, told Cosmopolitan the initial training would probably be done by Kate.She said: Prince George and Princess Charlotte’s etiquette education likely started as soon as they could attend events with their family. It would probably begin with simple training like how to shake hands and curtsy around the age of two. Initial training would likely be given by their mother, The Duchess of Cambridge. George and Charlotte have been regulars at big family events since a very young age, and theyve already been on Royal Tours and stood on Buckingham Palaces balcony for Trooping of the Colour.  Theyre normally very well behaved, and there have only been a couple of wobbly moments so far.Unlike newbies to the royal family like Meghan Markle , who have to learn everything at once to bring them up to scratch, children born into the family can pick bits up slowly.Myka adds: Growing up in the Palace would mean that training is much less a course or official training, and more day-to-day observation and gentle lessons right before an event or when meeting an important guest to help prepare them.

title: this child ping off frustrated
story: NewsFrustrated mums Snapchat message hours before toddler died after being bound in monstrous cageEllie-May Minshull-Coyle was  months old when she died after being forcibly restrained face down by ligatures on her bed, a court heardShareByLynda RoughleySophie Evans:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsEllie-May Minshull-Coyle died after being forcibly restrained face down by ligatures on her bed, jurors heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA frustrated mum sent a Snapchat message to a pal in the hours before her toddler died after being bound in a monstrous cage, a court has heard.In the message, sent after her daughter became unsettled, Lauren Coyle, , said: This child is p***ing me off tonight, a jury was told yesterday. And in another message, she said: Shes taking the Mick now. Ellie-May Minshull-Coyle was  months old when she died after being forcibly restrained face down by ligatures on her bed, jurors heard. She was tied to the mattress of the bed, which had been turned into a cage, with ligatures across her chest and legs, Liverpool Crown Court was told. The little girl was full of le before she woke up around midnight and a duvet was allegedly placed over her and her ankles were bound together.  Prosecutors claim, at some point, she vomited onto her bedding and pillow, before eventually her heart stopped beating and she stopped breathing At the time of her death on March  last year, Ellie-May was living with Coyle, the mum’s boyfriend Reece Hitchcott, , and lodger Connor Kirby, , in Preston, Lancashire. All three are on trial at the court and all deny manslaughter. Coyle is said to have sent the Snapchat message to her friend at some point in the hours before her daughter was pronounced dead. During the course of the night, the toddler was placed in a very dangerous sleeping environment, the court was told. By mid-morning, she was dead, prosecutors said. Opening the prosecution case yesterday, QC Christopher Tehrani said the three defendants, each in their dferent ways, were responsible for or took on the responsibility for the child’s care and welfare.  He alleged Hitchcott built the cage, which he described as “a monstrous structure”, against the two sides of Ellie-May’s toddler bed. The jury of six women and six men were shown photographs of the bed which showed slats and sides from her cot had been attached to it with towels and sheets draped over them so the child could not see or get out. It is alleged the little girl had been forcibly tied to the bed on more than one occasion and restraint marks on her body showed she had had at least one wrist and one ankle tied. The prosecution said the duvet placed over the tot would have impacted on her ability to control her body temperature, causing her immense suffering, distress and upset. Mr Tehrani said: “By being restrained in her bed in a face-down position the prosecution say Ellie-May’s breathing would have become compromised. She would not have been able to move off her front due to being restrained to allow her to resume breathing properly.  “Ellie-May at some point, say the prosecution, vomited onto her bedding and pillow. Eventually, her heart stopped beating and she stopped breathing. The placing of the duvet over her body would have complicated matters further and may well have resulted in hyperthermia. The prosecution’s case is that Ellie-May’s death was unnecessary, pointless and wholly avoidable. The court heard Coyle and Hitchcott had been in a relationship for about three months and lived in a two-bedroom flat. Hitchcott’s friend, Kirby, had been lodging with them for a number of months, sleeping on the sofa. During the night of  to  March , Ellie-May appears to have been unsettled, claimed Mr Tehrani. At some point during the course of the night, Ellie-May was placed in a very dangerous sleeping environment...and by mid-morning on March  Ellie-May was dead,” claimed Mr Tehrani.  Mr Tehrani said on March , Ellie-May had been “full of le and mischievous” and had a good appetite. Evidence suggested Hitchcott, assisted by Kirby, put her to bed about . pm and she slept well until shortly after midnight.The prosecution said Coyle sent the Snapchat message to her pal saying: This child is p***ing me off tonight.In messages to her dad, Sean Coyle, she told how she had left the child to cry for two hours as she’s taking the Mick now. He told her not to have a go at Ellie-May and to grin and bear it, the court was told.Sean Coyle called round sometime between  and .am to check on his daughter and grand-daughter and she told him to be quiet as Ellie-May was sleeping, it was said.When he went into her bedroom, Hitchcott was crouched over her bed in a gap between the end of the bed and the wall. He believed he was trying to wake Ellie-May, who was lying on her back. He askedshe was okay and he replied: “Yeah I think so.”  Mr Tehrani suggested: “You may think that was an unusual response, he had got to know her and treated her asshe was his own daughter.” Mr Coyle realised something was not right and when he askedshe was breathing Hitchcott shook her arm, the court heard. “When Mr Coyle looked at Ellie-May her eyes rolled back into her head and she looked ‘clammy’, the prosecution said. Mr Coyle now knew that something terrible had happened to Ellie. An ambulance was called and after ing to the bedroom, Mr Coyle told Hitchcott to get Ellie-May, who still had the duvet over her, out of bed. Hitchcott pulled the covers about half way down the bed and put his hands under her torso and pulled and lted her up. Mr Tehrani queried whether he was struggling to do so as her feet and legs were tied by the pink blanket and other material and he had not had time to unbind her. Mr Coyle and paramedics tried to resuscitate Ellie-May. She was taken to Royal Preston Hospital and was declared dead at .am.  Mr Tehrani told the jury that after her collapse the police attended and it was found that a pink and a blue blanket had been used as ligatures going under the mattress. The blue one - which would have corresponded with Ellie-May’s chest area - was undone but the pink one - which would have corresponded with her legs - was knotted and tied so tightly the sides of the mattress were raised off the bed frame by cm, it was said.Coyle later told police Hitchcott had been binding her daughter across the chest with the blue blanket since mid-January saying it would help her settle into a sleep routine and stop her banging her head on the wall. She said she did not approve of the action and never did it herself. Coyle had also been given ‘safe sleep’ practice by a health visitor and told to put her to sleep on her back. Kirby said Hitchcott had built the cage and attached it with his help in January last year. Hitchcott allegedly told a friend after the child’s death that he had restrained her in her bed on the night of March  by tying the blue blanket around her.

title: venomous false widow spider infestations
story: NewsThousands of children banned from school due to deadly venomous spiders that are about to hatch eggsFour schools in the Newham borough of London are closed while the dangerous spiders - Britains deadliest - are dealt with by pest controlShareCommentsByGrainne Cuffe:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsFalse Widow Spiders are the UKs most poisonous arachnid"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThousands of children have been told to stay home today because their schools have been invaded by Britains deadliest spiders. Newham Council has evacuated two primary and two secondary schools to treat the invasion of  widow spiders immediately before the eggs start hatching. Thousands of kids in the east London borough stayed home while pest control experts scoured the schools in a bid to curb the killer menace. False Widow Spiders, the UKs most poisonous arachnid, are dark-coloured with globular bodies and range from . to  mm in size. Although named because of its physical similarity to the killer black widow spider, the species bites rarely cause death but can be very painful.  Symptoms include severe pain radiating from the bite and fever - but could prove fatala young and vulnerable child was bitten in an especially sensitive location. Four schools in the east London borough are facing weeks without lessons, including Lister Community School, Star Primary, Ellen Wilkinson Primary and Rokeby Secondary School. Headteacher at Star Primary, Lisle Von Buchenroder, said the school was forced to close so pest control can exterminate the eggs before they start hatching. In a letter to parents Wednesday she said: I am writing to update you regarding the current school closure. It was with much regret that I had to make the decision to close the school yesterday as the safety and well-being of pupils and staff is always our number one priority. I was made aware of an infestation of noble  black widow spiders which was discovered during a routine check by Newham’s Environmental Team. They believe that the infestation is contained to the outside of the building and that this needs to be treated immediately before the eggs start hatching. I want to reassure all members of our community that these are precautionary measures and that we are very lucky to have found out in time to take action to remove them. After speaking to the Environmental Team this morning, I do regretfully have to inform you that I am advised the school treatment plan will happen in two phases, starting tomorrow.

title: woman who only went toilet
story: NewsWoman who only went to the toilet ONCE a week was so bloated by mystery illness that people thought she was pregnantKayleigh Henning suffered from bloating, constipation and abdominal cramps for more than  yearsShareCommentsByLiz Dunphy:,  OCT NewsKayleigh Henning suffered from bloating, constipation and abdominal cramps for more than  years, pictured here with husband Robert "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman who was so bloated by a mystery illness that people thought she was pregnant is now expecting her first child after beating illness by avoiding six common foods .Kayleigh Henning suffered from bloating, constipation and agonising abdominal cramps for more than  years. Her condition was so bad she could only go to the toilet once a week. Sleepless nights were spent curled up on the bathroom floor in agony while multiple doctors failed to correctly diagnose her problem.Kayleigh said: It was so annoying because everyone just assumed I was pregnant and wouldnt leave that alone - I was definitely not pregnant!Id wear tights or anything like that which normally fit me for the whole day. By the end of the day, Id be very uncomfortable and Id have pressure marks from my trousers or tights imprinted on my skin.  “It was pretty painful, which affects you mentally. You feel like you just dont want to go out anywhere. Id often find Id experience diarrhoea on nights out and that is obviously pretty embarrassing. So many times I wouldnt feel like going out. Because I was constipated, Id be going to the toilet only once a week. That in itself is disconcerting because youre thinking in the back of your head why havent I been to the toilet . I probably endured the problems all through my s, even at university. Id been to see my GP mainly because of constipation problems and Id get given fibre gel drinks, she says. Kayleighs situation came to a head when she graduated from Heriot-Watt University, in Edinburgh, and moved from Scotland to Northern Ireland that week.  “The stress of that culminated in my first visit to AE. I was really worried I wouldnt be able to fly back for the graduation ceremony because I was in so much pain. I was just curled up on the bathroom floor, because it was cold and the best place to be.” Tiredness and depression, caused by her painful and irritable symptoms, had became part of daily le for the then -year-old.Doctors put the symptoms down to Irritable Bowel Syndromeand prescribed a drug they thought would help.Kayleigh went home and had her first nights sleep in - days, but she developed an allergic reaction to the drug and had to rush back to AE. On most occasions [at the GP] I dont know whether it was ignorance or easiness, I always got these fibre gel drinks which I used for quite a while until another GP told me to come off them because they were not a long-term solution.But then Kayleighs personal trainer mentioned food intolerances and said she could fast-track an elimination diet with a test which analyses IgG antibody reactionsto up to  food and drink ingredients provided by the company YorkTest .Kayleigh said: My trainer was intolerant to a few things and didnt know until she took the test. Since she has eliminated those things from her diet, she has felt so much better.” Kayleighs husband, Robert, has ME [chronic fatigue syndrome] and was also going through a rough time but couldnt understand why. Kayleigh says: Hes had a few allergy tests, but never any intolerance tests. He had already eliminated gluten and cows milk from his diet. His lunch consisted of a chicken breast, potatoes and an egg every day.  “Interestingly when he took the intolerance test, which I got for him as a Christmas present, he found he was intolerant to eggs! So as soon as he eliminated the eggs he felt better as well.” Although Robert had around  intolerances, from eggs to raspberries, the message from specialists was not to panic - and even that some intolerances can be reintroduced six months after eliminating them from a diet. Kayleighs test - the YorkTest FoodDrink Scan programme - also threw up several surprises, revealing she had reactions to cow’s milk, egg white, lentils, yeast, buckwheat and gluten. “I’m not surprised by cow’s milk or gluten and avoided them as much as possible, because I knew that they didnt agree with me. I was surprised by lentils - I loved making lentil soup and sweet potato and lentil stew - and of course lentils are seen as healthy,” she says. My borderline list had things like walnut, rhubarb and avocado, which I ate all the time as well. What the experts advise is to eliminate everything over a period of six months then you can start to reintroduce things. We dont necessarily do that, but we can enjoy things on occasions and not suffer because were not eating them every day. The test involves sending a finger-prick blood sample to a laboratory for analysis followed by up to two consultations with a nutritional therapist.  Kayleigh says: “I found the nutritional consultation very helpful. Particularly when it came to finding alternatives, especially for garlic! “She was able to provide much more specic information on what to avoid based on food groups and gave some great alternatives and recipes,” she says. As soon as Kayleigh started her elimination diet, she immediately felt better. “As I had already removed gluten, wheat and cow’s milk from my diet, I found it relatively easy to remove the remaining foods. The one I found most dficult was yeast. “I definitely feel much better, and I know when I have eaten something that I am intolerant to immediately. I havent been constipated since, I bloat much less, and I don’t experience the same stomach cramps, provided I steer clear of my trigger foods. I do eat the odd food I probably shouldnt, but at least I know the reason for any discomfort. I am so much happier, consistently comfortable and have regular bowel movements, too.

title: young mum runs fashion brand
story: NewsYoung mum runs own fashion brand with , Instagram followers from bedroom after learning techniques on YouTubeEmily Southern stays up until am working on her Cub Le designs and then gets up early to do the school runShareCommentsByKelley Price:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsEmily Southern quit her paramedic course to set up clothing brand Cub Le"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum runs her own fashion brand with , Instagram followers from her bedroom. Emily Southern stays up until am some nights working on her designs and then gets up early to do the school run. She orders garments from a wholesaler and prints her own designs after “sitting up for nights on end, watching YouTube videos”, to learn how to do it. Emily quit her paramedic course to set up the ultra-cool kids and parents’ clothing brand, Cub Le. The brand - originally run from her kitchen but now moved to a bedroom - has been featured in Tatler magazine, Teesside Live reports.  The -year-old, from Billingham, County Durham, realised she didn’t want dress her little boy Joey, now nearly five, in the stereotypical ‘blues, greens and dinosaurs’. That was one year ago, now she’s sold thousands of products in her own, mainly monochrome, designs and is planning to expand into wholesale supply and take on staff. She said: “It’s all pinks and blues for kids on the high street, I didn’t realise how common it is many parents want to dress their children in unisex. “Everyone takes a dferent line on it now.”  But it was only once she started selling personalised designs that things started to take off. “Once I got the idea out there, it took a couple of weeks for people to start looking at it,” Emily added. “I introduced personalised stuff - and as soon as I brought that out people just jumped on it. “I was working from my kitchen, but I’ve moved into a bedroom now.” Her latest design - tops sporting the logo Future Changer - is another take on personalisation.  “People have the option to add whatever they want, so my son’s says ‘Future Paleontologist’ because that’s all he ever talks about. “I thought ‘why not have what children aspire to be when they’re older  I’m donating % of the sales to World Vision UK, a charity that helps children create their own futures. “And I wanted something you couldn’t get on the high street. “I never expected this, my friends say ‘we just can’t believe how it’s taken off’ - but when I’m sat crying on my office floor because I’m so tired, I don’t really think about it. “Some nights I don’t get to bed till am, then I get up for the school run, but it just works. “And my partner, Joey’s dad, helps me a lot with day-to-day stuff like school drop-offs and bed times.”

story: NewsNurses give organ donor guard of honour as hes wheeled through hospital before le support is switched offThe moving scene took place at St. Lukes Hospital in Meridian, Idaho, USA, in what staff call a Walk of RespectShareCommentsByToby MeyjesLuke Kenton:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video nurses-give-organ-donor-guard-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEmotional hospital staff lined corridors as a silent mark of respect in a guard of honour for a dying organ donor on his way to have his le support switched off. The powerful tribute took place at St. Lukes Hospital in Meridian, Idaho, where they call it a Walk of Respect. In moving footage, staff from all departments stand side-by-side with family and friends of the donor in complete silence as he is wheeled from the Intensive Care Unit to the Operating Room. Arranged for every organ donation, the tradition was captured on video last week as a -year-old patient - whose family asked for him not to be identied - was wheeled through the hallway before being taken off of le support and passing away.  Public relations manager, Anita Kissee, who captured the video, said: [I] was moved by the number of people who made a point to be there. There were not a lot of dry eyes - I too was wiping my tears. What a privilege to be invited to be there in that moving moment. A spokesperson for St. Lukes Health System added: Its a way to pay tribute to the patient, their incredible gt of le, and support the family during a deeply emotional time.

title: teen didnt know pregnant until
story: NewsTeen didnt know she was pregnant until she was giving birth on kitchen floorMilaois Murphys mum Victoria thought she had appendicitis until she went into labour and her waters brokeShareCommentsByLynne KelleherChris kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMum Malois Murphy with her partner James Mulligan and baby Harper "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager didnt know she was pregnant until she gave birth on her kitchen floor to her tiny daughter weighing just a pound. Milaois Murphys mum Victoria thought she had appendicitis until she went into labour and her waters broke. The -year-olds baby girl, Harper, arrived at just  weeks as an ambulance was en route to her Dublin home in the middle of the night. Milaois told the Irish Mirror that the baby literally slid out into my trousers - and hailed her mum actions in resuscitating the newborn as heroic.  The teen said: “She was born on the kitchen floor. “When she came out she let out a little cry and then she stopped breathing so me Ma had to resuscitate her. “The baby was only the same size as her hand. She was just a pound .If it wasn’t for her, she is a super Mammy. I think the ambulance men were telling her how to do it.  “The ambulance and the fire brigade were just amazing. They did kind of scare me a little bit when they said they had to put the baby in a plastic bag to keep her warm. “At that time, I didn’t even know what I had. I had so much adrenaline going around my body, I didn’t feel pain anymore.” Milaois had been getting sick all that night but had no idea she was pregnant. She said: “I had back pain and I couldn’t sleep but that was my only symptom. I thought I was getting a bit chubby. “The baby could have been kicking but I didn’t know because I never had a baby and I thought it could be wind or something.  “That night, I was vomiting and vomiting and I said, ‘Ma, I need to go to the hospital’. We thought it was my appendix and we rang the Mater at about  o’clock. “Within seconds I felt pressure and my waters broke everywhere. “Me Ma knew straight away and told me to relax and called my sister and the baby literally slid out into my trousers. She was born on my kitchen floor. I was brought to the Rotunda. “I was so numb with the shock it didn’t click with me until the next morning that I had a baby. “Then I went up and I saw her and the mother instinct immediately kicked in. Then I rang her father and we went up and picked her name.”  RTE series, The Rotunda, airing on Thursday at .pm, catalogues the long and dficult road for baby Harper who was in intensive care for months. Consultant Neonatologist Adrienne Foran said the arrival of the baby at one pound and  ounces was a huge shock to Milaois and her partner James Mulligan. She added: “Harper was smaller than a bag of sugar. She was about  minutes old when I met her, she had come in with no heart rate but responded well to initial resuscitation. “We had to ask Milaois after having that big shock to express her own breast milk which was the best thing for the baby.That’s an awful lot to ask a girl who five or six hours earlier went to bed with not a care in the world to find out she was in labour, had a baby she wasn’t expecting who is potentially very sick, very premature.”

title: designers from across europe heading for dundee
story: Hundreds of designers from across Europe will head to Dundee University in April for an international conference, when the European Academy of Design event Running With Scissors takes place.Designers, businesses and researchers will discuss topics such as the future of healthcare, articial intelligence, entrepreneurship and ethics.Delegates will be encouraged to “take contrary views” to shed new light on challenges.Dr Louise Valentine, head of entrepreneurship, enterprise and employability at Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design, said: “We’re bringing one of the world’s most influential design conferences to one of the world’s most interesting design cities.“Dundee is the ideal location to debate the future of design given its strong heritage, entrepreneurial school of art and design, world-leading design research and its international status as a Unesco City of Design.”

title: embarrassed freddy frans confident dundee united can recover
story: Dundee United defender Freddy Frans admits he felt embarrassed to have led the side during their - home defeat at the hands of Ross County which, ultimately, spelled the end for Csaba Laszlo.Frans captained the side on the day as Csaba was relieved of his duties as manager in the wake of the Tannadice hammering.His No  Laurie Ellis has taken interim charge and will likely be in the dugout as United travel to Somerset Park to face league leaders Ayr United on Saturday.And, although he is still hurting after the County calamity, Belgian centre-back Frans believes they can bounce back straight away.“People should look at themselves, we don’t need to talk about somebody , we don’t need to talk about the manager or other players,” he said.“We need to look at our own performances and I feel embarrassed.“Especially in an important game like this against one of our title rivals. I can’t remember getting beaten like this.“At half-time there was a lot of emotion, we were trying to get things straight and after the game we’re angry but what can you say  We need to look at ourselves.“It’s easy to look at others and pass the blame on but there is no use in doing that.“We need to stick together.“You always have to be confident, it’s stupid as a football player to think you can’t turn it around. You have to stay positive.“Even though it’s hard to take we have to take it on the chin and go again this weekend.”The -year-old was at a loss to explain what went wrong on Saturday as a Billy Mckay hat-trick and goals from Sean Kelly and Joshua Mullin did the damage for a United side that could only muster one of their own through Pavol Safranko on  minutes.What Frans did accept though, was they need to improvethey want to get the better of the likes of Ross County and others now above them in the race for the Championship title.The Terrors lie in fourth, five points behind leaders Ayr and Frans feels they can learn a thing or two from their promotion rivals.“Sometimes it’s hard to explain in football, you get so much confidence and then this happens. It comes from nowhere,” he added.“I think we started really well. We had a great chance at the beginning and, obviously, we miss it. We concede a stupid goal on a set-piece where we need to be smarter.“We get back into the game with a great goal and, in that moment, I thought we were OK but again we concede a stupid goal again with a cross from the side.“Even then at - it’s bad but I thought ‘look we’ve got  minutes to turn it round’ and then we concede quite early.“The red card for Stewart Murdoch finished it. It’s easy to blame it on mentality but with the goals we conceded it’s about quality as well.“It’s about being smart. That’s what theydid better on Saturday, they were more dirty, more street-wise and we’re too nice.“I can’t blame boys, especially during the week in training, for effort because we train really hard butyou see the game on Saturday it’s logical for the first thing people question to be mentality.“You can run as much as you want butyou don’t do the basics and take a hold of the ball,you don’t pick up your man, simple things like that you’ll lose the game.”Frans apologised to fans, saying: “There’s not much we can say to the supporters, just sorry. I know it’s cheap to say but there is no excuse. We’re just sorry.”

title: give laurie ellis the managers job permanently says dundee united legend john holt
story: Tangerine legend John Holt believes the Dundee United board do not have to leave Tannadice to find the perfect successor to Csaba Laszlo.The man who won the Premier League and two League Cups with United believes caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is the man to take over on a permanent basis.John remains a regular at home matches through his work in the Tannadice hospitality lounges and was sad to see Csaba sacked but believes after a dficult start to the season that the - weekend loss to Ross County made his departure inevitable.“You never like to see a manager sacked and I feel sorry for Csaba, I really do, but it’s been clear for a while now things haven’t been working.“Saturday was another bad home defeat and, for any manager,the team isn’t performing in front of their own fans it’s a big problem.“After the fourth goal I’d say between , and , fans just got up and left. You can’t have that. I know United are not where they want to be right now but even so you can’t have that kind of defeat at a club this size.”“Holtie” was pleased to see Ellis put in interim charge after the manager was sacked on Sunday but feels the way forward was a permanent appointment there and then.“I’ve spoken to Laurie a few times now and he comes across as someone who knows what he’s talking about and how to get the best out of players.“That’s what United need right now because they’ve a decent squad, it’s just that Csaba wasn’t getting the best out of them.“Laurie’s still young and it would be his first job as a manager, but with an experienced No  I think he’d be a success.“He’s got a steely edge to him but he gets along with people. He’d be good with you boys in the press and unlike in my day that’s important for a manager.”If Ellis doesn’t get the nod, the former favourite knows who he’d like to see the club turn to but accepts his second choice may not be heading back to Scotland any time soon.“Billy McKinlay is someone who’d do a great job. ‘Badger’ is a respected coach and he’s someone who knows his stuff.“I think the problem with him would be the level he’s been operating at down in England and where.”

title: jim mcinally backs former dundee united teammate to take over as manager
story: Jim McInally believes a former team mate would be the best choice as Dundee United’s new manager.The Tangerines are searching for a replacement for Csaba Lazlo.But Tannadice legend McInally would plump for Billy McKinlay, who made  appearances for United and has worked as a coach with Roy Hodgson at Fulham and David Moyes at Real Sociedad, Sunderland and West Ham.McInally, now Peterhead boss, told the Evening Express: “There are problems in boardrooms with chairman and directors who don’t look at the bigger picture enough.“Billy McKinlay had one failed spell as a manager in Norway.“But ultimately he’s worked at the highest level with Real Sociedad, Fulham under Roy Hodgson and last season at West Ham, and David Moyes thinks the world of him.#What I know about Billy is that he’s a really good organiser of a team and from what I understand that’s what United need.“It’s not just because he’s an old team-mate but he’s somebody that’s dferent and I would like to see the people making the decision look at the bigger picture.”McInally, who played  times for United, is desperate to see his old clubto the Premiership.He added: “Their current plight has been down to lack of leadership at the top.#

title: neil mccann backs his dundee players to handle the heat
story: Dundee will have to face a dferent kind of pressure this weekend against Kilmarnock but manager Neil McCann is backing his players to handle it once again.The Dark Blues boss was full of praise for the way his defence dealt with Hamilton’s direct approach in the second half of their - victory.Accies brought on strikers Rakish Bingham and on-loan Mason Bloomfield as they bombarded the Dundee defensive line.However, with the help of the crossbar a couple of times, Dundee held out and lted some of the heat that’s been on the manager and his team after the six straight defeats that began their season.With Killie’s attacking line of Greg Stewart, Eamonn Brophy, Jordan Jones, Chris Burke and Kris Boyd it’ll be a dferent sort of pressure the Dark Blues will have to be ready to deal with.Neil, though, expects the edginess in their defending as they homed in on their first win to be gone come Saturday.He said: “The next game will be a tough one against Kilmarnock but we enjoyed last weekend because it had been a long time coming.“Against Hamilton, I knew they would go direct, they brought Bingham on and did go more direct.“You have to deal with that – there is only so much you can do as a manager, tactically, and the players have to deal with it.“You have to be able to deal with the threat of them going direct.“There was a wee bit of edge still in their game because I’ve been saying for weeks I’d love to see them go in front and see what it did to their game.“I always knew they would still be playing with pressure but they dealt with that.“They had to deal with long balls, there were a couple of balls flashed across the goal but I thought we were well worth our three points last Saturday.”Meanwhile, a Dundee reserve side including first-teamers Jack Hamilton, Darren O’Dea, Jesse Curran and Jean Mendy were thrashed - by Dunfermline at Kelty Hearts’ New Central Park.It was Jimmy Boyle’s men’s first defeat in the Reserve League with goals from Lewis McCann, two from former Dundee United man Robbie Muirhead and second-half penalties from Tom Beadling and Myles Hippolyte counting for the Pars.The match did see a first outing for new Dee signing Grant Nelson.The -year-old from Rangers signed up with Boyle’s reserve side before the contest.

title: no looking back now for dundee after win nabi
story: There’s no looking back now for Dundee after they picked up their first victory of the season at the weekend, according to attacker Adil Nabi.The - success at the Hope CBD Stadium in Hamilton brought a welcome end to their run of seven-straight league defeats which stretched back all the way to last season.And, now they have got up and running finally, Nabi says it’s onwards and upwards for his new side.And he’s targeting a second result on the bounce when Kilmarnock come to Dens this coming Saturday.He said: “We’re not looking back – it’s all about looking forward now as a team and it’s about kicking on.“Bring on Saturday back at home.“We didn’t really look at the table but we knew the situation, you can’t hide away from that but as a team we have shown what we are like and we’re going to keep going and going.“On our day we can beat anyone, we’re not scared of anyone.“When we play like we played at Hamilton, showing both sides of the game, we can beat anyone.”The former West Brom and Peterborough forward, who signed for the Dark Blues in the summer, admits they had a bit of luck on their side against Accies.However, he insists that was deserved after a performance that showed two sides to Dundee’s current side.“It was overdue,” he added.“We rode our luck and got some luck back on Saturday – they hit the bar twice but we showed we can play our football and we can fight as well.“We showed that in abundance on Saturday.“Everyone is over the moon, the gaffer, the boys, absolutely buzzing and cant wait for the next game.“If you’re going to win sometimes you have to ride the storm and we rode it quite well.“There was no doubting they would come at us and put us under the cosh. We were troubled a few times but that was it, really.“We played as a team and that’s what we are about, to be honest.“We can play football but we know how to change it up sometimes, we can play long or play short and we showed that on Saturday.”Nabi has had to be patient in his short Dundee career so far after impressing during the club’s pre-season training trip to Portugal and earning a six-month deal.Saturday was just his fth start for the club and he says he’s starting to feel he’s up to speed.And he has promised to repay a lot of online support from Dundee fans by beginning to hit the net.Nabi had the chance to open his account against Hamilton but sent a good opportunity over the bar.He added: “I said to the gaffer that after my third, fourth start I’d be firing.“I’m slowly showing that, getting chances and looking lively.“I know the fans are happy with me – I read on the internet all the time that they are buzzing!“Hopefully, now I can start getting myself on the scoresheet and carry on.“I should have put that one away definitely but that’s going to come, I know that for sure.“My goals will come.”And with the club finally heading in the right direction, Nabi expects to have more opportunities to score as the team’s fortunes improve.“The win changes the mindset for us. As a team, when we were losing, we didn’t really let that get to us.“I know we’ve been under pressure having not won but as a team we’ve been positive.“We always knew we wanted to get that goal first and we showed what we can do when we get in front. There’s no better feeling than coming away with the three points and long may it continue.“Our season starts now and whatever happened before is past and we need to kick on.”

title: paul quinn claims paul sturrocks role undermined csaba laszlo at dundee united
story: Former Dundee United defender Paul Quinn believes there have to be major changes at the clubthey are to progress.A policy was introduced in the summer to ensure new signings live within a -mile radius of the city but Quinn felt that was papering over the cracks.He said: “Dundee United fans have proved themselves to be good, loyal supporters over the years. They want the best for their club but when you are in Dundee getting moaned at from fans, I guess in restaurants etc, that’s not helpful to the players.“What they should try and change is Tannadice.“When you go in the door it needs modernised.“I love all their history. There are players there up on the wall who I couldn’t even begin to lace their boots. Even within the tunnel area, though, could there not be something changed to reflect the modern era “Something needs to change in the mental side of things to move Dundee United forward.”Quinn was surprised to see club legend Paul Sturrockto Tannadice in March as an adviser to Csaba Laszlo. He said: “Our manager is our leader – that’s the golden rule in football.“You give the gaffer everything but then somebody  comes in all of a sudden and immediately you think: ‘What’s going on here ’“Players talk as football is a small world. They think: ‘The manager likes me but do I now need to keep this new guy happy as well ’“I felt for Csaba then. There’s no way you can dispute what Luggy did as a player for United but that was back in the day.“It looked from the outside as though there was undermining going on – that’s just a fact.”

title: poll results arabs come out in favour of one man to take on dundee united managers job
story: Dundee United fans have given a clear indication that they want a new face to take charge at the club, an exclusive Tele poll has revealed.The Tangerines are on the hunt for a new manager after the departure of Csaba Laszo on Sunday.A number of names have been linked with the position, including long-term assistant Laurie Ellis.However, Arabs who took part in our online poll have come out in favour of former Hearts gaffer Robbie Neilson.The -year-old, whose last spell as a manager was at MK Dons, received % of the voteafter , people took part in the poll.Current interim boss Laurie Ellis came second with % of fans backing him to take the hotseat on a permanent basis.Both Neilson and Ellis are currently the bookies# joint favourites to take on the role permanently.St Johnstone gaffer Tommy Wright was third on the fans# wish list at % # however, in reality the chances of the Northern Irishman coming to manage at Tannadice are slim to none.The poll results in full :Robbie Neilson Laurie Ellis       Tommy Wright Jim McIntyre    Terry Butcher   Billy McKinlay John Hughes     Dick Campbell  Paul Sturrock    Billy Dodds      Ian McCall       Steven Pressley John Robertson Other                 Of the respondents,  people selected the #other# category and suggested other names including former United man Barry Robson, legendary forward Duncan Ferguson, Maurice Malpas and Ian Cathro.Supporter Dave Stewart commented on the poll suggesting Danny Lennon takes charge.He wrote: #Laurie Ellis is guilty by association with the last two failures.#One Tommy Wright voter commented: #We need an experienced manager # no more ex players or inexperienced men.#Robbie Neilson supporters felt he had a decent track record in the SPFL to take the job.One wrote: #It has to be someone that has been in top flight football before. Going with an unknown is completely unacceptable.#Another said: #Robbie Neilson for me. He did a good job with Hearts, he can work on a small budget and knows the Championship well.#While one Arab wrote: #Laurie deserves an opportunity to be in charge of training and discoverhe can motivate players to achieve results in next few matches.#It would be a huge gamble but there are also massive risks appointing some unemployed ex United players. title: relieved gaffer neil hopes hamilton win is turning point for dundee
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann says he hopes his side have turned the corner on their season after being “well worth the three points” at Hamilton.The Dark Blues earned their first Premiership victory of the season with a - success at the Hope CBD Stadium with goals at the end of each half from defender Andy Boyle and midfielder Kharl Madianga.Heading into the contest, the Dens men had no points to their name after six matches but have cut the gap to the teams above them with St Mirren and Motherwell now just a point ahead in th and th position respectively.Dundee gaffer Neil was delighted to finally get off the mark and is hoping it’s just a belated start to the season for his side.He said: “I hope this is the turning point. I just felt we needed to get the first win and I believe in them to go on now.“We enjoyed the weekend because it had been a long time coming.“It’s a relief to get the three points, I’m not going to lie but I’m really pleased for the guys because I’ve been talking for weeks about the belief I still have in them that they could get a result.“I thought we were well worth the three points.“I thought we absolutely dominated the first half, we didn’t change how we played – there’s no use in me saying I have belief in them and then changing how we play.“I thought it was the right way to go on Saturday and we dominated the ball, created chances and it was a great header from Boyle.”On more than one occasion this season Dundee have had the better of the overall play but were unable to take advantage by grabbing the lead.This time, though, with Preston loanee Boyle’s th minute header they did just that and, after seeing Accies pass up a number of chances, sealed victory in stoppage time as Madianga smashed the ball beyond Gary Woods to send the fans and the bench delirious.Neil added: “It was sheer joy. Football is about winning games and when you’re down sometimes you don’t get a lot of luck but we got a bit of luck on Saturday.“I’ve been hammering to them about getting into the lead but we’ve been conceding goals quickly and that belief that you can win games clearly reduces.“I just said to them that our gameplan is to get into the lead, not to just sit back and try to recover from - down.“However, only they can make that happen. Hamilton will have said, ‘get a goal against them and they’re dead’ but the players were well fired up on Saturday, I didn’t have to do anything.“When the goal goes in from Boyle, great delivery from Calvin Miller, you know you have something tangible to hang on to.“I’m so pleased, I don’t want to go overboard because it is only three points but it is a big three points for the club.”

title: Fee introduction was a factor in recyling rate dip but just a blip insists Highland Council
story: THE controversial introduction of the fee for emptying brown bins was a factor in the arearsquos dip in recycling rates last year.But Highland Council chiefs say it was just a blip.While the level of household waste recycled nationally exceeded the amount sent to landfill for the first time, the tonnage slipped in Highland.The regionrsquos  recycling feat of . per cent dropped last year to . per cent ndash and last year a pound charge was brought in for emptying garden waste bins. This fee was increased to pound this year.The councilrsquos vice convener Allan Henderson, who also is also chairman of the environment committee, said: ldquoWhile wersquore getting better at recycling, the change to charging for brown bins has meant some garden waste being channelled into municipal waste.ldquoI believe our proposal to build a lsquomaterial recovery facilityrsquo and roll out extra brown bin coverage will reverse this slight dip.The latest figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyshow that recycling rates improved at  of Scotlandrsquos  local authorities.It estimates that . per cent of waste generated in Scotland was recycled, which was an annual increase of . per cent.Scotlandrsquos environment secretary Roseanna Cunningham welcomed the figures but said more progress was needed, particularly in the cities.The biggest increases in recycling rates were in West Lothian, East Renfrewshire, Dumfries and Galloway, South Ayrshire and Aberdeen City.Ms Cunningham said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has big plans for tackling waste plastics, in particular by introducing a depositscheme, to further incentivise people to recycle.ldquoWersquove also introduced a household recycling charter for local authorities to sign up to, which is making the approach to recycling less confusing for households and creating a more consistent and efficient system for authorities.The Sepa figures show the amount of household waste generated in Scotland was . million tonnes in  ndash a decrease of , tonnes from .Thursday  Oct  : PM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Thursday  Oct  : PM
