but its not Brexit, says Northern Ireland MLABelfastIreland is to give Theresa May and the UK Government a Brexit boost by backing an all-UK customs union with the EU after its departure from the union, it has been reported.https:www.belfasttelegraph news brexit irish-government-boost-for-may-but-its-not-brexit-says-northern-ireland-mla-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece bbd AUTOCROP h bpanews_fcf--d-f-ceaeb_EmailIreland is to give Theresa May and the UK Government a Brexit boost by backing an all-UK customs union with the EU after its departure from the union, it has been reported..pushHowever, one Northern Ireland MLA rejected the plan as "not Brexit".The Financial Times reports - ahead of Leo Varadkar meeting European Council president Donald Tusk and chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier -  officials in Dublin are privately arguing in favour of the proposal for an entire customs union between the EU and UK for a time-limited period.As well as protecting Irish trade with the UK, it would also prevent a hard border on the island.It is one of Theresa Mays proposals, should no solution be found to the Irish backstop impasse.Michael Barnier has already rejected the idea.“It looks like it would resolve that issue [of the border],” a senior Irish official involved in Brexit talks told the Financial Times. “Whether Europe accept it or not is another conversation.”Poll: % of voters believe Theresa May will agree to Brexit border in Irish SeaBrexit: % back special status for Northern Ireland in poll of , online Belfastreaders The forthcoming EU summit on October  is seen as crucial to the outcome of the Brexit negotiations.Taoiseach Leo Varadkar warned time is running out to reach a Brexit deal.Arlene Foster, said the DUP would not agree to any solution which would see a sea border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK - stating her red line was "blood red".DUP leader Nigel Dodds, at the Conservative party conference, said a custom union with the EU had to include the entire UK and be time-limited.Alliance leader Naomi Long said it was much more preferable option and could help grow of the Northern Ireland economy.Citing unionist lobbying for the cut in corporation tax, She said there had been dferences "for years" between the UK and Northern Ireland and there was "nothing to fear".Alliance leader Naomi Long tells #bbcgmu unionists have nothing to fear from Northern Ireland being treated dferently from the rest of the UK after Brexit. pic AIgNm— BBC News NIOctober , However, Jim Allister said to remain within a customs union with the EU "was not Brexit". He said it "denied the right" for the UK to negotiate trade deals with countries in the rest of the world.PUP Belfast councillor, John Kyle said the DUPs "insistence on a hard Brexit poses the greatest existential threat to NI since . A special customs arrangement with EU and U.K. would offer enormous economic opportunities and secure the Union for generations." The EU, meanwhile, is concerned the proposal would in effect create a back door to the single market without any of the obligations of full membership.Ahead of travelling to the continent, Leo Varadkar said: "The immediate focus of the Irish Government is on the pressing need for agreement on a Withdrawal Agreement, with an operational and legally-binding backstop.“The Withdrawal Agreement must ensure that, no matter what the outcome of negotiations on the future relationship between the EU and UK, a hard border on the island of Ireland will be avoided.“This is critically important to reinforce the stability brought about by the peace process and the Good Friday Agreement.“The negotiations are entering a critical phase, and time is running out.“But I believe that an agreement is possible, with the right political will and focus on all sides."Theresa May said the British proposal was "a free-trade deal that provides for frictionless trade in goods" and that under her plan "the seamless border in Northern Ireland – a bedrock of peace and stability would see no change whatsoever".She said she would never accept a deal which "carves off Northern Ireland – a part of this country – effectively leaving it in the EU’s customs union"."We will not betray the result of the referendum and we will never break up our country," she told her party conference.

Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern Ireland call from Belfast baby Caragh Walshs sobbing father is played at inquestCaragh Walsh, who died of a severe brain injuryBy Stewart RobsonOctober   Comments call from Belfast baby Caragh Walshs sobbing father is played at inquestBelfastThe family of tragic Caragh Walsh heard the -week-old child struggling for breath as the  phone call made by her father was played at her inquest yesterday.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland -call-from-belfast-baby-caragh-walshs-sobbing-father-is-played-at-inquest-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news local-national article.ece eac AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailThe family of tragic Caragh Walsh heard the -week-old child struggling for breath as the  phone call made by her father was played at her inquest yesterday..pushThe babys family, including mother Tammie-Louise Walsh, broke down in tears and comforted one another during the second day of the hearing.Caragh was found unresponsive in her home in west Belfast in February  by Christopher ONeill, her father, who was acquitted of her murder last year.The call lasted several minutes, with harrowing descriptions of baby Caraghs appearance heard by the court, such as "going pale" while "struggling for breath".Medical staff who tended to Caragh at the Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children, also gave evidence.Emergency services were called to the scene, a flat in Twinbrook, on February , .When emergency centre staff answered the phone, Mr ONeill was sobbing heavily and had to be asked to slow down by emergency personnel.Mr ONeill said: "My wee -week-old daughter isnt breathing", later adding, "you have to understand, Im so sorry."As the recording of the call progressed, the distraught mother put her head between her knees while other devastated family members soon followed.Sporadic noises from the baby could be heard clearly, sparking further anguish for the family. Dr Julie-Ann Maney, who was recalled to the witness box after giving evidence on Monday, explained that it appeared Caragh had "respiratory dficulty" and was "breathing slowly".Dr Maney added that respiratory arrest then caused her heart to stop and prevented oxygen from travelling to the brain.Mr ONeill was asked to check for signs of le, confirming each time he heard his daughter take and release a breath."I dont know whats wrong," he said, before through tears he added, "I cant look at her."I tried to force a bottle in her mouth to seeshe would take it," he added, after stating that "her eyes are closed and shes shaking."Shortly after emergency services arrived, the father was heard directing ambulance staff to his home. Seconds later, the call ended.Caragh spent two days in hospital before succumbing to a severe brain injury at half past one in the afternoon of February , .Dr John McCabe was the registrar at the Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children when Caragh was admitted. He told the court that trauma became the "main dferential" after speaking to Caraghs father at the hospital. The doctor displayed to the court the way in which Mr ONeill tried to revive his daughter, a movement he described as "vigorous". Counsel for Mr ONeill said it conflicted with that of another medic who gave evidence on the first day.Dr McCabe added that this did not change the approach to Caraghs treatment.Mr ONeill attended the inquest yesterday, which is set to last for five days.

Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandA long drive home for Armagh familys  FordRebuilt car in ,-mile from Armagh to CortinaThe family with their restored  Mark I Ford CortinaBy Mark BainOctober   CommentsA long drive home for Armagh familys  FordBelfastAn Armagh family have completed a four-year labour of love by driving their restored  Ford Cortina through Europe to the town in Italy the car was named after and back again.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland a-long-drive-home-for-armagh-familys--ford-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece bf AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailAn Armagh family have completed a four-year labour of love by driving their restored  Ford Cortina through Europe to the town in Italy the car was named after and back again..pushWhen Mandy Leyburns father Robert arrived home with the shell of the old Mark I Cortina in  she joked it would be lovely to drive it "home" some time in the future, not expecting to be taken literally.Mandysaid shes amazed at the reaction her -year-old car got during its trip through  European countries over two summer weeks to arrive in the Italian town of Cortina - and even more amazed that the car survived. "It really was just a shell when my dad brought it home. Hes always tinkered and restored cars and I wanted to help him. I guess this was my apprenticeship," said the -year-old nurse from Middletown.Mandy and her dad spent weekend after weekend lovingly restoring the car over the past four years."We just started it as a weekend project. We both work full-time, so it was a hobby for both of us," she said."My dad has always tinkered with cars but we took on quite a lot with this one. However, looking at it now, theres no way Id ever part with it. It has a lot of sentimental value."The Cortina caused quite a stir as Mandy, husband Justin Gormley, Robert and mum Jessica made their way through the Continent on the ,-mile road trip. The family spent a lot of their spare time posing for photographs. The Cortina was even commandeered for a photoshoot by a model agency in Paris."The whole experience made us feel pretty cool," added Mandy."Once the Cortina got through the MoT in June we decided wed go for it. We turned it into our family holiday, though we had to load the boot up with a lot of spare parts just in case, as we werent really sureour work on the car would last the pace."We thought about driving straight to Cortina and back again, but it was too good an opportunity to waste, so we planned the trip to take in a lot of the sights all of us wanted to see around Europe. It all went so well and we might plan another one."Apart from the UK, the car passed through the Republic, France, Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg, Germany, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Italy, Austria, Slovenia and Monaco."Weve been through the Black Forest, driven across the Millau Viaduct in southern France, the highest bridge in the world, and around the famous Stelvio Pass in the north of Italy with its  hairpin bends," said Mandy."When we arrived in Cortina DAmpezzo in Italy the locals were amazed to see the car. "There are not that many of them still around, and even fewer managed to make it back to the town they were named after."Back in  a new Ford Cortina would have completed around  miles to the gallon, but Mandy said she wanted to make the car as economical as possible."You could say I had a trip like this in the back of my mind when we put a diesel engine in it, and in the end we were getting up to mpg, so that was well worth it considering how far weve managed to travel in it."

Pic Michael SmythBy Jonathan BellOctober   CommentsBelfast International Airport apology after chaotic delays at security checksBelfastBelfast International Airport has apologised to passengers after long delays were reported during security checks on Monday morning.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland belfast-international-airport-apology-after-chaotic-delays-at-security-checks-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece cb AUTOCROP h Airport_queues_.jpgEmailBelfast International Airport has apologised to passengers after long delays were reported during security checks on Monday morning..pushSocial media users reported "chaotic" scenes as they waited to get bags searched before heading into the departure lounge.Many took to Twitter to show long queues stretching down through the airport as they vented their frustration at the wait.Some labelled it as a "shambles" while others described the scenes as "chaotic". One user joked it would soon be quicker to drive to Dublin than get through the airports security.Its thought bottlenecks occur because of people arriving at the airport too early for their flight while others show up at the advised time leading to more passengers than expected arriving at one time. The airport took to the social network to remind people to arrive at least two hours before departure."Carefully packing your bags at home can help us reduce the time it takes to get you through security," it tweeted.A spokeswoman added: "We apologise to any passengers who suffered delays as a result of queues at security this morning. Customer services staff were on hand to deal with any passenger queries and  indeed any passengers with feedback or complaints we would ask them to contact the airport directly so that we may resolve their issues."Dont forget to arrive at least  hours before your flight and that carefully packing your bags at home can help us reduce the time it takes to get you through security. Check out hand luggage guidance: https:t.co VwFXCnIJ pic LLtTyDrM— Belfast AirportOctober , "The security search area was fully staffed with all security lanes open for the number of departing flights this morning. We again urge passengers to arrive at the airport at least two hours before their flight is due to depart, evenyou are travelling with hand luggage only, and to be prepared for the security search."Long queues at security were reported over the summer causing much frustration. And last Monday the airport blamed equipment failure for long delays though its security.Michael Smyth - a union official for Nautlilus International which represents ferry workers - arrived early at the airport for his flight to Liverpool for his organisations annual conference.He is a regular flyer visiting many of the UKs ious ports. He said he queued for an hour on Monday and while he made his flight with time to spare he said others turned back in the queue saying they had missed theirs."The queue was all the way down the escalator," he said."I just couldnt understand it as all the lines were open and they were processing everyone at a fair rate. It was not like it was going slow, it was just the sheer volume of people trying to get through."And by the time I got through it all the queue was just the same . It was a nightmare."He added: "We went away for our holidays in the summer and had a  minute queue then. But you expect that over the Twelfth fortnight not at the beginning of October when it is mainly just commuters."The thing that really got me today was there was no one giving advice or even helping people who were about to miss their flights. There were some asking to get past to catch a flight and people were letting them through, but there needed to be better assistance.""Had I missed my flight I would have missed important meetings today."The airport pledged to end long delays after it announced a new company would be taking over the handling of security. Wilson James will take over security operations on November .Belfast International Airport urged passengers to be prepared for security checks before arriving at the airport to speed the process along."Adhering to these guidelines and carrying only essential items in hand luggage can help reduce the need for manual checks at security, which can quickly cause queues to build up," the spokeswoman added.The airports guidelines include: Ensuring hand luggage is not densely packedAll non-essential liquids are packed in hold baggageAny liquids brought through security must be in a l resealable plastic bag All laptops, tablets etc must be removed from  hand luggage Remove all coats, belts etc

Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandPregnant sheep skinned in Northern Ireland field - legs choppedDisgust: Arron LamontBy Victoria LeonardOctober   CommentsPregnant sheep skinned in Northern Ireland field - legs choppedBelfastA farmer has expressed his shock after finding one of his heavily pregnant sheep skinned, with all four of its legs chopped off and its throat slit.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland pregnant-sheep-skinned-in-northern-ireland-field-legs-chopped-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece bf AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailA farmer has expressed his shock after finding one of his heavily pregnant sheep skinned, with all four of its legs chopped off and its throat slit..pushPart-time farmer Arron Lamont made the grisly discovery in his field between Kilrea and Rasharkin early yesterday morning.He has reported the matter to the PSNI but said he wanted to warn other farmers of what had happened.Arron said he initially thought a dog was responsible for killing the pedigree Dorset ewe.But he said there is no way an animal could have carried out such an attack."It was like a butcher job," he said.He added that wire fencing had been damaged and the gate into the pen was open.He thinks the attacker pulled the ewe down the field where they cut its throat with a kne. Arron said that the hedge sits lower than the road, so they couldnt be seen.He believes it is there that the pregnant animal was hung up on barbed wire to be skinned and had its legs cut off in the barbaric attack."You can see the clean lines of the kne, and the wool and the skin was cut off - not pulled off," he said last night.Arron explained he had been trying to build up his flock, but now another of his sheep has lambed early because of what he believes is trauma.The lorry driver said he was keeping the horric story from his two young children - a son and daughter aged seven and six respectively - as it was too disturbing.He described those behind the grim attack as "total scum to do this to an innocent animal", which he believed would have suffered."How anyone could do this to an animal is beyond me," he said. "Someone knew what they were doing."This wasnt a five minute job."It wasnt a pretty sight to come across this morning," he added.

For the last two weeks excavators have been removing the top level of peat from the section they plan to search.Now an ICLVR team of forensic archaeologists and technicians will comb an area measuring about  metres by  metres – a task that could take months.Mr Hill said peat excavated during previous searches ended up being dumped on the area now being examined.“The dilemma we faced here is we had up to two metres of peat that had been redeposited on the site from ious searches around ious areas,” he said.“Because of the amount of disturbance this ground has undertaken over the years it makes it extremely challenging.”" width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Jon Hill, senior investigator with the Independent Commission for the Location of Victims Remains Mr Hill said techniques used on previous Disappeared searches, including cadaver dogs and geophysical surveys, were not beneficial for the current dig as there was too much previously disturbed earth.The senior investigator said the volume of wet peat also presented a health and safety issue, as the excavators could not track across the land without sinking into it. The team is using special mats to move the machines over the site.Part of the area was examined in the first search for Mr McVeigh in  – an operation undertaken by the Garda.Mr Hill said it was worth re-examining the ground because techniques now used by the commission were not available to gardai  years ago." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Drone footage of Bragan bog captures the scale of the latest search for Columba McVeigh Mr McVeigh’s brother Oliver said his overriding emotion as the dig progressed was one of “frustration”.“It’s really a waiting game,” he said.“You have to be learn to be patient. We have to be getting closer, but again we could be left disappointed.“I’m searching for him from when I was , I’m now . That’s only the searching – not theof time he’s been missing. The physical search to find his body is  years old.“My mother is dead  years and my father didn’t even know about the searches. I was young when they first started searching and I was helping my mother along and now I’m ." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Columba McVeigh’s brother Oliver “When you put things into perspective like that it’s crazy.“The one positive thing is there’s someone there digging and that’s the only chance they have of finding him. Becausethere’s nobody there digging, they won’t find him.”Three of the  people classied as the Disappeared remain missing.As well as Mr McVeigh, they are former monk Joe Lynskey and soldier Robert Nairac.The ICLVR can be contacted confidentially by telephone on   International +   .

UK’s leading GP has said, as she blamed a lack of resources for outdated methods..pushGP practices already struggling with finances are unable to keep up with the latest innovations, the chairwoman of the Royal College of GPswill say in a speech on Thursday.Professor Helen Stokes-Lampard will call on political leaders to invest in technology to support GPs and ensure the NHS leads the way in patient care.“Give us the chance to tame the ‘tech tsunami’ in a way that doesn’t put existing services at risk, in a way that benefits all our patients, and makes our working lives easier,” she will say.GPs on the frontline just can’t afford the investment in technologyProfessor Helen Stokes-Lampard, RCGPsFacebookTwitterHealth Secretary Matt Hancock has listed the transformation of technology as among his top priorities since taking on the role and urged health chiefs to get on board.Addressing members at their annual conference, Professor Stokes-Lampard is expected to say: “I get really exasperated when I hear accusations that GPs are technophobic dinosaurs. What utter nonsense.“GPs are not ‘afraid’ of technology or innovation.“But robots don’t come cheap, tech costs money, and for GP practices that are already on the brink, implementing new, good technology is unfeasible.”" width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Professor Helen Stokes-Lampard will address the annual conference on Thursday Professor Stokes-Lampard, a practising GP in the Midlands, will also accuse tech companies of creating a “digital ide”, with younger, fitter patients granted better access than those in need.She will say: “Those with the latest smartphone, those who speak English and live in cities, those who have high speed broadband, are being offered something that others are not.“I believe that with the right use of technology in the future NHS we can actually aim to reduce health inequalities and counteract some of the adverse social determinants of health.“But GPs on the frontline just can’t afford the investment in technology, most of us aren’t being propped up by wealthy venture capitalists, after all.“We need technology that works for patients, makes our lives easier and is not lining the pockets of private investors at the expense of the NHS.”I have heard the concerns @HelenRCGP has raised in the media about GP at Hand. We need more GPs, we need more AHPs, and we need to engage the best possible technology to make sure NHS is sustainable and there for generations says @MattHancock #FutureVisionGP #cpc— RCGPOctober , Professor Stokes-Lampard will also reiterate concerns about GP at Hand, which is available to some patients in London and has received the backing of Mr Hancock.The app offers a symptom check for patients and video GP consultations, but has been accused of “cherry-picking” healthy patients.“We need rapid, independent and scientic way to evaluate new innovations, such as online consulting options, software, apps and wearables, so that we can swtly, safely and effectively establish which is the good new technology,” she is expected to say.A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: “Innovative technology has the potentialto really transform healthcare for patients and staff – that’s why we are encouraging innovation from right across the tech sector to work with the NHS.“New tech will augment primary care services and give patients greater choice about how they access expert medical advice.“We’re also investing for the future with an extra £. billion a year in funding for general practice by  – a % increase.”– The Royal College of GPs’ annual conference takes place in Glasgow from October  to October .

title: derry family lost much loved pet donate 1000 local
story: A Derry family whose beloved pet was mauled to death have donated £, to local animal charities and praised the support and generosity of their community after the traumatic event.The city was shocked by the story of Ozzy, a much-loved family pet, who was mauled for almost an hour as his -year-old owner looked on terried and helpless.Marie Doherty had been taking her three-year-old shih tzu, Ozzy, a walk in Bishop’s Field Park in July when he was viciously attacked by two large dogs that were not on a leash.Little Ozzy was rushed to the vet and survived for a couple of days after losing his leg but, sadly, lost his fight for le.Derry City and Strabane District Council confirmed in the wake of the attack that the two dogs responsible, who they described as a ‘Staffordshire Bulldog type’, had been euthanised.Speaking to the Derry News, Michael, Marie’s son, who arrived at the scene after the attack and took Ozzy to the vet, said that the local community and one neighbour title: sdlp host civil rights discussion featuring labour mp went viral last week strong views effect brexit ireland
story: The SDLP will host a discussion this Saturday in the Museum of Free Derry on the fight for civil rights  years ago and the fight that continues today. The discussion will include Labour MP Stephen Pound as a list who will share his views on the fight for civil rights  years on from the Civil Rights Movement. Mr Pound, who is the Labour Shadow Minister for Northern Ireland, went viral last week after a video was made of him speaking in defence of the rights of citizens across Ireland from Brexit. Mr Pound is expected to speak on the challenge of Brexit and the impact on the rights of citizens across Northern Ireland, including the impact on the Irish border and the Peace Process.Commenting ahead of the event SDLP Leader Colum Eastwood said: “The Civil Rights Movement belongs to no one party - it belongs to the people. However, for us in the SDLP it has a special part in our history as our party was founded directly from the Civil Rights Movement. googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“ years on from when citizens marched together in the defence of equality and opportunity for all, it is right that we remember but also that we revive our sense of determination to deliver a future based on fairness for all peoples.“As we face into the uncertainty of Brexit, here in Derry we will have an open discussion with voices from the Civil Rights Movement then and also with those of us committed to delivering civil rights now. This event is open to all. "It is important that we come together to find solutions to the major threats that now face us. This is the time to renew our sense of purpose, our sense of community and deliver justice and opportunity for all.”The event, Civil Rights Then and Now from .pm to .pm, Saturday, October , in the Museum of Free Derry. title: £1bn City Deal initiative could help tourism drive
story: HIGHLY ambitious proposals aimed at shaping future tourist provision in Newcastle are among the key projects included in Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos bid for a share of poundbn investment package under the City Deal initiative.City Deals are packages of funding and decision making powers which allow councils to boost the economy through the development of large projects in their respective areas.They are designed to allow councils to take charge and responsibility of decisions that affect their area, do what they think is best to help businesses grow, create economic growth and decide how public money should be spent.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is one of five councils paired with Belfast City Council, universities and the private sector who have committed poundm to help deliver a raft of schemes, with the remainder of the cash coming from the Treasury and Northern Ireland Executive.It is anticipated that the city deal initiative has the potential to help the councils create , new jobs over a -year period.Enterprising proposals to signicantly enhance tourism attractions in Newcastle were unveiled last year aimed at drawing international visitors to world class attractions in the resort.They include a gondola ride into the heart of the mountains and a visitor centre at the site of the old quarry at Thomasrsquo Mountain.Other proposals include an Alpine coaster ride enabling people to hurtle down the side of the mountain on a single track in a buggy, an indoor activity centre in Donard Park, elevated tree top walk in Tollymore Forest Park and new visitor centre and bird hide at the Murlough Nature Reserve.Consultants appointed to look at developing the resortrsquos visitor infrastructure also suggested constructing a new bridge under the main Kilkeel Road at the Bloody Bridge on the outskirts of the resort.City Deals have been hugely successful in other parts of the UK and the local council is hoping its funding bid will help deliver a step change in the regionrsquos economic fortunes and help achieve future growth.The local council has been working with its partners in close collaboration with the Civil Service, Ministry for Housing, Communities and Local Government and the Treasury to agree the priority projects for the programme of investment.It is also hoped to roll out superfast digital connectivity to enable businesses across the region to connect to new markets and opportunities and keep visitors for longer by investing in additional world class, authentic visitor attractions. There are also proposals to build on Strangford Loughrsquos tourism potential.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin said the local authority was delighted to have reached a key milestone in the development of the Belfast Region City Deal.ldquoWe have in place an investment proposal that focuses on key investment initiatives within our infrastructure, our tourism, our digital connectivity, the skills and education of our people and innovation and digital capability of our businesses, he said.ldquoAs we move through the next stage of negotiations, we will continue to work closely with our partners and stakeholders to ensure that the city deal we secure will deliver on our ambition of a step change in economic performance and more and better jobs for our people.Cllr Murnin said the city deal process had helped to establish what he described as a ldquogenuinely collaborative working relationship across the region and is spearheading a new way of working for councils, the broader public sector, education and business.The local authority and its partners anticipate that an announcement will be made in the forthcoming autumn budget statement, paving the way for them to work up the respective proposals further..prettyPhoto

title: Ash shortlisted for music prize
story: THE new album from Ash has been shortlisted for this yearrsquos Northern Ireland Music Prize.Islands was released by Downpatrickrsquos Tim Wheeler, Mark Hamilton and Rick McMurray in May.The event, which will take place on November  at the Ulster Hall, is now in its sixth year and includes theof three categories that formed part of the very first NI Music Awards back in .Over  industry and media cast their vote for the best album of the last  months. They were also invited to nominate for Best Live, Best Single and the Oh Yeah Contender Award for best emerging act. There will be a second round of voting for all but Best Single, which will go to public vote later this week.The NI Music Prize is coordinated by the Oh Yeah Music Centre and is supported by Belfast City Council, Arts Council of Northern Ireland, British Council, PRS , PPL , Help Musicianrsquos Northern Ireland, Invest Northern Ireland and Tourism Ireland.The winners of each category will be awarded a cash prize. Best Single, Best Live Act and Oh Yeah Contender will receive pound, and pound, will go to the winner of Best Album..prettyPhoto

title: Ballygalget GAC opens new health and wellbeing centre
story: RESIDENTS of the Ards Peninsula will be able to enhance their health and wellbeing thanks to the completion of Ballygalget GACrsquos state of the art health and wellbeing Centre which was officially opened last Friday.The pound, flagship facility, which already has attracted  members, includes a state-of-the-art gym mdash The Camaacuten Fitness Suite mdash with  hour access, changing areas, health and wellbeing room and a fitness area for spin and other classes.The project received grant funding from the Rural Basic Services Scheme of the Northern Ireland Rural Development Programme - which is funded by the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.It was administered by Ards and North Down Rural Partnership Local Action Group. Funding was also provided by Ards and North Down Borough Council.Welcoming the new facility, Mayor of Ards and North Down Borough Council Richard Smart said the council was ldquodelighted to have provided financial support towards the project.ldquoThis state-of-the-art facility will improve the quality of provision and sporting experiences for people living within the Borough mdash something which Ards and North Down Borough Council is wholeheartedly committed to, he remarked.Jerome Burns, from DAERA, lead funder of the Health and Wellbeing Centre, said: ldquoThe Leader programme, through which this project has been funded, enables local people to determine the needs of their own area and decide how best to address these and this project is an excellent example of how the programme is delivering on the ground. I have every confidence that Ballygalget GAC, with its extensive network of volunteers and dedicated committee members, will make this project a resounding success.Paddy Coulter, chairman of Ballygalget GAC said: ldquoAs a club we have been overwhelmed by the generosity of local people and businesses who have rallied behind the project supporting fundraising initiatives such as our Club Lotto and Buy a Brick campaign.ldquoWithout their support and that of our funders, DAERA and Ards and North Down Borough Council this fabulous facility couldnrsquot have become a reality.ldquoThe club are also extremely grateful to the Ulster Community Investment Trust Ltd who provided vital access to finance through their third sector loan fund.Mr Coulter added: ldquoIt is fantastic to see the buzz around the club and so many people joining from surrounding towns.ldquoHaving over  members demonstrates that there really was a demand for a facility such as this, which will help our club, parish and surrounding communities to become fitter and healthier for generations to come.You can find out more by following The Camaacuten Fitness Suite on Facebook..prettyPhoto

title: Ballygowan lecturer appointed veterinary association president
story: SIMON Doherty, a Ballygowan-based veterinary consultant and senior lecturer at Queenrsquos University Belfast, has been elected President of the British Veterinary Association.His appointment was confirmed last week during the Associationrsquos annual membersrsquo day at the National STEM Learning Centre in York.The British Veterinary Associationis the national representative body for the veterinary profession in the UK, representing the views of over , members on animal health and welfare and veterinary policy issues to government, parliamentarians and key influencers in the UK and EU.Simon said it is a ldquoreal honour to be appointed the BVArsquos president at a time when it is critical for the organisation to provide a strong voice for vets.ldquoWe are a relatively small profession, but the BVA has a growing membership who are becoming increasingly engaged due to cross-cutting concerns around issues such as workforce capacity and capability, he explained.ldquoHowever, itrsquos also an exciting time when many vets are exploring the ersity of available career paths, novel working patterns and the opportunities afforded through leadership and innovation.Simon has confirmed that the theme for his presidential year is lsquoone veterinary communityrsquo which builds upon past presidents John Fishwick and Gudrun Ravetzrsquos themes of lsquoTeam Vet ndash Working Togetherrsquo and lsquoThe Veterinary Familyrsquo respectively.His theme encapsulates the crucial role of the veterinary profession at the regional, national and global levels and recognises the importance of continued collaboration with key stakeholders within the profession and with members of the wider animal health and welfare sector.Simon graduated as a veterinary surgeon from the University of Glasgow in  after which he worked for five years in mixed practice in West Stirlingshire in Scotland and closer to home in North Down.He was also instrumental in setting up Veterinary Northern Irelandas a lsquoone-stop shoprsquo for the local veterinary associations in the Province.In , Simon was appointed as a Veterinary Research Officer at the Veterinary Sciences Division of the Agri-Food  Biosciences Institute at Stormont where his research interests included novel vaccine technologies in farm and aquaculture species, colostrum management in dairy systems and the detection and control of epizootic diseases.Simon was appointed an honorary lecturer in animal health and welfare at Queenrsquos in  and ed to the private sector in . The following year, he set up Blackwater Consultancy Ltd, which works with companies to drive inward investment and support export trade in the animal health and aquaculture sectors.For three years, the Ballygowan vet was the animal sciences and aquaculture specialist for the Department for International Trade and in June this year was appointed to a senior role within the Institute of Global Food Security at Queenrsquos.He is involved in teaching, curriculum development and commercial interactions relating to animal health and aquaculture. Simon is also a past president of the NI Veterinary Association and of the Northern Ireland Branch of BVA.Simon has authored many peer-reviewed scientic papers, tech-transfer articles and reports on a wide range of animal health and welfare issues and is also actively involved in the provision of veterinary careers advice, regularly mentoring applicants to veterinary school..prettyPhoto

title: Ballylone Flute Band celebrates 110th anniversary
story: BALLYLONE Concert Flute Band celebrated eleven decades of music making, with a dinner at Temple Golf Club on Saturday night.The band has seven flute sections mdash piccolo, trebles, concerts, altos, basses, contra bass, and sub-contra bass, as well as percussion.The conductor since  has been Philip Walton, who is also deputy conductor of the Ulster Orchestra, and the arranger is Alan Trimble. Craig McAllister has succeeded his father, David, as Drum Major.Competing since , the band became Flute Band  champions in ,  and , and World Senior Flute Band champions in , , ,  and .On Saturday night Mr Walton was kept busy handing out a large number of long service awards. Looking to the future, members of the young learnersrsquo class received their certicates from the Royal Schools of Music.The band was formed in  from local families in Ballylone townland. This family basis continues to the present day, with additional talent drawn from farther afield. lsquoFamilyrsquo means extended family, with fathers, sons, daughters, husbands and wives all taking part.This year has been special for one Ballylone family, with the passing of band veteran Ainsley Harrison. Ainsleyrsquos father, Bill, was a founder member, who served  years as secretary. Four of his grandchildren and seven of his great grandchildren play in todayrsquos band. His sons, Sam and Ainsley, joined the band, naturally.During WW band practice was suspended for three years and the instruments were stored on the Harrison farm. Young Ainsley took the opportunity to become proficient on every iety of flute. He eventually served for  years as flautist and was appointed band president on retirement from playing.On his death his children requested that memorial donations in lieu be given for the bandrsquos benefit. They then purchased a new Trevor James alto flute, and presented it in Ainsleyrsquos memory. This flute is now played on parades by his daughter, Sandra.David Burrows, from another Ballylone family, received a clock in appreciation of his  yearsrsquo service. His we recently retired from the band and three daughters and two of his grandchildren are members. He and Ainsley were instrumental in the rebuilding of Ballylone Hall in .Saturday nightrsquos dinner was a thoroughly enjoyable occasion, celebrating the bandrsquos past and looking forward to its future. title: Charitable cyclists hand over cheque to Mainstay
story: BIG-HEARTED cyclists have raised pound, for Mainstay DRP in Downpatrick.Philip Todd, Paddy Moore and Claire Magennis, three members of the Mainstay DRP management committee, were joined by Jim McMullan, Greer Lowe and another man also Paddy Moore for a fund-raising cycle along the Northern Ireland coast.Even the weather couldnrsquot hold them back as they cycled  miles from Derry to Newry over four days to raise vital funds for the charityrsquos work.On the third day they rode  miles around Strangford Lough and in total, they climbed , feet over the four days.A spokesman for Mainstay DRP, which works with adults with learning disabilities and or autism, said: ldquoFor those of you interested, thatrsquos , pedal revolutions and an average of  miles per hour.ldquoIt was a huge success and the efforts of all involved should be applauded.The charity hopes to run another cycle, of a similar duration, in June next year.Anyone interested in taking part is asked to get in touch with the charity on    option  and ask to speak to Kate..prettyPhoto

title: Decision time in semi finals
story: THERE are GAA championship semi-final showdowns all the way this weekend.The action gets underway on Friday night at Pairc Esler in Newry when Darragh Cross face Liatroim in the first of the Parador Lodge IFC semi-finals at .pm. This will be followed by the Morgan Fuels SFC last four encounter between derby rivals Burren and Mayobridge at .pm.Twenty-four hours later at the same venue, Bredagh and Saul lock horns in the IFC at .pm and at pm champions Kilcoo take on Warrenpoint in the SFC.The Darragh Cross v Liatroim clash is a tough one to call.Both teams play in Division  with Darragh enjoying the better of results and are sitting just outside the top four with games in hand. Inconsistency has plagued Liatroim all season and they are precariously perched fourth from bottom with three league games left to play.Darragh beat Liatroim in the league - to - back in August and also accounted for Atticall, Drumgath and Bredagh in the championship, while Liatroim lost to Atticall, but saw off Dundrum and St Johnrsquos in the Championship.Darragh will look to Matty Hardy, Oisin McConvey, Shane Murray, Lee Morrison, Marcus Miskelly and Michael Monan with Liatroim banking on big games from P J Davidson, Conor and Ruairi McCrickard, Gerard McAnulty and Liam Middleton.Darragh seem to have the edge in experience and their exciting attacking formation should be too much for Liatroim to handle.The Burren v Mayobridge SFC clash is expected to be an intriguing affair with no quarter asked or given.Paddy OrsquoRourkersquos side sit proudly at the top of the ACFL Division , but lost both league games this season to Mayobridge, who are six points behind the leaders with a game in hand.Burren have been impressive in beating Loughinisland, Carryduff and Castlewellan to get this far with Mayobridge accounting for An Riocht, Saval and Clonduff.Burren are a solid all-round side and can rely on Donal OrsquoHare, Liam Kerr, Paudie Poland, Ryan Treanor, Cathal Foy and David McEntee to take and make scores.Benny Coulter has Mayobridge purring again and in Ryan Brady, Cathal Magee, Caolan Gallagher, Conleth OrsquoHare and Kevin McClorey he has potential match winners who will all need stoppingBurren are to progress.Bredagh are expected to see off Saul in the IFC on Friday night, given they play in a higher ision.However, Saul are just one more win away from lting the Division  title and a win over Glasdrumman in their last game on October  will see them promoted as champions.On their day, Bredagh are a match for anyone and should have too much power for Saul. However, Donnan Ritchiersquos side showed against a fancied Ballymartin outfit that they fear one one andthey can repeat that sort of display then Bredagh may watch out.Bredagh will look for big efforts from Donal Hughes, Tommy McElroy, Donal McKegney, Michael Robinson, Conor Francis and Owen Costello with Saul relying on Adam King, Cathail Arnold, the Harney brothers, Caolan Magee and Rory Mullen.Unfortunately, star player Pierce Laverty will miss the game as he headed off to Australia on Sunday to take part in a week-long series of Aussie Rules trials.Following this game, Kilcoo will continue in their bid to make it seven-in-a-row when they face Warrenpoint.Kilcoo have again arrived at this stage of the competition with a minimum of fuss and itrsquos going to take an exceptional side to wrestle the Frank OrsquoHare Cup from their grasp.Ryan and Jerome Johnston look to be flying again after an injury-interrupted season and they have the perfect foils in Conor Laverty and Ceilum Doherty with Paul Devlin directing affairs in and around the middle of the park.The Branagan brothers are also expected to have a massive impact on the game as they set about taming Joe Magee, Aaron Magee, Ross McGarry, Ryan Mallon and Ryan and John Boyle.There is also a county final to look forward to on Sunday when Portaferry and Ballycran battle it out for the Senior Hurling Championship title in Ballygalget at pm..prettyPhoto

title: Fantástico%2C Emma
story: LOUGHINISLAND girl Emma Branf has been named as the top Spanish student in the UK and Ireland.The  year-old former Assumption Grammar School student was given the accolade by the Spanish Embassy in the UK and Ireland at a ceremony held at IES Vicente Cantildeada Blanch in London.Itrsquos the first time the award has gone to a student from Northern Ireland.Emma was accompanied to the awards ceremony by her proud mother, Francesca.She and her teachers were also rewarded with a tour of the IES Cantildeada Blanch School, the only bilingual Spanish and English School in the United Kingdom and Ireland, located in London.Emma said: ldquoI am delighted with this achievement but I must also pay tribute to the quality of language teaching in Assumption Grammar. I wouldnrsquot be where I am todayit had not been for my teachers there.School principal Peter Dobbin said that he was thrilled that the honour went to Emma and the schoolrsquos Languages Department.ldquoEmma richly deserved this public recognition of what she has achieved, he said. ldquoIt also highlights the crucial importance of learning languages as a le skill for all our young people.ldquoI am privileged to lead a school with an incredible Languages Department, with top performing linguists who continuously inspire the Assumption pupils.Mr Dobbin explained that the award acknowledges not only the results achieved in Spanish but also performance in other subjects across the curriculum at A Level.ldquoOur Head of Spanish, James Leonard, leads a department which continues to set the highest of standards in the United Kingdom and Ireland. Our Assumption pupils are blessed to have such a talented linguist at the helm, he added.Mr Leonard described Emma as a ldquostar student, with no Spanish background, yet naturally gted, and excels at a level which surpasses all expectation.Lynsey Patton, who taught Emma for six years, and who identied and nurtured her potential in languages, added: ldquoIt has been a joy to watch her develop linguistically. She certainly has a bright future ahead.Emmarsquos prize is a three-day visit to the region of Castilla y Leoacuten, which she will embark upon in early .She is currently taking a gap year, working in Paris, and will continue her linguistic studies at university next year..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 3%2C 1978
story: NEWCASTLE mdash A drastic slump in support for Newcastle Town Committee has thrown its future in the balance mdash and a special meeting in a fortnightrsquos time could decide whether it will carry on.Lack of support from the public, traders, clubs and organisations at last weekrsquos annual meeting has confronted the town committee with a major crisis and it may need a big increase in interest to persuade it to carry on.The town committee was formed four years ago to promote the area as a tourist attraction and since then the fortunes of Newcastle have improved dramatically.Mr Bill Martin, town committee chairman, was clearly disappointed at the lack of public support and in a hard-hitting attack he called for more people to come forward and lend their weight to the committee.ldquoItrsquos shattering to think that only a handful of people are prepared to come to our annual meeting, he said. ldquoHow can we make Newcastle the top report in the provincewersquore not going to get the necessary support from the townspeople Mr Martin was critical of the apathy surrounding the town, considering the big steps it has taken over the last few years.Since the committeersquos formation the townrsquos trade and tourism has boomed, yet he claims the same old faces are having to do all the hard work.ldquoMy feelings are stronger than Irsquom prepared to say. Really, our committee must seriously question the need to go on. Is it worthwhile staying in existencewe are not backed by the people ldquoThe committeersquos path is at a crossroads and it is us who must decide the future. Which way we go will ultimately depend on the turnout at our next meeting.Mr Gerry Toner, another founder member of the committee, was also shocked at the appalling turnout at last weekrsquos meeting.ldquoI think it is very sad that the business people in the town are not prepared to come forward to do something positive for the area, he said.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch familyrsquos running protest against Down councillors took another turn this week with a noisy protest outside the councilrsquos headquarters in Downpatricik.Mrs Gemma Rice and her children began chanting and banging tin cans as councillors held their fortnightly meeting.In recent weeks the family has been mounting a silent picked outside the council offices when there are meetings in progress. They claim that councillors have done nothing to help them solve the smoke problem at their Carlisle Park home.The chanting outside the meeting went on for well over an hour. Inside, councillors decided against calling in the police as there were children involved. They closed the windows in the chamber and tried to speak over the noise from outside.DOWNPATRICK mdash Down councillors are staying firmly on course with their plans to open a major dumping site in a picturesque area less than half a mile from the Quoile River, outside Downpatrick.Despite facing a mounting wall of protest from planners and conservationists, councillors decided this week to stick to their guns and push ahead with the scheme.The site eats up almost  acres of land, about half a mile from Quoile Yacht Club, and the council scheme entails a six-feet excavation of the entire area.Pollution controllers at Stormont have already come out against the scheme because they fear it could pollute the nearby Quoile River and local planners have received many complaints from conservationists.Even councillors themselves are split and some launched into fierce opposition of the scheme at this weekrsquos council meeting.Downpatrick councillor George Flinn, whose home is less than a five-minute walk from the river, was the sternest critic and he pulled no punches in an open attack on the plan.ldquoI am appalled that a council which prides itself on being forward-looking should be asked to agree to the vandalising of one of the areas of outstanding natural beauty within its district.KILLYLEAGH mdash Residents of Killyleagh and Shrigley have called for a full debate on the future of the harbour site and possible marina plans. It will be top of the list for discussion when the local town committee holds their annual meeting in January .Other matters to be discussed at the AGM are law and order and the future of the vandalised community hall. Senior representatives of the RUC will be invited to attend.The town committee wishes to advise all residents of Killyleagh and Shrigley that its meetings are held on the last Thursday of every month. Any matters of general communal interest which they wish to be discussed should be communicated to committee members.PORTAFERRY mdash A Portaferry motorist and his front seat passenger were killed instantly on Saturday when their car collided head-on with an Ulsterbus.Police are still trying to determine the cause of the accident which killed Mr Trevor Mahood, of Shore Road, and Mr David McVeigh, of Lawson Gardens, Portavogie.The crash occurred at the Kingrsquos Corner blackspot between Greyabbey and Kircubbin. Another passenger in the car is still seriously ill in hospital. The bus driver and two passengers on the bus were slightly injured.CROSSGAR mdash Plans have been drawn up to make Lissara Presbyterian Churchrsquos annual harvest fair on Saturday a bigger lsquoknockoutrsquo than usual. One of the ideas being introduced to make the fair a major success is a local version of the renowned TV show lsquoItrsquos a Knockoutrsquo.Teams for dferent congregations in Crossgar district will compete in a iety of games introduced by Mr Dermot Nesbitt in the War Memorial Hall. The fun doesnrsquot begin until .pm, but there are many other things to keep visitors busy during the afternoon.KILCOO mdash A local missionary, Sister Alphonsus Devlin, from Kilcoo, is at present home on vacation from Pakistan where she teaches in a diocese of . million people.She works under very strenuous conditions where the extreme heat in the summer causes many diseases, as well as drought, and where living standards are very low.Before going back to Pakistan she has been trying to thank local people for their prayers, moral support and donations which were sent over.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Castlewellan Lake has proved to be a happy hunting ground recently for many local anglers, according to figures released by the Department of Agriculture.One Castlewellan fisherman, Jerry Mullan, netted a three-quarter pound rainbow trout and a lb brown trout from the lake recently, while other anglers reported good catches.DUNDRUMmdash Murlough Nature Reserve, Dundrum, will be setting for a series of winter walks starting this Sunday. The scheme is being organised by the National Trust and follows a series of successful summer walks.RACING mdash A record attendance of over , turned up at Downpatrick racecourse on Saturday to pay tribute to triple Grand National winner Red Rum.Probably the most famous racehorse of modern times, Red Rum revelled in the attention shown by thousands of admiring fans.Posing for the camera, allowing himself to be stroked and petted have all become part of Rummyrsquos le.Host to Red Rum and his entourage was Mr Jeremy Maxwell, chairman of Downpatrick Race Supporters Club. ldquoWe have had a most successful day andwe have done anything surely we have shown to the government what is obvious to most people that Downpatrick racecourse is very much alive..prettyPhoto

title: Giant Castlewellan tree shortlisted for accolade
story: A GIANT Redwood tree with  trunks in Castlewellan Forest Park has been shortlisted for the Woodland Trustrsquos Tree of the Year competition for .The Giant Redwood has been associated with Castlewellan Castle back to the s when the castle was built.The treersquos history is linked to all the plant hunters and explorers of the time who risked their lives bringing back exotic plants from thousands of miles away.Itrsquos believed to have been grown from the very first Giant Sequoia seeds brought back to England from Calornia in .Three years later, the third Earl Annesley obtained ten small samplings from England in and planted some of them in the Walled Garden at Castlewellan Castle, which was their family home at the time.The Holm Oak at Kibroney Park in Rostrevor was crowned Northern Irelandrsquos Tree of the Year in .Newry, Mourne and Down District Council chairman Mark Murnin is urging all the districtrsquos residents to vote for the Giant Redwood.ldquoIt would be wonderfulanother tree within the council area won this year, he said. ldquoIt is gratying to have one of our most venerable trees nominated for this prestigious award.ldquoI have seen this tree many times, and it is truly magnicent. The Giant Redwood attracts visitors from around the world, and is much loved by local families.To vote please do so before am, Monday, October , by visiting www.woodlandtrust.org.uk treeoftheyearvote..prettyPhoto

title: Kielty appointed integrated education patron
story: DUNDRUM comedian Patrick Kielty has become a patron and supporter for the Northern Ireland Council for Integrated Education.The US-based father-of-two hit the headlines last weekend for his Twitter explanation of the implications of Brexit on both sides of the Irish border.He joins Carl Frampton, Liam Neeson and Sir Kenneth Branagh as celebrity patrons of the Council.Earlier this year, Patrick authored a landmark documentary for BBC, lsquoMy Dad, The Peace Deal and Mersquo, which explored the legacy of Northern Irelandrsquos peace deal  years on. The documentary received audience and critical acclaim.He said of his support for integrated education: ldquoIf we want to change the future we need to start with our kids, letting them discover what they have in common.He also referred to a visit to Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle.ldquoWhen I visited Shimna Integrated College earlier this year it was great to see young people with opposing political opinions freely expressing themselves as friends, he said.ldquoWersquore one society made up from dferent backgrounds, not two communities. Letrsquos celebrate it and move forward together..prettyPhoto

title: Kilclief in full flow as ‘Fin are bottled up
story: A RESILIENT Kilclief outfit produced a rousing second half display to shatter Aughlisnafinrsquos championship dreams at St Colmanrsquos Park, Drumaness, on Saturday.Despite going into the break only - to - down, Kilclief were staring down the barrel of an ignoble defeat after losing the influential Louis McMullan and James McGrath to early black cards.To make matters even worse, they also lost the talismanic Ciaran Sloan to a hamstring injury and almost down to the bare bones, they looked vulnerable and there for the taking.However, led brilliantly by Aiden McCann and Eoin King they took the game to Aughlisnafin with a swagger and sparkle that Willie Megoranrsquos side were unable to contain.Aughlisnafin were impressively out of the traps first. Midfielder Eoin Lundy took the gamersquos first score before Ciaran Sloan levelled matters with a converted free. Unanswered points from the imposing Oran Flanagan, two frees and a rsquo, edged the lsquoFin into a deserved - to - lead by the seventh minute.It could have been even worse for Kilclief had Conall Magee not appeared from nowhere to block a certain Colm McVeigh goal with his foot.Lundy then made it a three-point game with a superlative score, but Kilclief, responded with points from Ciaran Sloan and Callum Shields after registering several wides.The lsquoFin finished the first half strongly and two more frees from Oran Flanagan gave them a - to - lead after  minutes. The last score of the half went to Kilcliefrsquos Dale Curran in the th minute to leave two points between the sides.Kilclief manager Dee King switched things round at the back for the start of the second half and this brought an immediate change in fortunes.Aughlisnafin were given fair warning of the maelstrom that was building up when Caelan Savage hit the woodwork after only  seconds of the restart and within minutes, points from Savage and Conor Sloan had the sides level.Aughlisnafin retaliated with a Sean Fitzsimmons goal against the run of play in the th minute, but two points from Caelan Savage left just a point between the sides by the th minute.Lundy and Shane Mooney extended Aughlisnafinrsquos lead to three points again, - to -, with  minutes remaining, but it was Kilclief who had a deadly sting in their tails.Caelan Savage was the lsquogo torsquo man and he delivered in style with a goal and a point to put Kilclief into the lead for the first time in the game and they never looked back after this.A Conor Sloan score and two points from lsquokeeper Ryan Miskelly, a rsquo and a long distance free, was the icing on the cake for Kilclief as they surged into the showdown with Teconnaught at Pairc Esler on October . Subs: E Breen for McMullan , D Curranfor McGrath , Conor Sloanfor Ciaran Sloan, S Cultra for Curran. title: Local historical society celebrates 70th anniversary
story: THE Lecale and Downe Historical Society recently celebrated seven decades of preserving and promoting the history and heritage of Lecale and County Down.At a th anniversary dinner at Denvirrsquos Hotel mdash the original meeting place of the society in  mdash a three course meal was enjoyed by  members and friends.A presentation of an engraved gavel was made by Mr Johnny Dooher, of the Federation of Ulster Local Studies.Following the dinner and refreshments the special guest for the evening, eminent Irish historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, gave his address on the lsquoDecade of Centenariesrsquo of -.Mr Roderick Downer, chair of the society, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be celebrating this milestone in the societyrsquos own history and to mark it.ldquoIt was wonderful to have so many members of the society, from all walks of le, join together for an enjoyable evening with a riveting talk by Dr Phoenix.The society will also be celebrating  years of continuous publishing when it launches the latest edition of Lecale Review in November.The Review is an eclectic mix of historical stories from the area. This yearrsquos edition will include articles such as a history of the Hollymount estate near Downpatrick, shipwrecks of Co Down, the Home Guard post WW and a story entitled lsquoThe Great Cat of Cloughrsquo..prettyPhoto

title: Lord Eames to talk at lecture
story: LORD Eames, the former Church of Ireland primate, will be the guest speaker at the Saint Patrick Centre in Downpatrick this Friday evening.His talk, entitled lsquoSaint Patrick, Armagh and the search for Common Groundrsquo, is the second of the Legacy Autumn Lecture Series at the centre.Lord Eames was the longest-serving Archbishop of Armagh and the most senior primate in the Anglican Communion.The high points of his ecclesiastical career were often on the international stage. A lawyer by training and a cleric by vocation, he served as Chairman of the Lambeth Commission on Communion, which produced the Windsor Report in October .He has been awarded many accolades, including nine honorary doctorates and the Freedom of the City of Armagh.Fridayrsquos lecture begins at pm and admission is free..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland author delves into legacy of St Patrick
story: THE St Patrickrsquos Treasury is a unique celebration of the myths, legends and traditions of Irelandrsquos patron saint.Written by Loughinisland man John Killen, author and former chief librarian at the Linenhall Library in Belfast, it reflects a long-held interest in the le, writings and legacy of St Patrick.Beautully illustrated, this book from Blackstaff Press includes information on places associated with Patrick, such as Downpatrick, Saul, Armagh, Cashel and Slemish.It also examines ious religious relics and traditions associated with one of the best-known and best-loved saints in the world.Itrsquos an accessible yet meticulous approach, which has been a labour of love for John, who brings together the stories that have been associated with St Patrick across the centuries. Of particular interest to local readers will be sections on Saul mdash the place of Patrickrsquos landing.Observing the interest of those outside Ireland on St Patrick, John began thinking seriously about his book project five years ago.He said: ldquoSt Patrick is so obviously supported across the world ndash what is it that causes that support ldquoI was brought up outside Downpatrick in Loughinisland. I assumed I knew everything about St Patrick. I wanted to see ndash what do we know about St Patrick  I wanted to go back. I wanted an anthology of peoplersquos writings throughout the centuries, build up a picture of what he was and what he means throughout our history over , years.John said some of his findings were a ldquototal surprise, such as the article by Maureen Donnelly lsquoThe Altar Stone of Saul Abbeyrsquo. This details how the altar stone on which Patrick is said to have celebrated Holy Communion ended up on a wagon owned by a man who wanted it for the doorstep of his new house at the junction of Saul Street and Scotch Street in . But the wagon overturned, the stone broke and it found its way instead to the Catholic Church in Saul.ldquoI never realised there was an altar stone of St Patrick actually in Saul chapel, John said. ldquoI went three times to try and see it. I could not get in the first time as there was a ceremony on. It took me a bit of time to find it. This is one of the earliest and possibly holiest relics in Ireland open to all to see.John said he was also ldquoblown away by a stained-glass window, lsquoPatrick Arrives in Saulrsquo, in Saul Chapel.ldquoThe three windows are designed so the three windows show one image, he explained. ldquoIt is absolutely beautul.John is the author of many books, including The Irish Christmas Book and The Unkindest Cut: A Cartoon History of Ulster -, as well as books on the Irish famine and the United Irishmen.Surrounded by sites linked to our patron saint in Downpatrick, John believes at times we ldquocanrsquot see the woods from the trees.He points to the massive success of less important sites in the south, or how such a historical location would promoted ldquoto the nth degree in the US.ldquoI think that is the challenge for people here today, he said. ldquoThere is so much scope, there really is. I think we lose the wood from the trees. So many stories, so many things to pursue.Interestingly, his research points to an attitude from some in the south of Patrick being a ldquonorthern saint. There is also, of course, the increased secularisation of Ireland.ldquoBut there are still a massive amount of people who are people of faith, John continued.ldquoWe live in an area of huge historical importance. Because we are so familiar we often just take it for granted.The St Patrickrsquos Treasury is available through selected bookstores and online retailers such as Amazon..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland seal league
story: LOUGHINISLAND secured a place in the top flight of Down football when coming out on top in a thrilling encounter against Longstone on Saturday.In the process they maintained their record of having won every league game to date in an action-packed encounter at the picturesque Mourne venue.The Blues got off to a great start with two points from the impressive Declan McClements, either side of one from Paddy McKenny which settled them into the game.It took ten minutes for Longstone to open their scoring when Michael Ireland slotted over the bar before getting his sidersquos second with a close range free. A Stefan Mason point put two between the sides, but Longstone were quick to answer when Conor Shields closed the gap to a point at the end of the first quarter.Declan McClements, Rory Mason and Stefan Mason added a further two points apiece with Aaron McClements scoring a superb point to cap a great first half for the visitors and help them to a six-points cushion.A brace of points from Mark Poland and an excellent score from Dean Haughian brought the lsquoStone back into contention, but they still trailed - to - as Ronan Barry blew for half-time.As expected, Longstone came out with a sense of purpose on the restart. A point by Stefan Mason was cancelled out by a similar score from Declan Magee for the home side. Jonny Flynn split the posts for the Blues, but Longstone were quick to reply with a close range free from Ireland.Two goals in two minutes for the home side meant they trailed by a single point and at this stage the game was anyones.However, Loughinislandrsquos recent senior championship campaign saw them battle-hardened and they stood tall to a man across the pitch as the Cloch Fhada men asked some serious questions going into the final quarter when they trailed by three points.Mark Poland and Rory Mason swapped scores and Declan McClements extended his sidersquos lead to four before Longstone hit back once again through former country star Poland.With six minutes to go and the game flowing from end to end, Conor Megoran picked up the ball on the right wing and sent it high into the Longstone square.Stefan Mason reacted quickest and with his back to goal shimmied to make space for a shot which flew past Michael McStay and into the back of the net.Longstone threw everything at the Bluesrsquo defence with Dan Gordon and Sean Cochrane combining to bravely block a certain goal-bound effort with Gordon taking a boot in the face for his troubles.Longstone knew it was not to be their day when Chris Turley denied them with a fantastic save to tip the ball over the bar with two minutes left on the clock.When they needed to dig deep, Loughinisland showed their true mettle. Having been rocked when conceding the two second half goals they steadied the ship with a defence led by Paddy Megoran, Dan Gordon, Jonny Flynn and Dean McLoughlin putting in a rousing last ten minutes when Longstone asked some serious questions.Declan McClements showed a stature beyond his youthful years in midfield, knocking over five points from play. Aaron McClements looked back to his old self with some magnicent high fielding which propelled his team forward throughout the  minutes.In the forward line Stefan Mason top-scored with - and alongside Conor Megoran and Rory Mason gave the Longstone defence plenty to think about with great support from Paddy McKenny, John McCarthy and Paul Digney.Loughinisland: C Turley, S Cochrane, P Megoran, C OrsquoToole, D McLoughlin , D Gordon, J Flynn , D McClements , A McClements , R Mason , P McKenny , P Digney, C Megoran, Stefan Mason , J McCarthy.Longstone -Loughinisland -ACFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: Pierce heads to Australia
story: A YOUNG Saul Gaelic footballer has just jetted off to Australia to compete for a potential Aussie Rules professional contract.Under the expert guidance of former Down and AFL star Marty Clarke,  year-old Pierce Laverty has successfully secured a ticket to Melbourne for a series of trials.Pierce will get a week to train and acclimatise before testing starts on October  in goal kicking, skills, agility, time-trials and jump tests.All the big AFL clubs will be observing the training and testing week and will select players who they think are good enough to make it.Typically, Pierce is taking this opportunity in his stride, and itrsquos his combination of skill, athleticism and attitude that has set him apart.Unfortunately, Pierce will miss Saulrsquos Parador Lodge IFC semi-final clash with Bredagh in Newry on Saturday night, but hersquos hoping his team-mates can make it through without him and that he will be home in time for the final..prettyPhoto

title: Sam Rutherford Cup belongs to St Patrick’s
story: ST Patrickrsquos Golf Club are the proud holders of the Sam Rutherford Cup.Saturday and Sunday witnessed the clash of the titans as St Patrickrsquos took on neighbours Rockmount in the two-leg final.The first leg was played at St Patrickrsquos in ideal conditions for golf with a light breeze and sunny conditions.Rockmount had chosen to play away from home as they had enjoyed good results from this tactic in previous rounds. However, St Patrickrsquos were not going to be complacent in their approach and fully recognised the quality of their opponents.St Patrickrsquos had the right blend of youth and experience and the games were played with great spirit and determination.The first pairing of James Kernoghan and Pearse Tumelty succumbed to the power and precision of Rockmountrsquos top pairing and lost out by two holes.Pocket rockets Gary Murrayand Ed Baggley Jr were second out and played their usual power game with the addition of sublime putting finesse to win by two holes.The third pairing of Paddy Totton and Gary Murraydelivered the killer blow to Rockmount and romped home by four holes.Their tenacity and resilience proved to be the foundation for the rest of the team. The last pairing of the rock steady Adrian Magee and Declan Dowie continued their unbeaten run in the competition, winning by one hole.The players from St Patrickrsquos did their club proud by winning the first leg with five holes up. Although this was a slender lead to take to Rockmount, the confidence of the lads to deliver away from home remained.For theleg at Rockmount conditions were much more dficult with a swirling wind and occasional showers.The St Patrickrsquos opening pair was Totton mdash the lsquodaddy of the team mdash and the Strangford Murray. They played some sublime golf with Totton driving like a professional and the silky putting skills of Murray resulting in them winning their match by one hole. This again laid the foundation by beating Rockmountrsquos top pairing.Up next were the Crossgar Murray and Baggley Jr, who played like giants and produced some phenomenal golf against great opponents to win by one hole.The third pairing of Tumelty and Kernoghan proved their worth with the superb driving ability of Kernoghan combined with the steady chipping and unflappable putting of Tumelty resulting in a halved match.The final pairing of the mercurial Magee and Dowie proved once again how the youth of the team held no fears and played with complete passion and energy, never allowing any dips in performance to unravel their steely determination to win. They eventually won by two holes, birdieing the last two in an amazing cauldron of pressure.The match was played with great sportsmanship by both clubs and Rockmount were most gracious in defeat.St Patrickrsquos club captain Michael Donovan and team Captain Brendan Mullen were delighted to receive the pennant and cup from Dave Allen..prettyPhoto

title: Seal stranded on Murlough Beach
story: THIS young stricken seal was at the centre of a drama on Murlough Beach last week.Named as Panoramix, it emerged that the one-year-male ended up stranded on the beach after leaving its colony in Wexford.Several hours later as local National Trust wardens kept an eye on him, Panoramix finally was able to summon enough strength toto the water.The seal was spotted last Tuesday by Dundrum conservationist Seamus King as he scanned Dundrum bay from his telescope in his apartment.He soon realised that the seal was in dficulty as he seemed unable to move.Mr King said: ldquoThis was about pm and I saw that the seal was exhausted and had dficulty getting back into the water.ldquoIt seemed not to be moving at all and for a time I wonderedit was still alive.Seamus, who is a RSPB member and a volunteer with Mourner Heritage Trust, knew not to interfere with the seal but to seek expert advice.ldquoI called the seal manager, Amy Robinson, at Portaferry, and she contacted Sea Rescue Ireland who askedI could get close enough to get more information, said Mr King.ldquoWith the help of two National Trusts wardens, I approached the seal to take a picture of its tag. I was told that it was a young male from Sea Rescue Ireland in Wexford, not one of our own seal colony which live on the Ballykinlar side of Dundrum bay.The agreed plan of action was to keep an eye on the seal and to leave it overnight to seeit had moved before taking it to Exploris to safety the next day.Mr King adds: ldquoThe greatest danger was that he could have become more stressed had there been for example a dog in the area, or a walker getting too close. Any approach can make a seal more anxious.ldquoWe were able to establish some time later, thanks to our two National Trust friends, that had ed safely to the water, sometime between -pm..prettyPhoto

title: Ulster Bank site is put on the market
story: THE former Ulster Bank in Killyleagh has been put on the market for sale.The High Street branch closed earlier this year with the move criticised by customers who said the decision would have a major impact on the town.The branch was one of eight the Ulster Bank closed mdash a decision which bank officials described as ldquodficult.In a bid to soften the blow, officials said the bank provides customers with more ways to bank than ever before. They explained the way people bank has changed radically over the past few years with a signicant reduction in the number of customers using branches.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker, a former customer of the bank, hopes a buyer can be found for the property.ldquoThis is a prime site and I hope there is a willing buyer to redevelop the building and hopefully provide a number of new jobs, he said.Cllr Walker said he hoped the building will not be lying empty for too much longer.He added: ldquoThe building has been empty since last May and I hope the sale will generate interest in the former bank branch which I believe has much to offer potential buyers in the centre of the town..prettyPhoto

title: storm ali batters fermanagh
story: Fermanagh is facing unexpected high winds as Storm Ali batters the county.In Enniskillen, many local businesses have been forced to close due to a lack of power. The strong gales have caused damage to buildings as roof tiles and other debris litter East Bridge Street, resulting in the closure of the road.A spokeswoman from the PSNI stated: ldquoPolice are advising motorists and pedestrians that East Bridge Street in Enniskillen has been closed, due to falling roof tiles. A police cordon is in place and for safety reasons, officers are advising the public not to cross it.As the storm continues to wreak havoc on the county, reports of fallen trees are re.
